This study aims to assess the acute effects of furosemide on hemodynamics and pulmonary congestion in patients with acute heart failure. The study will be conducted as an open-label, single-group assignment, and will enroll patients who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria. The primary outcome measure will be the change in pulmonary fluid content after administration of furosemide, measured using remote dielectric sensing (ReDS). The study will be conducted at a single center, and will include 20 patients.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of a smartphone application in reducing binge drinking behavior among university students. The study is a non-randomized, parallel-group, triple-masked design, with an experimental group receiving the smartphone application and an active comparator group receiving a control intervention. The primary outcome measure is the change in the number of standard drinks per week over 30 months. Secondary outcome measures include changes in phosphatidylethanol (PEth) concentrations at various time points. The study is open to students aged 18-25 years who meet certain inclusion and exclusion criteria.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the potential benefit of nitazoxanide as an adjuvant therapy in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The study will be conducted as a randomized, open-label, parallel-group trial, with 35 patients in each group. The primary outcome measure will be glycemic control, and secondary outcome measures will include insulin resistance, lipid profile, and serum levels of A-kinase anchoring protein 1 and asprosin. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 weeks.

This study aims to investigate clinical risk factors of autism and to elucidate the changes in gut microbiome in Egyptian autistic children and their possible correlation with clinical outcomes and the severity of the disease. The study will be conducted on 50 autistic children and 50 healthy controls, aged between 3-9 years. The inclusion and exclusion criteria will be determined by the medical history taken from the parents of the children before test application. The study will be designed as an observational study, with no intervention. The primary outcome measures will be autism clinical risk factors, and the secondary outcome measures will be intestinal microbiome and metabolome analysis. The study will be conducted over a period of one year.

The study aims to develop an internet-based self-help money management program to improve financial self-efficacy and its associated adverse outcomes among adults with severe mental illness. The program consists of four weekly modules incorporating key components of money management and the Model of Human Occupation (MOHO). Participants in the money management condition will start the program immediately after randomization and complete the post-intervention assessment right after they finish the treatment. Participants in the waitlist control group will wait for four weeks without the program and then complete the post-intervention assessment. The primary outcome measures include change in financial self-efficacy, financial behavior, financial attitude, and financial well-being. Secondary outcome measures include change in psychological well-being, anxiety symptom, depressive symptom, and quality of life.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of START (Startle Adjuvant Rehabilitation Therapy) in enhancing upper extremity function post-stroke. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial with 60 participants, divided into two groups: an experimental group that will receive START therapy and a sham control group that will not receive START therapy. The primary outcome measures will include changes in electromyography (EMG) onset, amplitude, and movement linearity during a functional reaching task, as well as changes in functional reaching task scores and skill transfer to untrained tasks. The study will assess the effectiveness of START therapy in improving upper extremity function and skill transfer in individuals with stroke.

The study aims to evaluate the effects of endoscopic lung volume reduction on diaphragm function and conformation in patients with hyperinflated COPD. The study will be conducted as a single-arm, open-label, before-and-after study, with all patients receiving endoscopic lung volume reduction. The primary outcome measures will be transdiaphragmatic pressure and diaphragmatic conformation, evaluated before and 3 months after unilateral ELVR.

The study aims to compare the clinical performance of dual- and light-cure bulk-fill resin composites in Class II restorations over a two-year period. The study is a randomized clinical trial with three arms: Fill-Up bulk-fill resin composite, QuiXfil bulk-fill resin composite, and Tetric N-Ceram Bulk Fill bulk-fill resin composite. The primary outcome measures are esthetic properties, functional properties, and biological properties, all evaluated using FDI criteria. The study will assess the clinical performance of the three bulk-fill resin composites in terms of their ability to maintain the health of the teeth and prevent caries recurrence.

This clinical trial is comparing the effectiveness of 177Lu-DOTATATE versus everolimus in treating metastatic midgut neuroendocrine tumors. The study will assess the progression-free survival, overall survival, objective response rate, post-progression survival, and time to second objective disease progression of both treatments. The study will enroll 100 participants and will be conducted at a single site.

The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival, and the secondary outcome measures include overall survival, objective response rate, post-progression survival, and time to second objective disease progression. The study will use a parallel-group design with randomization to either 177Lu-DOTATATE or everolimus.

The study population will consist of patients with metastatic midgut neuroendocrine tumors who have progressed after previous peptide receptor radionuclide therapy. Patients will be excluded if they have brain metastases, uncontrolled congestive heart failure, or any other significant medical or surgical condition that may interfere with the safety or efficacy assessment of the investigational regimen.

The study will be conducted at a single site, and the estimated enrollment date is December 2022. The estimated completion date is March 2025.

The study will be conducted in accordance with the International Conference on Harmonisation Good Clinical Practice guidelines and the applicable regulatory requirements. The study protocol has been approved by the institutional review board, and informed consent will be obtained from all participants.

The study aims to compare the effects of Mulligan technique versus McKenzie extension exercise with manual traction in patients with chronic unilateral radicular low back pain. The primary outcome measures will be pain reduction and range of motion. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial with 16 patients in each group. The patients will be treated with Mulligan techniques or McKenzie extension exercises with manual traction for four weeks, and the assessment will be done at baseline and at the completion of the intervention. The study will be conducted at Rehab Care and Jinnah Hospital Lahore from June 1st to January 31st, 2024.

This clinical trial is investigating the long-term safety, tolerability, and efficacy of weekly subcutaneous doses of TransCon CNP in children and adolescents with achondroplasia. The study is open-label and will enroll participants who have completed a previous clinical trial with TransCon CNP. Participants will receive weekly subcutaneous injections of TransCon CNP for up to 10 years. The primary outcome measures will be safety and tolerability, and height Z-scores. Secondary outcome measures will include annualized growth velocity.

This observational study aims to investigate the impact of illness perceptions and coping strategies on quality of life in patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. The study will use correlation analysis and mediation analyses to assess the mediating effects of self-efficacy, coping, depression, and anxiety on quality of life. The primary outcome measure will be the 12-item Short Form Health Survey (SF-12), which will be measured at the start of the study and up to 24 weeks. The study will include patients aged 18-75 years with a diagnosis of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, based on a 12-lead ECG and cardiologist-led examination. Exclusion criteria include severe complications, malignant disease, psychiatric conditions, participation in another study, and cognitive impairment.

The LORENA trial is a clinical study that aims to assess the success rate of local excision as a treatment for early rectal cancer, with no adjuvant therapy, in order to preserve the rectum. The study will be conducted in patients with clinical staging cT1N0M0, who are older than 18 years old, and have a tumor inferior verge not farther than 2 cm proximal to the anorectal rim. The primary outcome measure will be the success rate of no need of total mesorectal excision after follow-up, and the secondary outcome measures will include postoperative complication rate, radicality of resection, histological poor outcome predictor rate, and radical rescue surgery specimen quality. The study will be conducted in two arms: local excision and total mesorectal excision. The study will be conducted in two centers, and the estimated enrollment is 145 patients. The study will be conducted over 36 months, and the follow-up period will be 36 months.

The study aims to evaluate the outcomes of patients undergoing surgical repair for type A aortic dissection. The study will compare the outcomes of patients who undergo conservative root-sparing aortic valve resuspension with or without hemiarch repair, extensive ascending aorta replacement with aortic root replacement, and total arch replacement. The primary outcome measures will include operative mortality, rate of mesenteric ischemia, rate of permanent neurologic deficit, rate of composite of major adverse events, and rate of perioperative myocardial infarction. Secondary outcome measures will include rate of transient neurologic deficit, rate of spinal cord injury, rate of acute kidney injury, rate of perioperative bleeding, reoperation for bleeding, rate of mechanical circulatory support, rate of composite of major adverse pulmonary events, and rate of late survival.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of virtual reality (VR) in reducing academic stress and improving academic performance in physiotherapy and nursing students of the University of the Balearic Islands. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with 3 arms: an experimental group that will use VR, an active comparator group that will use traditional guided visualization, and a control group that will not receive any intervention. The primary outcomes will be the intra-group and between-group differences in academic stress and perceived stress in the last month, as well as the level of current perceived stress, blood pressure, maximal heart rate, and salivary cortisol level just before starting the exam. Secondary outcomes will include the exam qualification pondered by the average qualification of the degree. The study will be conducted over 4 weeks, with two sessions per week for each group.

This clinical trial aims to compare the efficacy and safety of remimazolam and propofol as anesthesia induction agents in morbid obesity patients undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy. The study will enroll 44 patients in each group and will be conducted at Seoul National University Bundang Hospital. The primary outcome measure will be the rate of hypotension events during anesthesia induction, and secondary outcome measures will include induction time, vasopressor use, and adverse events. The study will use a randomized, parallel-group design with a single-blind masking.

This study is a phase II clinical trial that aims to assess the efficacy and safety of the combination of darolutamide, leuprolide acetate, and exemestane in treating patients with recurrent adult-type granulosa cell tumors of the ovary. The primary outcome measure is the objective response rate, and the secondary outcome measures include duration of response, progression-free survival, and overall survival. The study will be conducted as an open-label, single-arm trial, and patients will receive exemestane, darolutamide, and leuprolide acetate according to a specific dosing schedule. The study will also assess the incidence of adverse events.

This study aims to assess the effects of Elexacaftor/ tezacaftor/ ivacaftor (ETI) on gastrointestinal function and structure in children with cystic fibrosis (CF) aged 6 to 11 years. The study will use MRI to measure gastrointestinal physiology, lung structure and function, and liver endpoints in children with CF before and after starting ETI. The study will also include healthy volunteers for comparison. The primary outcome measure will be the change in small bowel water content between study time points. Secondary outcome measures will include small bowel water content, liver volume, liver elastography, and lung ventilation.

This is a randomized, double-blind, controlled bi-center study comparing the postoperative analgesic efficacy of dexamethasone and methylprednisolone in caudal block for children undergoing hypospadias surgical repair. The primary outcome measure is the duration of analgesia, and the secondary outcome measures include the severity of postoperative pain and side effects. The study will enroll 100 patients, aged 1 to 6 years, who will be randomly assigned to receive either dexamethasone or methylprednisolone in addition to bupivacaine for caudal block. The study will be conducted at two centers, and the results will be analyzed using intention-to-treat principles.

This study aims to evaluate the impact of hemodiafiltration (HDF) on the regeneration of marginal donor lungs during ex vivo lung perfusion (EVLP). The study is a prospective, randomized, parallel-assignment, open-label pilot study. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the EVLP + HDF group or the EVLP-only group. The primary outcome measure is the suitability for transplantation of the lungs after 6 hours of EVLP with HDF. Secondary outcome measures include PGD grade 3 at 72 hours after transplantation, survival, length of mechanical ventilation, length of ICU stay, and length of hospital stay. The study will enroll 10 participants in each group and will be conducted at a single center.

This study aims to compare the effectiveness of white noise and multisensory stimulation in retinopathy examination on premature infants. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with premature infants randomly assigned to three groups: the control group, the white noise group, and the multisensory stimulation group. The primary outcome measures will include physiological responses, behavioral indicators, and overall examination success rate. The study will be conducted in a controlled environment to ensure consistency across groups, and statistical analyses will be employed to compare the outcomes between the three groups. The results of this study will inform healthcare professionals and researchers about the benefits of auditory stimulation (white noise) and the additional advantages of multisensory stimulation during retinopathy examinations.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of a modified calculation formula for meibomian gland grading. The study will enroll participants aged 18 to 80 years old, with no history of eye surgeries or systemic health conditions affecting ocular health. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the previous calculation formula or the modified calculation formula group. The primary outcome measures will be the area of the meibomian glands and the whole eyelids, and the WTW distance of the cornea, measured at baseline.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of Zinc Gluconate in the prevention of oral mucositis in patients undergoing radiotherapy for head and neck cancer. The study is a single-blind randomized clinical trial, with two arms: the experimental arm receiving Zinc Gluconate and the control arm receiving a solution based on sodium chloride and bicarbonate. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of oral mucositis one week after the end of radiotherapy. Secondary outcome measures include the time of onset and severity of oral mucositis.

This study aims to determine the predictive ability of a panel of biomarkers in saliva in healthy and periodontally affected subjects. The study will be conducted as a cross-sectional clinical study, and the participants will be recruited from the dental clinic. The primary outcome measures will be the salivary biomarkers, and the secondary outcome measures will include demographic information, medical history, and periodontal parameters. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months, and the results will be analyzed to determine the predictive ability of the biomarkers.

The study aims to investigate the effect of white noise, heart sound, and music on reducing neonatal pain during heel lance. The study is a randomized controlled trial with 84 infants aged 28-42 weeks. The infants were exposed to white noise, heart sounds, or music for 10 minutes before, during, and 20 minutes after the procedure. The primary outcome measure is the Neonatal Infant Acute Pain Assessment Scale (NIAPAS) pain score, and the secondary outcome measure is the crying time. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This study aims to compare the effectiveness of two training and supervision processes for clinicians providing caregiver skills training (CST) to parents of children with developmental disabilities and/or autism. One group will receive remote training and supervision, while the other will receive face-to-face training and supervision. The primary outcome measure is change in caregiver skills and knowledge from baseline to week 12, as evaluated by the Caregivers Skills and Knowledge Measure. Secondary outcome measures include change in parenting stress, adaptive behavior, social communication abilities, and caregiver adherence and competence. The study will be conducted at three University of Pittsburgh Medical Center (UPMC) sites.

The study is a randomized clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of transcranial electrical stimulation (a-TES) in the functional recovery of patients with subacromial pain syndrome. The study will be conducted with a sample of 64 participants, randomly assigned to either an experimental group (receiving real a-TES) or a control group (receiving sham a-TES). The primary outcome measures will be changes in pain and disability index (SPADI), Western Ontario Rotator Cuff (WORC) scale, and shoulder pain pressure threshold (PPT) in kg. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in shoulder muscle strength, active range of motion, joint position sense, head forward posture, shoulder protraction, kyphosis, subacromial space width, scapulohumeral rhythm, and mean signal amplitude and frequency of the scapulothoracic muscles. The study will be conducted over a period of 8 weeks, with 24 sessions of therapeutic exercises and real or sham a-TES. The study will assess the short-term and long-term effects of a-TES on pain, functionality, and quality of life in patients with subacromial pain syndrome.

This study aims to compare the verbal scores of children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) who received hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) and those who did not receive HBOT. The study will use a retrospective design and will include children aged 2 to 17 years who were diagnosed with ASD and received applied behavioral analysis at the Oxford Recovery Center. The primary outcome measure will be the change in verbal scores at 6 months, measured using the Verbal Behavior Milestones Assessment and Placement Program (VBMAPP) and the Assessment of Basic Language and Learning Skills (ABLLS). The study will also collect data on the number of participants with hyperbaric oxygen treatment-related adverse events.

The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the analgesic efficacy of ultrasound-guided adductor canal block and 4-in-1 block in patients undergoing knee surgeries. The primary outcome measures are postoperative pain scores at 6, 12, 18, and 24 hours, and secondary outcome measures include change in blood pressure and heart rate, and postoperative opioid requirements. The study will enroll 60 patients, randomly assigned to receive either the adductor canal block or the 4-in-1 block. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This is a prospective randomized controlled trial to assess the effectiveness of immediate lymphatic reconstruction in reducing the risk of arm lymphedema in breast cancer patients after axillary lymph node dissection. The study will enroll 120 participants and will be conducted over a period of two years. The primary outcome measure will be the occurrence of arm lymphedema at two years, and secondary outcome measures will include drainage amount, seroma or lymphocele, patient-reported outcome measures, and subclinical lymphedema. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (immediate lymphatic reconstruction) or the control group (no intervention).

This study aims to assess the functional and aesthetic outcomes of patients with deep hand burns who underwent releasing incisions. The primary outcome measures include functional score, healing assessment, and scar quality. The study will be conducted at the Pierre Colson Burn Center and will enroll adult patients with acute hand burns that required skin grafts. The study will have one arm and will assess the effectiveness of the intervention in improving functional and aesthetic outcomes.

The PLANT study is a randomized, delayed intervention trial that aims to assess the effectiveness of a flexible, multimodal WFPBD educational program for providers at Stanford in any department. The program will include interactive didactic sessions, cooking classes, and weekly emails with suggested resources and activities including movies, recipes, and websites. The study will measure the change in diet ID score, mindset about WFPBD, and state of change (motivation/confidence) from baseline to week 6. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 weeks.

This study aims to validate a questionnaire to assess the rehabilitation needs of patients with early-stage breast cancer. The questionnaire, called the Patient Reported Outcome (PRO) questionnaire, will be translated and adapted for use in different cultures, and its validity will be evaluated in a sample of 280 patients. The study will assess the levels of agreement between the two assessments and the interclass correlation coefficient will be calculated for each item. The study will be conducted in two arms: the first arm will include 80 representative patients for transcultural adaptability, and the second arm will include all patients (at least 280) for validation. Patients with cognitive or memory impairment will be excluded from the study. The study will be conducted over a period of six months.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of the Connecting and Reflecting Experience (CARE) program in reducing postpartum anxiety and depression symptoms, improving parenting stress, and enhancing parental reflective functioning and attachment. The study is a single-group assignment, open-label design, and will include 12 sessions of CARE group therapy. Participants will be recruited from Montefiore Medical Center and will be eligible if they are experiencing moderate to high levels of depression and/or anxiety symptoms in the postpartum period. The primary outcome measures will include change from baseline to post-treatment in postpartum anxiety and depression scores, parenting stress, and parental reflective functioning. Secondary outcome measures will include change in infant temperament and post-treatment rating of treatment acceptability and feasibility. The study will be conducted over 15 weeks, with assessments at baseline, post-treatment, and 6-month follow-up.

The study aims to investigate the effects of electroencephalography-based neurofeedback (EEG-NFB) training on cognitive function in healthy young men. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled parallel-group design, with 50 participants in each of the two groups: the training (TR) group and the control (CO) group. The TR group will undergo 3 weeks of EEG-NFB training, while the CO group will not receive any training. The primary outcome measures will include the trail making test (TMT-A and TMT-B), Stroop test (ST-I and ST-II), and the attention index. The study will be conducted at the University School of Physical Education in Wroclaw, Poland, and will be approved by the ethics committee of the university.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness and safety of endovascular recanalization via radial approach and femoral approach in patients with acute basilar artery occlusion. The primary outcome measure is favorable neurological function at 90 days post-operation, and the secondary outcome measure is procedure time. The study is a randomized controlled trial with a parallel assignment and single-blind design. Patients with acute ischemic stroke in the posterior circulation confirmed by symptoms and imaging examinations, and basilar artery occlusion confirmed by CTA, MRA, or DSA within 24 hours of onset will be included in the study. The study will enroll 120 patients and is expected to be completed within 2 years.

The BUNDLE study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to improve healthcare engagement and trust among Black/AA pregnant individuals in Southeastern Wisconsin. The study will compare the effectiveness of an integrated prenatal care model that includes community doulas and clinical obstetric providers to standard prenatal care. The primary outcome measures will be perinatal healthcare engagement, trust in provider, reported discrimination, perceived stress, depression, cesarean birth, unplanned healthcare utilization, severe maternal morbidity, breastfeeding initiation, and group-based medical mistrust scale. The study will be conducted at Froedtert and the Medical College of Wisconsin Health System.

This is a Phase 1 open-label study to evaluate the safety and determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of IBRX-042 in subjects with HPV-associated tumors. The study will be conducted in up to 60 subjects who will be administered IBRX-042 by injection once every 3 weeks for a total of 3 injections. Subjects will receive study treatments until they report progressive disease (PD), unacceptable toxicity, withdraw consent, or if the Investigator feels it is no longer in their best interest to continue treatment. Subjects who progress, discontinue treatment, or complete the study will attend an end-of-treatment (EOT) visit 30 days after the last study assessment. Additionally, subjects will attend a follow-up visit 6 months following administration of the last dose of IBRX-042. After the subject completes or withdraws from the study, the study team will contact subjects approximately every 3 months for a minimum of 1 year post-administration of the first dose of study drug and then yearly until death to collect follow-up information, including survival status, collection of adverse events, and any current cancer treatment regimen. A clinic visit will be scheduled for 6 months after the last injection administered for collection of whole blood for exploratory immune and molecular profiling.

This is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effects of connective tissue massage and classical massage on pain, functional status, and quality of life in patients with chronic non-specific low back pain. The study will be conducted over a period of four weeks, with three sessions per week lasting 15-20 minutes each. The participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: the connective tissue massage group, the classical massage group, or the control group. The primary outcome measures will include the visual analog scale, the modified Schober test, the sit and reach test, the back pain functional scale, the Roland Morris disability questionnaire, and the short form-36 questionnaire. The study will be conducted at the Muğla Sıtkı Koçman University Physical Therapy and Rehabilitation Department.

This study is a randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment, multi-center study to compare the efficacy and safety of OMNI canaloplasty with cataract surgery versus OMNI canaloplasty and Hydrus microstent with cataract surgery in patients with mild to moderate open-angle glaucoma.

The primary outcome measure is the change in unmedicated intraocular pressure from baseline at 12 months. Secondary outcome measures include the reduction in the number of medications needed to control intraocular pressure from baseline and the percentage of patients with greater than 20% reduction in intraocular pressure from baseline at 12 months.

The study will enroll approximately 80 subjects aged 18 years and older who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria. Subjects will be randomly assigned to receive either OMNI canaloplasty or OMNI canaloplasty and Hydrus microstent in one eye each. The study will consist of preoperative and postoperative care, as well as follow-up visits at one month, six months, and one year after the surgery.

The study will be conducted at multiple sites in the United States and will be sponsored by a pharmaceutical company. The study is expected to take approximately one year to complete, and the results will be analyzed and published in a peer-reviewed medical journal.
This study will assess the efficacy and safety and tolerability of the study will be conducted at 12 weeks.

This study aims to assess the effectiveness of text message interventions in improving adherence to repeat colonoscopy in a Veterans Affairs (VA) hospital. Participants will be randomly assigned to either an experimental group receiving text message instructions and motivation or a control group with no intervention. The primary outcome measure will be the National Annie Colonoscopy Survey Score, which assesses participant satisfaction with the intervention. Secondary outcome measures will include the percentage of participants who attend their scheduled colonoscopy appointment and the percentage of participants who have adequate bowel preparation at the time of the procedure.

This is a prospective, multicenter, randomized, open-label, two-arms clinical trial comparing hysteroscopy versus endouterine aspiration for the management of trophoblastic retention after early miscarriage. The primary outcome measure is uterine vacuity, measured by endovaginal pelvic ultrasound at 6 weeks after surgery. Secondary outcome measures include complication rates, second-line surgical management, synechiae, and fertility at 6 weeks, 12 months, and 24 months after surgery. The study aims to compare the efficacy of hysteroscopy and aspiration in the management of trophoblastic retention after early miscarriage.

This study aims to investigate the use of online crowdsourcing to test multi-timescale inference strategies. Participants will be asked to complete a series of tasks that require them to make decisions based on the ratio of red to blue balls in two jars. The study will measure the accuracy of the participants' decisions and the time it takes them to make the decisions. The study will also test the effectiveness of different inference strategies and the impact of different levels of cognitive load on decision-making.

This is an N of 1 trial to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of lemborexant in treating insomnia in patients with early-onset dementia. The study will be conducted over 8 weeks, with the patient receiving alternating periods of lemborexant and placebo. The primary outcome measures will include total sleep time, sleep onset latency, wake time after sleep onset, number of night awakenings, and quality of sleep. Secondary outcome measures will include the presence and severity of adverse drug reactions and the willingness to drop out due to adverse events.

This is a prospective, double-blind, randomized, multicenter clinical trial to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy and safety of sinomenine versus glucocorticoid for early knee osteoarthritis. The study will be conducted in China and will enroll 240 participants who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either sinomenine or glucocorticoid intra-articular injections every 4 months for 24 months. The primary outcome measures will be the total WOMAC score and tibial cartilage volume at 24 months after the first injection. Secondary outcome measures will include The Timed Up and Go and 20m walking time at 24 months after the first injection. The study will be conducted to determine whether sinomenine is noninferior to glucocorticoid in reducing pain and improving function in patients with early knee osteoarthritis.

The study aims to determine the effect of breathing exercises applied with virtual reality glasses on dyspnea, anxiety and quality of life in COPD patients. The study is a single-blind pre-test post-test parallel group randomized controlled experimental design. The sample size of the study is 48 patients, 24 in the experimental and 24 in the control group. The primary outcome measures are oxygen saturation, respiratory rate, forced vital capacity (FVC), volume of air exhaled in 1 second of forced expiration (FEV1), peak expiratory flow rate (PEF), FEV1/FVC, COPD Evaluation Test (CAT), Modified Medical Research Council (mMRC) dyspnea scale, Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), St George Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) and Virtual Reality Experience Evaluation Form. The study will be conducted in Ardahan, Turkey.

The study aims to understand the multilevel determinants of cardiovascular health in Black women through a biobehavioral approach. The study will use a combination of lab-based assessments and free-living monitoring to evaluate vascular health, physical activity, and social/physical context. The study will enroll 100 Black women aged 18-49 years old who will be randomly assigned to an observational group. The primary outcome measures will include macrovascular function, arterial stiffness, blood flow measurements, and physical activity. The study will be conducted over 11 days, with lab-based assessments on day 1 and free-living monitoring for 10 days.

This study will evaluate the efficacy and safety of RCN3028 in treating moderate to severe vasomotor symptoms (VMS) associated with breast cancer. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either RCN3028 0.8 mg or placebo for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measures will be the mean change in frequency and severity of VMS from baseline to week 12. Secondary outcome measures will include the Menopause Specific Quality of Life Questionnaire, the 50%, 75%, and 100% responder rates, the time to onset of efficacy, Subject's and Physician's Global Assessment, and frequencies of treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs).

The study aims to investigate the association between higher doses of tranexamic acid and a lower incidence of post-operative delirium after cardiac surgery. The study is a retrospective cohort study and will include all patients undergoing elective or in-house urgent cardiac surgery at Royal Perth Hospital between May 2018 and August 2022. The primary outcome measure is the Richmond Agitation Sedation Score, and the secondary outcome measure is 30-day mortality. The study will use a drug: tranexamic acid, and the intervention will be administered according to the standard of care.

The study aims to compare the effects of myofascial decompression therapy and positional release therapy on pain, range of motion, and functional disability in patients with chronic non-specific neck pain. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with 20 participants in each group. The primary outcome measures will be the numerical rating scale (NPRS) and the neck disability index (NDI), both assessed at 6 weeks. Secondary outcome measures will include range of motion in the cervical spine (flexion, extension, side flexion, and rotation) also assessed at 6 weeks. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This is a randomized parallel-controlled study comparing the ileostomy dumpling suture method with traditional suture method in rectal anterior resection surgery with specimen extraction via stoma. The study aims to assess the complication rate of stoma, stoma DET score, stoma pain score, and quality of life scale score for patients with stoma. The study is open-label, randomized, and parallel-assigned, with 2 arms: experimental (dumpling suture method) and other (traditional suture method). The primary outcome measure is the complication rate of stoma, and the secondary outcome measures include stoma DET score, stoma pain score, and quality of life scale score. The study is expected to enroll 40 patients and will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This study aims to assess the progression of cognitive and associated activities of daily living impairment in Parkinson's disease. The study will use a detailed neuropsychological test battery to assess cognitive function and instrumental activities of daily living (IADL) function. The primary outcome measures will be the diagnosis of Parkinson's disease dementia (PDD) / Level II diagnosis of mild cognitive impairment in Parkinson's disease (PD-MCI) and the change in global cognition and IADL function over 6-8 years. Secondary outcome measures will include the change in cognitive domain performance and the follow-up score in global cognition. The study will include 182 patients with Parkinson's disease who participated in the first follow-up assessment.

This study aims to determine the median effective dose of rocuronium for the prevention of myofibrillation caused by the injection of succinylcholine. The study will be conducted on patients aged 18 to 80 years old, and will be randomized, open-label, and parallel-assignment. The primary outcome measure will be the appearance of myofibrillation, and will be measured at an average of 45 seconds after the injection of succinylcholine. The study will enroll 300 patients, and the sample size will be evenly divided into three age groups: 18 to 44 years old, 45 to 59 years old, and 60 to 80 years old. The initial dose of rocuronium for pre-injection will be set at 0.04mg/kg, and will be adjusted based on the patients' myofibrillation level.

This study aims to assess the presence of environmental pollutants in human carotid atherosclerotic plaques and their relationship with the plaque phenotype and clinical outcomes. The study will enroll 300 consecutive patients with asymptomatic carotid stenosis undergoing carotid endarterectomy. The presence of air pollutants (benzene, toluene, xylene, and ethylbenzene) or of microplastics within tissues from atherosclerotic plaques will be assessed by chromatographic analyses. The primary outcome measure will be the incidence of a composite of myocardial infarction, stroke, and all-cause mortality in patients with polluted vs non-polluted plaques. Secondary outcome measures will include the incidence of a composite of myocardial infarction, stroke, and all-cause mortality according to terciles of pollutants burden.

This study aims to investigate the effectiveness and safety of transarterial radioembolization (TARE) in patients with colorectal cancer liver metastases. The study will compare the mean effective tumor dose and safe healthy liver dose between patients with and without a response to radioembolization. Additionally, the study will investigate the dose-response and dose-toxicity relationships after TARE.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the clinical performance of chemically cured conventional glass ionomer restorations enhanced with light-emitting diode radiant heat. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with 18 healthy patients with 36 second molar teeth. The teeth will be randomly divided into two groups: the control group (M1) and the experimental group (M2). The restorations in the M1 group will be performed using chemically cured conventional GICs without any enhancement, while the restorations in the M2 group will be enhanced with radiant heat from an LED. The primary outcome measures will be the clinical performance of biological and functional properties of the restorations, evaluated using FDI criteria at 12 months.

This study aims to develop and validate an assisted digital telemonitoring platform for patients with postoperative atrial fibrillation (POAF). The telemonitored group used the SAMSUNGTM Galaxy Watch5 smartwatch for remote monitoring, while the control group followed standard care protocols. The primary outcome measures were rehospitalization rate, scheduled consultations, and extra occurrences. Secondary outcome measures included technological adherence, treatment adherence, and use of the mobile application by patients. The study was a randomized, parallel-assignment, single-masked trial conducted exclusively at the Heart Institute of the Clinics Hospital of the Medical School of the University of São Paulo (InCor - HCFMUSP).

This is a randomized controlled pilot study to assess the effectiveness and usability of two digital solutions (HSmartBPM and HyperHealth) in the management of hypertension. The study will be conducted on 120 patients with essential hypertension, who will be randomly assigned to one of the two digital solutions or to standard care. The primary outcome measures will be changes in blood pressure at 2 and 6 months, and the secondary outcome measure will be user satisfaction. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in Belgium.

The Liver Care Trial is a randomized controlled study that aims to assess the effectiveness of a diagnostic test, Transient Elastography, in identifying liver disease in individuals attending treatment for alcohol use disorder. The study will be conducted at two outpatient clinics in Denmark and will include participants aged 18-110 years who are attending treatment for alcohol use disorder. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, which will receive the diagnostic test, or the control group, which will receive standard screening. The primary outcome measure will be alcohol abstinence or light consumption the last 30 days, assessed six months after randomization. Secondary outcome measures will include heavy drinking days last 30 days and change in AUDIT-C score since randomization. The study will be conducted over a period of six months.

The study aims to assess the value of trio exome sequencing in the etiological assessment of specific non-syndromic language and learning disorders. The study will be conducted on 200 participants, aged 3 to 40 years, who will undergo blood sampling and genetic testing. The primary outcome measure will be the identification of a genetic cause defined by the presence of at least one ACMG class 4 or 5 variant. The study will be open-label and will include 20 families with positive results and 10 families with negative results. The study will be conducted over a period of 4 months.

The Five Days for Health (FDH) study is a single-group, open-label, single-center, randomized controlled trial that aims to assess the effectiveness of a 5-day small group-based lifestyle modification program on weight loss in overweight or obese adults. The program includes education on nutrition, physical activity, and psychological support, and is led by a multidisciplinary team of endocrinologists-diabetologists, nutritionists, psychologists, and kinesiologists. The primary outcome measure is weight loss after 12 months, and secondary outcome measures include body composition and metabolic parameters. The study is designed to evaluate the effectiveness of the FDH program in promoting weight loss and improving metabolic parameters in overweight and obese adults.

tersterstersters

The Effect of Different Music Listened During Retinopathy Examination to Premature Infants on Their Pain and Comfort Level: A Randomized Controlled Trial. The study aims to determine the effect of different music listened during retinopathy examination on pain and comfort level of premature babies. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with 3 arms: experiment 1 (rainstick), experiment 2 (The Happiest Baby), and control (routine care). The primary outcome measures will be PIPP pain profile and PBIC comfort score. The study will be conducted at a neonatal intensive care unit in a tertiary hospital.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase III clinical trial to assess the safety and efficacy of sovateltide in patients with acute cerebral ischemic stroke. The study will be conducted in the United States, Canada, United Kingdom, and Europe. The primary outcome measure will be the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score at day 90 post-randomization. Secondary outcome measures will include the proportion of patients with National Institute of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score < 6, mRS ≤ 2, Barthel Index (BI) score > 60 on day 6, day 30, and day 90 post-randomization, improvement in functional outcome as assessed by NIHSS, mRS, and BI scores at day 6, day 30, and day 90 post-randomization, and improvement in overall clinical outcome as assessed by the global statistical test of mRS, NIHSS, and BI scores at day 6, day 30, and day 90 post-randomization. The study will also assess the incidence of recurrent cerebral ischemic stroke within day 30 and day 90 post-randomization, incidence of mortality within 90 days post-randomization, incidence of radiographic or symptomatic Intra Cerebral Hemorrhage (ICH) within 24 (± 6) hours of randomization, and any adverse events (AEs) or serious adverse events (SAEs) associated with sovateltide.

This study aims to investigate the prognosis and influencing factors of borderline personality disorder (BPD) patients. The study is an ambispective cohort study, and the participants are BPD patients who meet the diagnostic criteria of ICD-10 (F60.3). The primary outcome measures are the remission rate of BPD, social disability, and quality of life. The study will follow up the patients every 6 months for 2 years to assess the outcomes. The study will use Cox Proportional Hazard Model and Generalized Estimating Equation Model to analyze the influencing factors of remission and the patients' social function and quality of life.

The study aims to assess the management of dry eye (DE) by combining intense pulsed light (IPL) and diquafosol eye drops. The study will be conducted as a randomized, triple-masked, parallel-group study. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: IPL+Diquafosol, IPL, or DQS. The primary outcome measures will be non-invasive tear break-up time (NIBUT), ocular surface disease index (OSDI), and fluorescein and lissamine conjunctival and cornea staining (CFS). Secondary outcome measures will include meibomian gland function and secretion quality, tear film lipid layer score (TFLL), tear meniscus height (TMH), and conjunctival hyperemia (RS score). The study will be conducted over 28 days, with follow-up visits at day 14 and day 28.

This study aims to compare the effectiveness of two different mental health interventions, Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT), in improving patient-centered mental health outcomes, quality of life, well-being, and functional impairment among autistic adults with co-occurring anxiety and/or depressive disorders. The study will also explore patient characteristics that may moderate the relationship between CBT or MBCT and patient outcomes. The study will be conducted over a period of 18 weeks, with assessments at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months. The primary outcome measures will include the Patient Health Questionnaire Anxiety-Depression Scale (PHQ-ADS) and the Outcome Rating Scale (ORS). Secondary outcome measures will include the Mini-International Neuropsychiatric Interview (MINI), the PROMIS Autism Battery - Lifespan (PAB-L), the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (RSE), the Sheehan Disability Scale (SDS), the World Health Organization Disability Assessment Schedule II (WHODAS II), and the Negative Effects Questionnaire (NEQ). The study will also collect information on potential negative effects of intervention, intervention services satisfaction, and intervention therapist and therapy satisfaction.

This study is a single-arm, open-label, Phase II clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of methotrexate in the treatment of immune-related arthritis or arthralgias (irAA) in patients with cancer who have developed these adverse events while receiving immune checkpoint inhibitors. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients who are able to discontinue prednisone by 12 weeks without recurrence of grade 2 or higher irAA. Secondary outcome measures include total steroid usage, development of immune-related adverse events other than irAA, adverse events, re-initiation of immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy, and progression-free survival.

This study aims to compare the effects of general and regional anesthesia on sleep quality in patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty. The study will evaluate the sleep quality of patients using the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) and the Pittsburgh Insomnia Rating Scale (PIRS-20) before surgery, on the day of surgery, and one week after surgery. Additionally, the study will evaluate the anxiety and pain levels of patients using the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) and the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) before surgery, on the day of surgery, and one week after surgery. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with patients randomly assigned to receive either general anesthesia or regional anesthesia. The primary outcome measure will be sleep quality, and the secondary outcome measures will be anxiety and pain levels. The study will be conducted in patients undergoing elective total hip arthroplasty, and the results will be analyzed to determine if there are any differences in sleep quality, anxiety, and pain levels between patients receiving general and regional anesthesia.

This is a Phase 2/3, multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group study to assess the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of oral atogepant for the prevention of migraine in Japanese participants with episodic migraine. Participants will be randomized to receive atogepant dose A, dose B, or dose C once daily (QD) for 24 weeks, or placebo QD for 12 weeks, followed by re-randomization to receive atogepant dose A, dose B, or dose C QD for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change from baseline in mean monthly migraine days. Secondary outcome measures include change from baseline in mean monthly headache days, mean monthly acute medication use days, percentage of participants achieving at least 50% reduction in the 3-month average of monthly migraine days, change from baseline in Migraine Specific Quality of Life Questionnaire, Version 2.1 (MSQ v2.1) Role Function-Restrictive domain score, change from baseline in mean monthly performance of daily activities domain score of the Activity Impairment in Migraine - Diary (AIM-D), and change from baseline in mean monthly physical impairment domain score of the AIM-D.

This is a randomized, double-blind, controlled, single-site clinical trial to evaluate the safety and efficacy of efgartigimod in patients with Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). The study will compare the efficacy of efgartigimod to intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) in patients with GBS. The primary outcome measure will be the Guillain-Barre Syndrome Disability Scale (GBS-DS) at 12 weeks. Secondary outcome measures will include the Neuropathy Impairment Scale (NIS), Inflammatory Rasch-Built Overall Disability Scale (I-RODS), Forced Vital Capacity (FVC), Maximal Inspiratory Pressure (MIP), and Maximal Expiratory Pressure (MEP) at 4, 24, and 48 weeks. The study will enroll approximately 40 patients and will be conducted at a single site.

This is a phase 2b, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, parallel group, dose-ranging study to evaluate the virological response and safety of oral PF-07817883 in non-hospitalized symptomatic adult participants with COVID-19. The study will be conducted in 3 parts: screening, treatment, and follow-up. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either PF-07817883 or placebo. The primary outcome measure will be the change from baseline in SARS-CoV-2 RNA level. Secondary outcome measures will include the incidence of treatment-related adverse events, serious adverse events, clinically significant abnormal laboratory values, and clinically significant abnormal vital signs. The study will enroll approximately 240 participants at multiple sites in the United States.

This clinical trial is studying the effectiveness of adding letrozole to the treatment of cesarean scar pregnancy. The study is a non-randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment trial. Participants will be assigned to one of two treatment groups: MTX monotherapy or MTX + letrozole add-on. The primary outcome measures will be blood loss during the procedure, blood loss volume during the procedure, and conversion rate from hysteroscopy to laparoscopy or laparotomy due to hemorrhage. Secondary outcome measures will include the effect of treatment on bone marrow function, liver function, and kidneys function. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The BLEED study is a feasibility pilot study that aims to assess the safety and efficacy of blood salvage from liver donors for intraoperative transfusion support during liver transplantation. The study will enroll adult patients (≥ 18 years) receiving a liver transplant from deceased donors at Fondazione Policlinico A. Gemelli IRCCS. The primary outcome measure is the number and percentage of LT recipients successfully transplanted with internal donors, who received donor RBC concentrates for the intraoperative transfusion support during liver transplant. The study will also assess the secondary outcome measures, including blood product need, rate of graft failure, and adverse events. The study is an open-label, single-group assignment design, and all participants will receive the intervention (blood salvage from liver donors).

This clinical trial aims to compare the efficacy of sublingual and subcutaneous allergen immunotherapy in patients with bronchial asthma. The study will be conducted on 50 patients who will receive either sublingual or subcutaneous immunotherapy for 18 months. The primary outcome measures will be the levels of total IgE and sputum eosinophil counts after 6, 12, and 18 months of treatment. The study will be randomized, open-label, and parallel-group design.

This study aims to determine the minimum amount of tissue needed for contrast-enhanced stereotactic biopsy (CESB) to establish a reliable diagnosis for "recombined-only lesions" (ROLs) observed during contrast-enhanced mammography (CEM). The study is a prospective, single-center, observational cohort study that will enroll non-pregnant women with ROLs recently observed during a regular CEM examination. Participants will undergo CESB, consisting of an intravenous injection of iodinated contrast agent prior to image acquisition, followed by a contrast-enhanced stereotactic localization of the ROL to determine the location and depth of the lesion within the breast. After targeting, 18 samples will be acquired using a 9 Gauge vacuum-assisted biopsy (VAB), collected in six separate and numbered cassettes, to be able to determine the chronological order of the tissue sampling. Each specimen will be histologically analyzed in this chronological order, and findings will be compared with the final histopathological result after assessment of all 18 specimens. The primary study aim is to calculate the cumulative diagnostic yield per specimen, enabling the definition of a minimum number of biopsies required (or tissue volume needed) to establish a reliable diagnosis using CESB. Secondary study outcomes will include general parameters of the biopsy procedure itself, such as patient characteristics, histopathological results, pain experienced during the procedure, and complication rates (hematoma, infection).

The study aims to compare the effects of concentric quadriceps strengthening and facilitatory kinesiotaping on gait parameters in patients with knee osteoarthritis. The study is a randomized controlled trial with 6 weeks of intervention. The primary outcome measures are temporospatial gait parameters, and the secondary outcome measures are numeric pain rating score, functional status, and strength. The study will be conducted on adults aged 50-60 years with knee osteoarthritis, and the participants will be randomly assigned to either the concentric quadriceps strengthening group or the facilitatory kinesiotaping group. The study will assess the effectiveness of both interventions in improving gait parameters and reducing pain and disability in patients with knee osteoarthritis.

The Family Therapy Training and Implementation Platform (FTTIP) Supplement Study aims to gather qualitative data from therapists and agency leaders to better understand their experiences with the platform and its implementation. The study will include 20 therapists and 16 agency leaders who will participate in qualitative interviews at two time points. The primary outcome measures include therapists' perceptions and experiences of learning and practicing specific CIFFTA competencies, and agency leaders' experiences in facilitating EBTs at their agencies. The study will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness and implementation of the FTTIP platform.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the analgesic effect of freshly manufactured 35kDa hyaluronan fragment HA35 injection on herpes zoster pain and shoulder, neck, back, and temporal pain. The study is an open-label, single-group assignment design, and all participants will receive the HA35 injection once a week for 3 hours. The primary outcome measure is the pain score, which will be evaluated using a pain scale. The study is being conducted at the Department of Pain Diagnosis and Treatment of the affiliated Hospital of Qingdao University.

This is a randomized clinical trial that aims to compare the effectiveness and safety of hysteroscopic septoplasty with scissors and resectoscope in the treatment of septate uterus. The study will be conducted on 20 patients in each group, and the primary outcome measures will be operative time, fluid deficit, operative and postoperative complications, and the need for second intervention. The secondary outcome measures will include pregnancy rate and live birth rate. The study will be conducted over a period of at least 24 months, and the results will be analyzed using the Statistical Package of Social Science (SPSS) program.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a respiratory training to cardiac coherence on the reduction in the symptomatology of patients with Long COVID. The study will be conducted at the Reunion University Hospital and will include patients over the age of 18, living in Reunion and having a diagnosis of Long COVID according to the World Health Organization (WHO) definition. The study will be randomized, parallel-assignment, and single-masked. The primary outcome measure will be the evaluation of the effectiveness of a respiratory training to cardiac coherence on the reduction in the symptomatology of patients with Long COVID, measured by the Long COVID Symptom Tool (ST) scale. Secondary outcome measures will include the evaluation of the effectiveness of a respiratory training to cardiac coherence on the decrease of overall symptoms over time, the decrease of specific symptoms such as fatigue, dyspnoea, anxiety and depression, cognitive disorders, and the impact of the disease on daily life.

This study aims to assess the cardiovascular complications of ibrutinib therapy in patients with hematological disorders. The study will evaluate the incidence of atrial fibrillation (AF) and other cardiovascular events in patients treated with ibrutinib. The study will also assess the predictive value of biomarkers for cardiovascular complications. The study is a single-center cohort study and will include patients aged 18 and over who are receiving ibrutinib therapy for hematological disorders. The study will follow patients for 12 months after the introduction of ibrutinib.

The study aims to assess the effect of bicarbonate profiling in dialysis fluid on phosphate removal during hemodialysis and blood pH. The study will be conducted on 20 chronic hemodialysis patients, who will be assigned to one of three groups: Group 1: B) Dbic 35 -30 mmol/L C) Dbic 30- 35 mmol/L, Group 2: C) Dbic 30- 35 mmol/L B) Dbic 35 -30 mmol/L, and Group 3: A) constant Dbic 35 mmol/L. The primary outcome measure will be the blood phosphorus concentration change in hemodialysis patients, and the secondary outcome measure will be the maintaining of acid-base balance in accordance with applicable recommendations. The study will be conducted for 4 weeks, and arterial blood samples will be obtained predialysis and every hour during the treatment.

The study aims to evaluate the potential superiority of the approach of combined administration of tDCS and MCT, compared with interventions based tDCS alone or MCT alone, in the treatment of unipolar depression. The study will be conducted as a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group trial, with three arms of treatment, each consisting of 8 sessions, involving the administration of 1) the neurostimulation intervention (tDCS), 2) of the psychotherapeutic intervention alone (MCT), 3) of both techniques in consecution (tDCS-MCT). The primary outcome measure will be the change in the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale during follow-up (end of treatment, 1, 3, 6 and 12 months). The study will also evaluate the TMS-EEG correlates of change in depressive symptomatology, correlating them with the different proposed therapeutic interventions, in a subgroup of patients recruited, in the context of a pilot study.

This study aims to determine the efficacy and safety of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) who are undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and are at moderate risk of gastrointestinal bleeding. The study is a randomized, open-label, controlled trial that will enroll 120 patients and will be conducted at a single center in South Korea. The primary outcome measure will be the occurrence of upper gastrointestinal clinical complex events, including upper gastrointestinal bleeding with clear origin, upper gastrointestinal bleeding with unclear origin, and potential upper gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation, at 6 months after randomization. Secondary outcome measures will include the occurrence of cardiovascular clinical complex events, such as combined variables of cardiovascular death, non-fatal myocardial infarction, coronary artery reopening, or ischemic stroke, also at 6 months after randomization. The study will use a parallel-group design, with patients randomly assigned to receive either PPI treatment (lansoprazole 15 mg once daily for 6 months) or no intervention. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months, and data will be collected during normal medical procedures and checked through endoscopy in case of upper gastrointestinal bleeding.

The study aims to investigate the influence of hot and cold cognition on prospective memory in HIV+ patients and healthy subjects. The study will use neuropsychological testing to assess prospective memory, global cognitive performance, hot cognition, and cold cognition. The primary outcome measure will be prospective memory, and secondary outcome measures will include the influence of global cognitive performance, hot cognition, and cold cognition on prospective memory. The study will enroll HIV+ patients and healthy controls, and the results will be analyzed to determine the impact of HIV infection on prospective memory and the relationship between cognitive factors and prospective memory.

The study aims to determine the effects of vertical sitting versus supine lying traction on pain, range of motion, and function in patients with chronic radicular low back pain. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial with 2 groups: an experimental group receiving vertical sitting traction and an active comparator group receiving supine lying traction. The primary outcome measures will be the Oswestry Disability Index and Numeric Pain Rating Scale, assessed at 12 weeks. The study will enroll patients with chronic radicular low back pain for at least 3 months, and exclude pregnant females, patients with a history of spinal trauma, and those with systemic diseases.

This is a randomized clinical trial to evaluate the effectiveness of dry needling and laser therapy in the treatment of lateral hip pain. The study will be conducted with 30 participants, randomly divided into two groups: dry needling and laser therapy. The primary outcome measures will be pain intensity and hip function, assessed through the Visual Analog Pain Scale (VAS) and the VISA-G questionnaire, respectively. Secondary outcome measures will include lower limb function, assessed through the Timed Up and Go Test (TUG) and the 30-second Sit to Stand Test. The study will be conducted over a period of six weeks, with two sessions per week. The participants will be evaluated before treatment, immediately after treatment, and 12 weeks after treatment. The study will be double-blinded, with the participants and the researchers unaware of the group to which the participants are assigned. The results of the study will be analyzed using the Shapiro-Wilk test, Student's t-test, two-way ANOVA test, and Cohen's D test.

The study aims to assess the diagnostic accuracy of a rapid technique for the detection of intestinal anti-transglutaminase antibodies in patients with suspected celiac disease. The study will compare the sensitivity and specificity of the rapid test with the reference standard (serology and histopathology) and evaluate the concordance of the rapid test with culture-EMA results. The study will include patients undergoing elective esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) for suspected CD, eosinophilic esophagitis, autoimmune enteropathy, inflammatory bowel disease, gastritis, gastric or duodenal ulcer, and gastroesophageal reflux disease.

This study aims to investigate the effects of cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia in nurses with post COVID-19 condition. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with 6 weeks of cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia provided to the experimental group, and usual care provided to the control group. The primary outcome measures will be insomnia severity, sleep quality, and sleep efficiency, and will be measured at baseline, 1, 2, and 3 months after the end of the intervention. Secondary outcome measures will include anxiety, depression, and health-related quality of life. The study will enroll nurses with post COVID-19 condition who are aged between 20 and 65 years, and will be conducted in a hospital setting.

This is a pilot study to evaluate the acceptability of a web-based patient decision aid for stroke prevention in patients with recent onset atrial fibrillation. The decision aid is designed to facilitate shared decision-making between patients and their physicians for atrial fibrillation stroke prevention treatments. The study will assess the effectiveness of the decision aid in improving the process of shared decision-making, and will also evaluate the acceptability of the decision aid among patients and clinicians. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with participants randomly assigned to receive either the decision aid or standard care. The primary outcome measure will be the 9-Item Shared Decision Making Questionnaire (SDM-Q-9: patient version), which will be administered immediately after the clinic visit.

NNC0491-6075 is a new medicine being developed to treat dyslipidaemia. This study aims to assess the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of NNC0491-6075 in healthy participants and participants with dyslipidaemia. The study will be conducted in three parts: Part A (single ascending dose), Part B (multiple ascending dose), and Part C (single ascending dose in healthy Japanese participants). Participants will receive either NNC0491-6075 or placebo, and their safety and tolerability will be monitored throughout the study. The study will also measure the concentration of NNC0491-6075 in the blood over time and assess its effectiveness in reducing triglycerides and increasing HDL-C.

This clinical trial aims to compare the efficiency of high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) and non-invasive ventilation (NIV) in treating acute moderate hypercapnic respiratory failure (type 2 RF) in adult patients. The study will be conducted in the intensive care unit (ICU) and will include 100 patients, randomly divided into two groups: HFNC and NIV. The primary outcome measure will be the failure of treatment modality, measured at one hour, and the secondary outcome measures will include mortality and ICU stay, measured at 28 days. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of a digital health intervention (Medly Uganda) in improving self-care and clinical outcomes in patients with heart failure in Uganda. The study will be conducted in three phases: a 1-2 month run-in period, a 3-year intervention period, and a 6-month follow-up period. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either the digital health intervention or enhanced HF clinical care. The primary outcome measures will be change in self-care of heart failure index (SCHFI) and clinical effectiveness, assessed through a composite of mortality and HF hospitalization. Secondary outcome measures will include participant fidelity to self-care, facility fidelity to implementation strategy, and changes in blood pressure, weight, resting pulse, and 6-minute walk test. The study will also assess the change in Pro-NT BNP, left ventricular ejection fraction, Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire (KCCQ), and EuroQol-5D (EQ-5D) and Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9).

This is an open-label, balanced, randomized, single-dose, two-treatment, two-sequence, two-period, two-way crossover study to compare the bioavailability of ibuprofen and diphenhydramine hydrochloride modified-release tablets (400mg/50mg of Overseas Pharmaceuticals, Ltd.) with reference 1 (R1): ibuprofen tablets (Motrin IB®) and reference 2 (R2): diphenhydramine hydrochloride tablets (Benadryl®). The study will be conducted in healthy adult subjects under fasting conditions. The primary outcome measures will be the area under the curve from time zero to the time of the last quantifiable plasma concentration of the period (AUC0-last) and the area under the curve from time zero to infinity (AUC0-inf). The secondary outcome measures will include peak concentration of the first dosing (Cmax), time to reach peak concentration of the first dosing (Tmax), terminal half-life (T1/2), and mean residence time (MRT).

The study aims to assess the impact of apalutamide in metastatic hormone-sensitive prostate cancer patients. The primary outcome measure is the undetectable PSA rate at the end of year 1 and year 2. Secondary outcome measures include the impact of apalutamide on fatigue, cognitive function, and health-related quality of life. The study is a multicentre, prospective, observational study.

This study will evaluate the effectiveness of Duobrii lotion in treating scalp psoriasis. The study will be conducted as an open-label, single-arm study. Subjects will apply the lotion once daily to the affected scalp area for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measures will be hair growth and scalp itch.

This study aims to compare the effectiveness of radial and capitate shortening in the treatment of ulna minus variance Kienbock's disease. The study will be conducted as a randomized parallel-group trial, with 20 participants in each arm. The primary outcome measure will be the modified Mayo wrist score, assessed at 1 year. The study will be conducted at a single center, and participants will be randomly assigned to either the radial or capitate shortening group. The study is expected to take 1 year to complete.

The Effectiveness of Dual Task Exercise Training on Balance, Mobility, Physical Performance and Quality of Life in Children With Cerebral Palsy.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to assess the effectiveness of dual task exercise training in improving balance, mobility, physical performance, and quality of life in children with cerebral palsy. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 weeks, and the participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group will receive dual task exercise training, while the control group will receive conventional rehabilitation. The primary outcome measures will include the Pediatric Balance Scale, Timed Up and Go Test, One Leg Standing Test, 3-Meter Backward Walk Test, 6 Meter Walk Test, and the Generic Children's Health-Related Quality of Life Questionnaire. The study will be conducted in a rehabilitation center, and the participants will be evaluated before and 12 weeks after the interventions.

The study aims to detect and characterize non-seasonal influenza viruses in Belgium by conducting active surveillance among sentinel participants from different targeted groups (avian influenza outbreak farms, poultry farm sentinel network, wild bird/life rehabilitation centre sentinel network, and pig industry veterinarian sentinel network) and outbreak participants. The study will measure the number of sentinel participants and outbreak participants positive for a non-seasonal influenza virus, as well as the number of outbreak participants with seroconversion against a non-seasonal influenza virus. The study will use diagnostic tests such as RT-qPCR and seroneutralization assay to detect and characterize non-influenza viruses.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a 6-week canine-assisted therapy program in improving emotional regulation, behavioral disorders, and self-esteem in youth residing in a residential treatment center. The study will use a longitudinal, within-person design with two parallel conditions: an experimental group receiving the canine-assisted therapy intervention and a control group receiving treatment as usual. The primary outcome measures will include the Emotional Stroop task, Flanker task, Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale, and Negative Affect. The study will also collect attendance and attrition data, as well as secondary outcome measures such as change in positive affect, significant event report, and attitudes towards pets.

This study aims to investigate the effect of myofascial release in addition to foot core exercises on lower extremity performance in young adults with asymptomatic flexible pes planus. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled parallel-group study with two groups: the experimental group, which will receive myofascial release in addition to foot core exercises, and the control group, which will only receive foot core exercises. The primary outcome measures will be balance, flexibility, power, and gait. The study will be conducted with 20 participants in each group, and the data will be analyzed using a mixed-effects model.

The study aims to investigate whether training of the arms can reduce pain when inserting a peripheral venous catheter in patients undergoing cytostatic treatment. The study will also examine the experience of challenges with vein status for patients in cytostatic treatment. The study is a randomized controlled trial with an 8-week daily arm training program for the experimental group, and normal care for the control group. The primary outcome measures are pain level and vein status, measured at baseline, after five weeks of training/control, and after eight weeks of training/control.

This study aims to determine whether decidual leukocyte subpopulations and their associated activation markers were different between women having miscarriage of either a trisomy 16 conceptus (47XY+16 or 47XX+16) compared with a chromosomally normal male conceptus (46XY) and compared with gestationally age-matched decidual tissues. Samples from presumably normal female conceptuses (46XX) were not chosen for study because of the inability to accurately differentiate from possible maternal cell contamination. For managing with miscarriage or termination of pregnancy (TOP) in first trimester loss, ultrasound-guided manual vacuum aspiration (USG-MVA) is one of the treatment options. USG-MVA for the treatment of early pregnancy loss has been used for many decades. It had been reported that USG-MVA is safer, more cost-effective, and is associated with shorter hospitalization time and cost than surgical evacuation under general anesthesia.

This is an open-label, single-group assignment, exploratory trial to investigate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamic properties of Lu AF28996 in Japanese men and women with Parkinson's disease. The study will be conducted in two parts: a 14-day dose escalation period, followed by a 21-day dosing period. Participants will receive ascending oral doses of Lu AF28996 for 14 days, and then initiate down-titration of the drug as per the investigator's judgment. The primary outcome measures will be the number of participants with treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs), the area under the plasma concentration-time curve (AUC0-tlast and AUC0-24h) of Lu AF28996, the maximum observed plasma concentration (Cmax) of Lu AF28996, and the oral clearance (CL/F) of Lu AF28996.
