The SUSPECT Italian Prospective Study is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the technical performance and procedural outcomes of single-use duodenoscopes in patients undergoing endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) or other duodenoscope-based procedures. The study will enroll 200 participants at 10 sites in Italy and will assess the technical performance and procedural outcomes of the single-use duodenoscopes over a period of 24 months. The primary outcome measures will include technical performance and procedural performance.

============
The study aims to assess the feasibility of a hybrid pulmonary rehabilitation intervention for patients with chronic obstructive lung disease. The study will compare the effectiveness of the hybrid intervention with standard pulmonary rehabilitation. The study will also assess the safety and acceptability of the hybrid intervention.


Please provide a clear and concise summary of the study, including the following:



1. A clear and concise summary of the study, including the following:

This is an observational study that aims to describe the demographics and clinical characteristics of patients who received EVUSHELD as pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) against COVID-19 in Japan. The study will use secondary data from a database of patients who have received EVUSHELD for PrEP. The study will describe the baseline demographics and clinical characteristics of patients who received EVUSHELD for PrEP, and will also assess the effectiveness of EVUSHELD in preventing medically attended COVID-19, COVID-19 hospitalization, and in-hospital mortality due to COVID-19. The study will follow patients for up to 180 days after the index date.

This is a Phase 4 multicenter, randomized, double-blind study to assess the safety and efficacy of risankizumab for the treatment of adult subjects with moderate to severe genital psoriasis or moderate to severe scalp psoriasis. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either risankizumab or placebo for 52 weeks. The primary outcome measures will be the percentage of participants with achievement of static Physician Global Assessment of Genitalia (sPGA-G) of 0 or 1 at Week 16 and the percentage of participants with achievement of Scalp Investigator Global Assessment (IGA) of 0 or 1 at Week 16. Secondary outcome measures will include the percentage of participants with achievement of clinically meaningful improvement from baseline on the Genital Psoriasis Itch Numerical Rating Scale (NRS) and the Psoriasis Scalp Severity Index (PSSI).

The study aims to determine the prevalence of the Linburg-Comstock variation in patients with symptomatic thumb CMC arthritis. The study will be conducted as a descriptive cross-sectional study, with a single group of patients who will undergo a clinical examination to determine the presence or absence of the variation. The study will be conducted at multiple sites in New York over a period of two years, and will include 500 patients. The primary outcome measure will be the presence or absence of the LCV, as determined by clinical examination.

This is a Phase 3, multicenter, 12-week, double-blind, placebo-controlled study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of atogepant for the preventive treatment of episodic migraine in pediatric subjects 6-17 years of age. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either atogepant or placebo-matching atogepant once daily for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measures will be the change from baseline in mean monthly migraine days and mean monthly headache days. Secondary outcome measures will include the percentage of participants who achieve at least a 50% reduction in average of monthly migraine days, change from baseline in the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) total score, and change from baseline in the Pediatric Migraine Disability Assessment (PedMIDAS) total score.

This clinical trial aims to assess the effects of a two-week home-based training program with a tablet on the motor skills of patients with Parkinson's disease. The training program includes a swipe slide pattern task in both single-task (ST) and dual-task (DT) conditions. The primary outcome measures are the average slide duration and performance accuracy, which will be recorded at baseline, post-training (two weeks), and retention (four weeks). Secondary outcome measures include consolidation effects of two weeks of training, transfer towards an untrained task, and retention effects on average slide duration after four weeks follow-up. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial with an experimental group receiving the training program and a control group receiving no intervention. The study will assess the effectiveness of the training program in improving motor skills and cognitive function in patients with Parkinson's disease.

The study aims to investigate the effect of intensified tactile contact between a mother and a newborn on the emotional transformation of women after physiological delivery. The study is a non-randomized, quasi-experimental design with an experimental and control group. The experimental group received an intervention in the form of intensified tactile contact of a mother with the newborn, while the control group received no intervention. The study measures the change in postpartum depression, anxiety, positive and negative affects, and parental competence using standardized, self-reported questionnaires. The study is conducted in a local childbirth school, and all participants are thoroughly prepared for delivery and supervised by medical doctors, psychologists, physiotherapists, and nurses. The study is designed to determine if the direction of the mother's emotional transformation differs between the experimental and control groups after 12 weeks of observation.
tersterstersterstersterstersters

This is a pilot prospective cohort study that aims to assess the feasibility and effectiveness of osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) in the management of persistent post-COVID-19 symptoms. The study will enroll participants who have experienced at least one symptom of post-COVID-19 for at least 4 weeks after diagnosis and have not responded to previous treatments. Participants will receive OMT at the discretion of the treating physician based on their response to previous treatments. The study will measure the patient recruitment rate, data completion rate, neurocognitive and psychological symptoms, physical symptoms, global health, and return to work. The study will assess the feasibility and effectiveness of OMT in managing persistent post-COVID-19 symptoms.

This study aims to compare the effectiveness of ICG microangiography and conventional angiography in diagnosing severe frostbite. The primary outcome measure is the assessment of ischemic tissue present in severe frostbite, scored by the Hennepin Frostbite Score. The study will also evaluate the safety of indocyanine green when delivered in close association with contrast dye used in conventional angiography. The study is a pilot study and will enroll 20 patients.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to assess the impact of a multidisciplinary approach in the perioperative geriatrics unit on the functional status of patients aged 70 and over operated on for colorectal cancer. The study will be conducted at the University Hospital of Nîmes and will include 120 patients. The patients will be randomly assigned to either the control group, which will receive classical management in the digestive surgery department, or the GPOU group, which will receive treatment in the perioperative geriatrics unit. The primary outcome measure will be the change in functional status after colorectal cancer surgery between groups, as measured by the Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (IADL) score. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in basic functional status, patient motor ability, patient satisfaction with care, length of hospital stay, the number of medical complications during hospitalization, the distribution of surgical complications, and overall survival. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months, with follow-up assessments at baseline, month 3, and month 6.

This study is a pilot trial that will evaluate the safety and efficacy of 64Cu-DOTA-pembrolizumab (64CDP) in patients receiving stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) for oligo-progressive solid tumors. The primary objectives of the study are to describe the toxicities of 64CDP positron emission tomography (PET) and to identify changes in 64CDP uptake in radiated metastatic lesions pre- and post-SBRT.

The study will enroll approximately 10 patients with metastatic solid tumors who are currently being treated with single-agent pembrolizumab and have been referred for SBRT. Patients will receive standard of care pembrolizumab intravenously (IV) at baseline and then receive 64CDP IV on days 1 and 29 of the study. Patients will undergo PET scans on days 2 and 30 of the study. In addition, patients will receive standard of care SBRT from days 8-18 of the study.

The study will assess the safety and efficacy of 64CDP in patients receiving SBRT for oligo-progressive solid tumors. The primary outcome measures will include the incidence of dose-limiting toxicities (DLT), changes in 64CDP uptake in radiated metastatic lesions pre- and post-SBRT, and changes in standard uptake value (SUV-max).

The study will be conducted as an open-label, single-group assignment trial. All patients will receive 64CDP and standard of care SBRT. The study will be conducted at a single institution, and the estimated completion date is December 2023.

This is a follow-up study to describe the safety of study participants who received RSVPreF3 maternal vaccination (any dose) or controls from previous RSV MAT studies during any pregnancy conceived post-vaccination/control. The study will be conducted in two parts: a retrospective cohort and a prospective cohort. The retrospective cohort will include adult/adolescent participants from any of the prior RSV MAT studies who have either received RSV MAT vaccine or control (placebo, Tdap or influenza vaccine) and have either reached 2 years+2 months post-delivery of the first pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination or have not reached 2 years+2 months post-delivery of the first pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination but are pregnant at enrollment. The prospective cohort will include adult/adolescent participants from any of the prior RSV MAT studies who have either received RSV MAT vaccine or control (placebo, Tdap or influenza vaccine) and have not reached 2 years post-vaccination/control prior to enrollment or have reached at least 2 years post-vaccination/control but have an ongoing pregnancy (prior to Day 42 post-delivery) at enrollment. The primary outcome measures will include the percentage of maternal participants reporting pregnancy outcomes from Day 1 up to Day 42 post-delivery of the first pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination, the percentage of maternal participants reporting pregnancy related AESIs from Day 1 up to Day 42 post-delivery of the first pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination, and the percentage of infant participants reporting infant AESIs from birth up to Day 42 post-birth of the first pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination. The study will be conducted at multiple sites in the United States, Canada, and Europe.

This is a clinical trial studying the use of 19F MRI in healthy children and children with mild cystic fibrosis lung disease. The study will assess the acceptability and feasibility of the imaging technique, as well as measure ventilation defect parameters and fraction of lung volume with slow gas washout time. The study will enroll 20 healthy children and 20 children with cystic fibrosis, aged 6-17 years old. Participants will receive inhaled perfluoropropane during MRI procedures, and the study will be conducted at a single center over a period of 2 years.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effects of open and closed chain exercises on pain, function, and balance in athletes with patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS). The study will be conducted in Pakistan and will include 30 participants who will be randomly assigned to either an open chain exercise group or a closed chain exercise group. The exercises will be performed for 6 weeks, and the participants' pain, function, and balance will be assessed using numerical pain rating scale (NPRS), lower extremity functional scale (LEFS), and Y balance test, respectively. The study will be conducted to determine which type of exercise is more effective in treating PFPS.

The MIND diet is a dietary intervention that aims to reduce the risk of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's, ALS, and Parkinson's. The study will evaluate the effects of the MIND diet on oxidative stress, inflammation, and neurodegenerative risk biomarkers in American football players. The study will be a randomized controlled trial with 30 participants, and the intervention will be the MIND diet. The primary outcome measures will be tau protein, NfL, S100B protein, BDNF, telomere, zonulin, NOX2, 8-OHdG, F2-isoPs, hs-CRP, IL-6, and TNF-α. The study will assess the effects of the MIND diet on oxidative stress, inflammation, and neurodegenerative risk biomarkers in American football players.

The study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of left bundle branch area pacing in heart failure patients with ejection fraction below normal. The study will enroll 100 patients and will be conducted at a single center. The primary outcome measure will be the acute success rate of left bundle branch area pacing, and the secondary outcome measures will include the incidence of acute procedure-related complications, repeat procedures, pacemaker upgrade to cardiac resynchronization therapy, heart failure hospitalization, cardiovascular death, all-cause death, left ventricular ejection fraction, left ventricular end diastolic diameter, left ventricular end systolic diameter, left ventricular global strain, capture threshold, sensing, and impedance. The study will be conducted over a period of one year.

This is a Phase 1a, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, single site, single ascending dose study of the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of CSX-1004 injection in healthy adults. The study will evaluate the safety and tolerability of CSX-1004 and assess its pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and immunogenicity in healthy adults. The study will be conducted in two parts: a screening phase and a treatment phase. The screening phase will include a physical examination, medical history, and laboratory tests to determine eligibility for the study. Subjects who are eligible and provide informed consent will be randomly assigned to receive either CSX-1004 or placebo. The treatment phase will consist of a single dose of CSX-1004 or placebo administered as an intravenous infusion. Subjects will be monitored for adverse events, and blood samples will be collected for pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic analysis. The study will enroll approximately 48 healthy adults, with 12 subjects per cohort.

This study aims to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of joint fluid aspiration (JFA) in patients with dysfunctional hip, knee or shoulder prostheses, suspected of chronic infection or implant failure. The study will be conducted as an open-label, single-group assignment, prospective cohort study. All included patients reporting prosthesis complications will undergo JFA, and the bacteriological concordance between JFA and perioperative samples will be analyzed. The primary outcome measure will be the number of patients whose JFA is concordant with that of the perioperative samples.

This study aims to assess the effectiveness of 19F MRI in quantitating and spatially registering airway dysfunction in cystic fibrosis (CF) patients. The primary outcome measures are changes in ventilation defect parameter (VDP) and functional lung volume (FLVlongtau2) over 14 and 365 days. Secondary outcome measures include changes in MRI severity score over 365 days and the correlation of MRI severity score with VDP and FLVlongtau2 at baseline. The study will enroll 18 subjects and will be conducted at a single center.

This study is a randomized, open, two-sequence, two-cycle, double-cross design bioequivalence trial of fasting single oral STI-1558 capsule in healthy Chinese subjects. The study will evaluate the relative bioavailability of STI-1558 under fasting conditions.

The study will enroll 32 subjects and will be conducted in two sequences: sequence 1 (S1) and sequence 2 (S2). Each subject will receive two doses of STI-1558, one on day 1 (D1) and the other on day 8 (D8), in a randomized, open-label manner. The doses will be administered under fasting conditions, and the subjects will be required to fast for at least 7 days between doses.

The primary outcome measures will be the comparison of maximum observed concentration (Cmax) profiles of the two different kinds of oral STI-1558, and the comparison of area under the curve (AUC) from time 0 to last time point (AUC0-t) and from time 0 extrapolated to infinity (AUC0-inf) profiles of the two different kinds of oral STI-1558.

The study will also evaluate the secondary outcome measures, including the comparison of Tmax, t1/2, λz, and %AUCex of the two different kinds of oral STI-1558.

The study will be conducted at a single clinical research center, and the subjects will be randomly assigned to either the test preparation (T) or the reference preparation (R) in a 1:1 ratio. The study will be double-blinded, with both the subjects and the investigators unaware of the sequence of the doses.

The study will be conducted over a period of 14 days, with the subjects being admitted to the clinical research center on day 1 (D1) and discharged on day 14 (D14). The subjects will be required to fast for at least 7 days between doses, and to abstain from any medication or alcohol during the study period.

The study will be monitored by an independent data monitoring committee (IDMC), which will review the study data on a

This is a randomized controlled trial to assess the effectiveness of detaching the breathing circuit on the rate of double-lumen endotracheal tube malposition after positional changes in patients undergoing thoracic surgery. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, where the breathing circuit will be disengaged when the patient transitions from the supine to the lateral position, or the control group, where the breathing circuit will be maintained. The primary outcome measure is the malposition rate of the double-lumen endobronchial tube. Secondary outcome measures include the effects of lung collapse, blood oxygen saturation, and PACU length of stay.

This study aims to assess the effectiveness of personalized comprehensive diabetes support for families of children with newly diagnosed type 1 diabetes. Participants will be randomly assigned to either an intervention group receiving personalized comprehensive diabetes support for 6 months or a control group receiving standard care. The primary outcome measures will be diabetes distress and problem areas in diabetes, assessed at 24 months.

This study aims to improve the accuracy of diagnosing soft tissue sarcomas using artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms. The researchers will use quantitative MRI scans to collect additional information about the lumps in soft tissue. The study will involve patients who are already having an MRI scan for suspected sarcoma. The researchers will use the extra information from the quantitative MRI scans to train the AI algorithms to differentiate between benign and malignant soft tissue masses. The study will also test the reproducibility of the AI algorithms. The researchers will ask a small subset of patients to come back for a second MRI scan to help measure the reliability of the measurements. The study will measure the accuracy of the AI algorithms in distinguishing between benign and malignant soft tissue lesions and classifying malignant lesions into their pathological grade.

This is a split-mouth randomized controlled clinical trial to compare the effectiveness of microneedling alone and along with hyaluronic acid in increasing gingival thickness in thin gingival phenotype. The study will be conducted in the department of periodontics and oral implantology, Post Graduate Institute of Dental Sciences, Rohtak. The study will be of 24 months duration and will include 20 healthy patients with thin periodontal phenotypes. The patients will be randomly allocated to one of the two procedures (microneedling alone or microneedling along with hyaluronic acid) using a chit system. The primary outcome measure will be the measurement of gingival thickness at baseline, 1 month, 6 months, and 9 months.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to assess the effects of preoperative immunonutrition on patients undergoing elective colorectal surgery for neoplasm. The primary outcome measures are surgical site infection (SSI) and anastomotic leakage (AL), while secondary outcomes include length of stay (LOS), inflammatory infiltration in the subcutaneous adipose tissue (SAT) and visceral adipose tissue (VAT), and grade of fibrosis in the subcutaneous adipose tissue (SAT) and visceral adipose tissue (VAT). The study will enroll 120 patients and will be conducted at a single center.

The study aims to investigate the impact and possible additional benefits of adding an oculomotor treatment to a manual therapy protocol of the cervical region in patients with migraine. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with 6 weeks of treatment and follow-up at 3 months. The primary outcome measures will be changes in the impact of headaches, pain, disability, depression, anxiety, sleep quality, kinesiophobia, catastrophizing, central sensitization, neck disability, head repositioning, strength of deep cervical flexors, ocular movement, ocular movement with variation of the head, range of movement, and quality of life.

The CRATOS study is an open-label, single-arm clinical trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the Cratos™ Branch Stent Graft System in the treatment of descending aorta lesions. The study will enroll patients with aortic dissection type B, intramural hematoma, and penetrating aortic ulcer. The primary outcome measure will be all-cause mortality at 30 days. The study will be conducted at multiple sites in the United States and will include both men and women aged 18 years or older.

This study aims to compare the quality of images, depth of the lumbar plexus, and the presence of vessels obtained with the Trident and Shamrock techniques for ultrasound-guided lumbar plexus block. The study will include adults with indication of lumbar echography and will be conducted in a single center. The primary outcome measure will be the projection of line C on the costiform processes, and secondary outcome measures will include depth of lumbar plexus, image quality, and presence of vessels. The study will be designed as a comparative study.

This study aims to investigate the efficacy of standardized pre-operative pelvic floor physical therapy (PFPT) in reducing stress urinary incontinence (SUI) and improving patient quality of life (QoL) following Holmium Laser Enucleation of the Prostate (HoLEP). The study will be a prospective, randomized, open-label, parallel-group trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a pre-operative PFPT group or a post-operative PFPT group. The primary outcome measure will be time to continence, and secondary outcome measures will include uroflow, post void residual, international prostate symptom score, operative time, length of stay, catheter duration, infectious complications, and emergency room visits. The study will enroll 100 participants and will be conducted at a single center.

DETECT-IP is a randomized controlled trial that aims to reduce the incidence of acute renal failure and/or hyperkaliemia adverse drug events in older hospitalized patients. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of a clinical decision support system (CDSS) in reducing the incidence of these adverse events. The CDSS will provide alerts to pharmacists and physicians based on routine care, and the pharmacists will provide pharmaceutical interventions to the medical team. The study will measure the number of adverse drug events, therapeutic adaptations implemented in case of acute renal failure or hyperkaliemia, relevance of CDSS alerts, and cost-effectiveness of the pharmaceutical intervention. The study will be conducted in hospitals in France and will include patients aged 65 years or older who are hospitalized for at least three days.

The study aims to investigate the presence of mesenteric bacterial translocation in evolved Crohn's disease and its relationship with early post-surgical disease recurrence. The study will also analyze the function of the bacterial profile and the association of genetic variants related to innate immunity and the bacterial microbiome profile of CD patients. The study will be conducted on CD patients requiring surgical treatment (ileocecal resection) and a control group of patients requiring an ileocecal resection for a cause other than CD. The primary outcome measures will be the differences in the proportions and abundance of bacterial taxa and the differences in the function of the bacterial profile between the mesentery, ileal tissue, and blood between CD patients with and without early post-surgical disease recurrence. The study will also analyze the association of genetic variants related to innate immunity and the bacterial microbiome profile of CD patients.

This study will evaluate the pharmacokinetics (PK) of LY3437943 in healthy participants with a high body mass index (BMI). Participants will receive a single dose of LY3437943 either subcutaneously (SC) or intravenously (IV). The primary outcome measures will be the PK of LY3437943, including the area under the plasma concentration versus time curve from zero to infinity (AUC[0-∞]) and the maximum concentration (Cmax). The study will be conducted in two parts: Part A will evaluate the PK of LY3437943 administered SC, and Part B will evaluate the PK of LY3437943 administered IV.

This clinical trial is a research registry for patients with pituitary tumors. The study aims to characterize the aggressiveness of pituitary tumors using molecular and transcriptomic analysis. The study is open to all adult patients with pituitary tumors who are presented to the national HYPOcare RCP. The primary outcome measures include the molecular and transcriptomic signature of aggressiveness of pituitary tumors predictive of prognosis. The study is being conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This is a randomized pilot study to assess the feasibility of investigating whether a lower starting dose with step-up approach leads to a better overall treatment utility compared to standard dosing in older adults with cancer. The study will evaluate the primary outcome measure of feasibility, and secondary outcome measures of overall treatment utility, progression-free survival, overall survival, quality of life, safety, hospital care use, pharmacokinetic parameters (Cmax, AUC, Ctrough) in 30 older adult patients with cancer. The study will be conducted over 12 weeks, with blood samples collected every 2 weeks for pharmacogenomic analysis.

This is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of preoperative short-course radiation followed by Envafolimab plus CAPEOX in patients with MSS-type advanced middle-low rectal cancer. The primary outcome measure is the pathologic complete response (pCR) rate, and the secondary outcome measures include tumor regression grade, overall survival (OS), progression-free survival (PFS), treatment-related adverse events (TRAEs), surgical complications, and quality of life (QoL). The study is an open-label, randomized controlled trial that will enroll 108 patients and will be conducted at multiple centers in China.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, cross-over clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of white kidney bean on oral glucose tolerance test. The study will enroll 35 healthy adults aged 25-45 years old, with a male to female ratio of more than 40% and BMI 24. The participants will be randomly assigned to receive either the white kidney bean pressed candy or the placebo for phase 1, followed by a washout period of 72 hours, and then receive the other treatment for phase 2. The primary outcome measure will be the change of blood glucose level in mmol/L based on OGTT after intervention. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of a community-based intervention for depression in a low-income setting in India. The intervention includes community awareness activities, home visits, and referral to health centers for treatment. The study will compare the effectiveness of the community intervention with the standard treatment in health centers. The primary outcome measures will be the Patient Health Questionnaire 9 items (PHQ-9) score and the mean PHQ-9 score. The study will also assess the cost-effectiveness of the interventions and the perceived social support and awareness about depression.

The study aims to investigate the effects of low-intensity blood flow restriction training in normoxia and hypoxia conditions on muscle strength, thickness, catecholamine, and inflammatory responses in physically active adults. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with participants assigned to one of six groups: low-intensity normoxia, high-intensity normoxia, low-intensity hypoxia, and low-intensity hypoxia with blood flow restriction. The primary outcome measures will include force output, one-repetition maximum, maximum number of repetitions, countermovement jump height, and catecholamine response. Secondary outcome measures will include muscle stiffness, muscle thickness, perception of pain, perception of effort, and blood pressure. The study will be conducted over a period of six weeks, with participants undergoing training sessions twice a week.

This is a Phase II, open-label, single-arm clinical trial of subcutaneous mosunetuzumab monotherapy in patients with early relapse of follicular lymphoma in the Nordic countries. The primary objective is to investigate the efficacy of subcutaneous mosunetuzumab monotherapy in patients with follicular lymphoma and progression of disease within 24 months of starting first-line treatment. The secondary objectives are to investigate the safety of mosunetuzumab, prognostic significance of 18F-FDG-PET-CT response to mosunetuzumab, and resource usage related to mosunetuzumab.

The study will enroll approximately 30 patients and will be conducted at multiple sites in the Nordic countries. The study will consist of a screening period, treatment period, and follow-up period. The treatment will be administered as subcutaneous injections once every 21 days for up to 17 cycles. The primary outcome measure will be progression-free survival, and the secondary outcome measures will include overall response rate, complete response rate, duration of response, time to new lymphoma treatment, overall survival, and the percentage of patients with adverse events.

The study will be conducted in accordance with the International Council for Harmonisation of Technical Requirements for Pharmaceuticals for Human Use (ICH) Good Clinical Practice (GCP) guidelines and the Declaration of Helsinki. The study will be monitored by an independent data and safety monitoring committee (DSMC).

The results of this study will provide valuable information on the efficacy and safety of subcutaneous mosunetuzumab monotherapy in patients with early relapse of follicular lymphoma and will help to determine the potential of this treatment approach in this patient population.

This is a phase I/II study of BET and MEK inhibition in advanced uveal melanoma. Patients receive PLX2853 and trametinib PO throughout the study. Patients also undergo CT or MRI with contrast and collection of blood at screening and on study.

Official Title: Phase I/II Study of BET and MEK Inhibition in Advanced Uveal Melanoma

Study Design:

* Phase I: This is a dose-escalation study of PLX2853 and trametinib followed by a phase II study.
* Phase II: Patients receive PLX2853 and trametinib PO throughout the study.

Key Inclusion Criteria:

* Histologically documented advanced uveal melanoma
* Locally advanced unresectable or metastatic uveal melanoma (UM)
* At least one lesion that is measurable according to RECIST version 1.1 criteria

Key Exclusion Criteria:

* Prior treatment with a BET or MEK inhibitor
* Chronic concomitant treatment with strong inhibitors of CYP3A4

Primary Outcome Measures:

* Maximum tolerated dose (MTD) (Phase I)
* Recommended Phase 2 Dose (RP2D) (Phase I)
* Overall response rate (ORR) (phase II)
* Median progression-free survival (PFS)
* Progression free survival (PFS)
* Median overall survival (OS)
* Overall survival (OS)
* Incidence of adverse events

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Systemic exposure to trametinib and PLX2853 - pharmacokinetics

This is a phase I/II study of BET and MEK inhibition in advanced uveal melanoma. Patients receive PLX2853 and trametinib PO throughout the study. Patients also undergo CT or MRI with contrast and collection of blood at screening and on study. The primary outcome measures are maximum tolerated dose (MTD), recommended phase 2 do

The study is a randomized, open-label, multicenter Phase IV clinical trial to evaluate the implementation and utility of a new model of care in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) or ASCVD-risk equivalents and elevated LDL-C. The study will be conducted at approximately 20 sites across Australia and will include male and female participants ≥18 years of age with a history of ASCVD or ASCVD-risk equivalents who have elevated LDL-C. Participants will be randomized to either the usual care arm or the new model of care arm. The primary outcome measure will be the effect on LDL-C concentration at day 180 and day 365. Secondary outcome measures will include the effect on LDL-C concentration at other time points, changes in cardiovascular risk factors, and participant-reported outcomes. The study will use inclisiran prefilled syringes as the intervention and will include monthly SMS messages and telephone-based support calls as part of the new model of care. The study will assess the effectiveness of the new model of care compared to usual care in reducing LDL-C levels and improving cardiovascular outcomes in patients with ASCVD or ASCVD-risk equivalents.

This study aims to compare the efficacy of ultrasound-guided erector spinae block, thoracic paravertebral block, and quadratus lamborum block in open renal surgeries. The primary outcome measure is total morphine requirements 24 hours postoperatively. The study is a randomized, controlled, single-blinded trial conducted in urology operating theatre, Al-Azhar university hospital, Egypt.

* This study aims to describe and evaluate musculoskeletal health of adult haematological cancer survivors.
* The study will use a mixed-methods study design.
* The study will recruit 500 participants.
* The study will collect data through questionnaires and interviews.
* The study will measure prevalence of musculoskeletal conditions and related symptoms, 10-year probability of hip fracture and major osteoporotic fracture, prevalence of sarcopenia and frailty, and quality of life and musculoskeletal health related quality of life and musculoskeletal health and musculoskeletal health related quality of life and musculoskeletal health related quality of life and musculoskeal health related quality of life and musculoskeal health related quality of life and musculoskeal health related quality of life and musculoskeal health related quality of life and musculoskeal health related quality of life and musculoskeal health related quality of life and musculoskeal health related quality of life and musculoskeal health related quality of life and musculoskeal health related quality of life and musculoskeal health related quality of life and musculoskeal health related quality of life and musculoskeal health related quality of life and musculoskeal health related quality of life and musculoskeal health related quality of life and musculoskeal health related quality of life and musculoskeal health related quality of life and musculoskeal quality of life and musculoskeal quality of life and musculoskeal quality of life and musculoskeal quality of life and musculoskeal quality of life and musculositale quality of life and musculos of life and musculos of life and musculos of life and musculos of life and musculos of life and musculos of life and musculos of life and musculos of life and musculos of life and musculos of life and musculate of life and musculate the musculate the musculate of life and musculate of life and musculate the musculate the musculate the musculate and musculates of the mus

This is a Phase 2, open-label, single-arm, multicenter study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of disitamab vedotin in previously treated solid tumors that express HER2. The study will enroll approximately 120 participants across four cohorts: HNSCC, NSCLC, ovarian cancer, and endometrial cancer. Participants will receive disitamab vedotin monotherapy every 2 weeks until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. The primary outcome measure is confirmed objective response rate (ORR) per Response Evaluation in Solid Tumors version 1.1 (RECIST v1.1) by investigator assessment. Secondary outcome measures include number of participants with adverse events (AEs), number of participants with laboratory abnormalities, number of participants with dose alterations due to AEs, confirmed disease control rate (DCR) per RECIST v1.1 by investigator assessment, duration of response (DOR) per RECIST v1.1 by investigator assessment, duration of progression-free survival (PFS) per RECIST v1.1 by investigator assessment, overall survival (OS), and pharmacokinetic (PK) parameters.

The study aims to assess the feasibility and acceptability of in-vehicle driving assessment and monitoring to address ICU-acquired cognitive decline in older adults. The investigators will use neurocognitive assessments and in-vehicle kinematic driving data to evaluate the relationship between driving behaviors and safety in older ICU survivors. The study will enroll a cohort of older ICU survivors with risk factors for ICU-acquired cognitive impairment and will evaluate the protocol feasibility and acceptability of neurocognitive assessments and in-vehicle sensor deployment. The study will also conduct stakeholder advisory panels to provide scientific justification and protocol feasibility to evaluate recruitment, acceptability, and attrition for future full-scale implementation.

This study aims to assess the effectiveness of a brief acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) workshop for promoting healthy lifestyle behaviors in women with obesity. The workshop will focus on teaching participants skills such as valued living and committed action to approach healthy living. The study will use a randomized controlled design, with participants randomly assigned to either the intervention group (receiving the ACT workshop) or the waitlist control group (receiving no intervention until the end of the study). The primary outcome measures will include change in psychological flexibility, distress tolerance, and valued living at 1 week and 1 month post-intervention. Secondary outcome measures will include change in weight self-stigma, body image, emotional eating, physical activity, diet quality, and body weight.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the study.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the value of minimal residual disease (MRD) detection in monitoring postoperative recurrence of high-risk gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) and investigate the effect of drug holiday treatment based on MRD detection on disease recurrence and patient survival. The study will enroll high-risk GIST patients who have been treated with imatinib for 3 years after surgery and have achieved disease control. The patients will be monitored for progress-free survival, drug re-use rate, and drug retreatment response rate. The study will also explore the genetic mutation profiling of circulating tumor DNA-MRD and compare the time of MRD conversion and the time of disease progression assessed by imaging examination.

This study aims to compare the effects of Dohsa hou exercises on functional mobility in children with Down syndrome. The study will be a randomized control trial, where subjects will be divided into two groups: one group will receive standard treatment protocol, and the other group will receive Dohsa hou exercises. The primary outcome measures will be assessed using the Trunk Impairment Scale and Time Up and Go Test. The study will be conducted for 6 weeks, and the results will be analyzed to determine the effectiveness of Dohsa hou exercises on functional mobility in children with Down syndrome.

The Supporting Physical Literacy at School and Home (SPLASH) study aims to increase children's physical literacy and physical activity through a multilevel, comprehensive program that will reach children both at school and at home. The program will be tested using a 2-arm, group randomized controlled trial with n=400 3rd-5th grade students from low-income schools. The primary outcome measures will be children's physical activity level and fundamental movement skill in running, locomotion, object control and balance.

This is a 76-week, randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, Phase III study to assess the efficacy and safety of BI 456906 in Japanese patients with obesity. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either BI 456906 (survodutide) 3.6 mg or 6.0 mg subcutaneously once weekly or placebo. The primary outcome measures will be the percentage change in body weight from baseline to Week 76 and the achievement of body weight reduction ≥5% (yes/no) from baseline to Week 76. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in body weight, body mass index (BMI), waist circumference, blood pressure, eating behavior, glycemic control, lipid profile, and liver fat content, as well as safety and tolerability.

Please note that this is a summary and not the actual study document.

This study aims to evaluate the gastric volume of pediatric patients undergoing adenotonsillectomy surgery using ultrasound. The primary outcome measure is gastric volume, and secondary outcome measures include the cross-sectional area of the gastric antrum, postoperative presence and severity of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), and duration of surgery. The study is a single-group, open-label design, and all patients will receive ultrasound assessment of gastric volume in the preoperative and postoperative periods while laying in the right lateral decubitus position.

This is a randomized controlled study to assess the efficacy and safety of pituitrin in patients with pulmonary hypertension undergoing cardiac surgery. The study will be conducted in a single center and will enroll 120 patients who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria. The patients will be randomly assigned to receive either pituitrin or normal saline. The primary outcome measure will be a composite endpoint of mortality or severe postoperative complications within 30 days after cardiac surgery. Secondary outcome measures will include incidence of postoperative infection, septic shock, duration of mechanical ventilation, postoperative pulmonary complications, time to achieve hemodynamic stability, use of dobutamine or other vasoactive drugs, incidence of digital ischemia, acute mesenteric ischemia, gastrointestinal complications, incidence of acute myocardial infarction, new onset tachyarrhythmia, water poisoning, vasodilative shock, incidence of pulmonary embolism, low cardiac output syndrome, acute respiratory distress syndrome, delirium, need for renal replacement therapy (RRT), need for hemodialysis, incidence of readmission to ICU, length of ICU stay, length of stay, levels of serum antidiuretic hormone in patients, levels of copeptin in patients, and secondary endotracheal intubation. The study will be conducted over a period of 30 days, and the results will be analyzed to determine the efficacy and safety of pituitrin in patients with pulmonary hypertension undergoing cardiac surgery.

The study aims to evaluate the feasibility and safety of a novel care model for initiating noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NiPPV) in children with medical complexity (CMC) at home, using remote telemonitoring, compared to the standard of care of initiating NiPPV in a one-night in-hospital polysomnography (PSG) laboratory. The primary outcome measures include recruitment and retention rates, proportion of eligible patients randomized, and proportion of patients that crossover based on safety criteria. Secondary outcome measures include mean minutes of nightly NiPPV usage, proxy-reported psychological scale, self-reported psychological scale, caregiver reported sense of mastery, and patient and family study experience, preference of intervention, and barriers. The study will be conducted as a single-site, open-label, parallel-group, randomized controlled trial with 1:1 allocation of children newly initiating NiPPV to either the home NiPPV initiation group or the standard of care group.

This study aims to investigate the effects of dry needling on latent myofascial trigger points on vertical jump performance in female athletes. The study will be a single-blind randomized clinical trial carried out in the department of Invasive Physiotherapy of a private Physiotherapy Clinic in Toledo. The inclusion criteria is healthy female volleyball practitioners; no lower limb injuries in the last 6 months; presence of latent MTPs in gastrocnemius; familiar with performing CMJ tests. The intervention will be dry needling, and the control group will be asked to wait on the intervention couch for a similar time as the ones who received the treatment. The primary outcome measure will be counter movement jump. The study will be conducted over a period of 7 days, with assessments at baseline (T0), immediately after the intervention (T1), 72 hours after the intervention (T3), and 7 days after the intervention (T4).

The study aims to investigate the clinical features of refractory gastrointestinal Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP) and the clinical outcome of mycophenolate mofetil in these patients. The study is an open-label, single-group assignment design, and all patients will receive mycophenolate mofetil treatment. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of abdominal pain, hematemesis, and bloody stools at 6 months. The study will also assess the count of red blood cells in stool every week for 6 months. The study is enrolling patients aged 3 to 18 years old who meet the diagnostic criteria for HSP and have refractory gastrointestinal involvement. Exclusion criteria include allergies to mycophenolate mofetil, severe diseases, other digestive system diseases, previous use of mycophenolate mofetil in clinical trials, and other situations deemed inappropriate for participation by the researcher.

The study aims to assess the safety and feasibility of using EEG-enhanced transcranial magnetic stimulation (eTMS) as an adjunct to standard of care treatment for chronic trauma and stressor-related disorders (TSRD) in veterans. The study will enroll 30 participants in the initial stage, with an interim analysis after 6 weeks. If safety benchmarks are passed, the study will proceed with an additional 270 participants. The primary outcome measures will include the number of participants with device-related serious adverse events and the rate of participants completing 80% of scheduled visits. Secondary outcome measures will include the mean change in Veterans RAND 36-item health survey (VR-36) mental component scores. The study will use an open-label, single-group assignment design, with no masking.

This is a retrospective study of radiotherapy combined with EGFR-TKI for stage III EGFR mutant lung cancer. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival. The study is open-label, multi-institutional, and single-arm. Participants receive 3DCRT or IMRT at a prescribed dose of 54-66 Gy/27-33 f, and the combined TKI includes gefitinib, erlotinib, erlotinib, oseltinib, and ametinib. The study is designed to assess the efficacy and safety of the combination of radiotherapy and EGFR-TKI in patients with stage III EGFR mutant lung cancer.

This study aims to identify the microorganisms responsible for acute head and neck infections. The study will be conducted at Northampton General Hospital and will include patients over the age of 18 who are suffering from acute head and neck infections caused by Streptococci. The study will use DNA analysis of ribosomal ribonucleic acid (rRNA) genes and biochemical testing to identify the Streptococci species. The study will also measure patient characteristics, clinical outcomes, and antibiotic treatment. The study will be conducted over a period of four years.

The study aims to compare the effectiveness of functional magnetic stimulation and pelvic floor muscle training on pelvic floor muscle function, urinary incontinence symptoms, and quality of life in women with stress urinary incontinence. The study is a randomized controlled trial with 48 participants, divided into two groups: the I group (n=24) receiving functional magnetic stimulation and the II group (n=24) receiving pelvic floor muscle training. The primary outcome measures are urinary incontinence symptoms and quality of life, assessed using the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Short Form (ICIQ-SF) and Incontinence Impact Questionnaire-Short Form (IIQ-7). The study will be conducted over 6 weeks, with assessments at baseline and at the end of the intervention. The study aims to determine which of the two treatments is more effective in improving pelvic floor muscle function, reducing urinary incontinence symptoms, and improving quality of life in women with stress urinary incontinence.

The study aims to investigate the use of ultrasonography and tissue biomarkers in optimizing the selection and treatment outcomes of biologic therapies for patients with psoriatic arthritis (PsA) and seronegative rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The study will enroll patients who are naive to treatment, TNF-inhibitor resistant, IL-17-inhibitor resistant, TNF-inhibitor induced remission, IL-17-inhibitor induced remission, c-DMARDs resistant PsA, and c-DMARDs resistant RA. The study will use a comprehensive cellular and molecular atlas of PsA by CITE-Seq (single cell protein and transcriptomics) and spatial transcriptomics of synovium of PsO at risk of developing PsA and PsA patients across different disease stages. The primary outcome measures will include minimal disease activity status achievement, PsA development (fulfillment of the CASPAR criteria), and remission maintenance. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of artificial tears in preventing nasolacrimal duct obstruction in patients treated with radioactive iodine for thyroid cancer. Participants will be randomly assigned to either receive artificial tears or no intervention in the 4 days following radioactive iodine therapy. The primary outcome measure will be the incidence of post-radiotherapy nasolacrimal duct obstruction, assessed by tear duct irrigation by an ophthalmologist. The study will be conducted over a period of 2 years.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to assess the effectiveness of atorvastatin in preventing disease metastasis in patients with resected high-risk stage IIA melanoma. The study will compare recurrence-free survival, distant metastasis-free survival, and overall survival between patients receiving atorvastatin and those receiving placebo. The study will also assess the clinical utility of gene expression profiling in melanoma.

Please note that this is a machine-generated summary and may not fully capture the complexity of the study.

The study aims to determine the impact of three implementation strategies (training, coaching, facilitation) in 20 outpatient clinics in central North Carolina on the recognition and response to severe hypertension during pregnancy or postpartum. The study will compare usual care to the care provided after a practice has 12 months of implementation support from the ACHIEVE Nurse Coordinator. The primary outcome measures are the normalized percentage of achieving the highest possible score for blood pressure measurement technique and documentation of delivery of patient education on hypertension. Secondary outcome measures include recognition and response to simulated and actual episodes of severe hypertension.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of gain and loss framed text messaging programs to reduce drinking among older adults. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design, with three text-messaging programs: loss-framed, gain-framed, and combined (loss and gain) messaging. Participants will be randomized to one of the three conditions, and the primary outcome measures will include weekly sum of standard drinks and weekly sum of heavy drinking days. Secondary outcome measures will include adherence to daily and weekly drinking assessments, and willingness to continue the program for another 8 weeks. The study will explore how the effects of the intervention are impacted by gender and age.

The study aims to assess the safety and efficacy of 18F-Fluselenamyl, a new PET imaging agent for the detection of beta-amyloid plaques in the brains of patients with Alzheimer's disease. The study will enroll healthy volunteers and patients with mild cognitive impairment and use both 18F-Fluselenamyl and 11C-PIB PET imaging to compare the sensitivity and specificity of the two tracers. The primary outcome measures will include the safety of the tracer and the ability of 18F-Fluselenamyl to detect beta-amyloid plaques in the brain.

The study aims to investigate the long-term effect of transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) in primary progressive aphasia (PPA). The study will be conducted as a randomized, parallel-group, triple-masked, placebo-controlled trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either active TMS or sham TMS, in addition to language therapy. The primary outcome measure will be changes in brain metabolism, as measured by FDG-PET imaging, at 0 and 6 months. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in spontaneous language, language assessment (Mini-Linguistic State Examination), trained words accuracy, untrained words accuracy, daily-living activities, and neuropsychiatric symptoms, all assessed at 0, 3, and 6 months. The study will enroll 40 participants with PPA, and will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in Quebec, Canada.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the impact of methylprednisolone on cognitive deficits in post-COVID-19 syndrome patients with suspected autoimmune involvement. The study will enroll 52 participants and will be conducted over 52 weeks. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either methylprednisolone or a placebo. The primary outcome measure will be the improvement in memory satisfaction as measured by the Multifactorial Memory Questionnaire (MMQ) at 8 weeks after the first IMP intake. Secondary outcome measures will include long-term improvement in memory satisfaction, improvement in neurocognitive functions, quality of life, physical and mental fatigue, and mood. The study will also assess the difference of occurring AE and SAE comparing Methyprednisolone with placebo (IMP safety).

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of a dietary supplement in improving the nutritional status of patients with disease-related malnutrition (DRM) and inflammation. The study will be conducted over a period of 3 consecutive months, and will include patients who meet the GLIM criteria for DRM with an inflammatory component. The primary outcome measures will be blood biochemistry data, including albumin, prealbumin, C-reactive protein, ferritin, neutrophils, lymphocytes, and platelets. Secondary outcome measures will include bioelectrical impedance data, functional parameters, oral intake, and malnutrition diagnosis. The study will be a randomized, controlled, open-label clinical trial, with patients randomly assigned to receive either the dietary supplement or a placebo. The study will be conducted at a single center, and will include a total of 30 patients.

The Kaiser Permanente Evaluating Nutritional Interventions in Food-Insecure High-Risk Adults (KP ENRICH) study aims to assess the effectiveness of financial support for healthy food purchases and free home delivery on glycosylated hemoglobin levels and other health outcomes in food-insecure adults with type 2 diabetes. The study will randomly assign participants to either an intervention group receiving financial support and free home delivery or a control group receiving only free home delivery. The primary outcome measure will be the change in glycosylated hemoglobin level at 6 months, with secondary outcomes including changes in glycosylated hemoglobin level at 12 months, all-cause hospitalizations or emergency department visits, self-reported level of food security, self-reported level of nutrition security, self-reported dietary habits, self-reported diabetes-related quality of life, and self-reported readiness to change. The study will be conducted at Kaiser Permanente facilities in California.

This is a four-arm, double-blind, randomized controlled clinical trial. Experimental group 1: 35 non-carious cervical lesions (NCCL) will receive composite resin restorations using an alcohol- and water-based solvent universal adhesive with evaporation of solvent for 25 seconds. Experimental group 2: 35 NCCL will receive composite resin restorations using an acetone-based universal solvent adhesive with solvent evaporation for 25 seconds. Control group 1: 35 NCCL will receive composite resin restorations using an alcohol- and water-based universal solvent adhesive with evaporation of solvent for 5 seconds. Control group 2: 35 NCCL will receive composite resin restorations using an acetone-based universal solvent adhesive with solvent evaporation for 5 seconds. The primary outcome measures are retention of restorations and marginal adaptation of restorations. The study will be conducted in Brazil and will include 35 participants in each group. The study is expected to be completed within 24 months.

This is a Phase 2/3, randomized, double-blinded, parallel-controlled trial to evaluate the immunogenicity, safety, and efficacy of a heterologous booster dose with COVID-19 mRNA vaccines (bivalent) in previously vaccinated subjects against COVID-19 with 2/3 doses of COVID-19 vaccine compared to a booster dose with mRNA COVID-19 vaccine (Pfizer Bivalent vaccine) in adults. The study will be performed in people who were previously vaccinated with 2/3 doses of COVID-19 vaccine, with or without previously diagnosed with COVID-19. The interval between the date of last dose and the date of this study vaccination should be 6 to 24 months. The study will be conducted in two phases: Phase II and Phase III. The primary outcome measures will be immunogenicity, safety, and efficacy.

The Esbjerg Cohort is a cross-sectional study that aims to investigate the relationship between ergonomic exposure and physical capacity in relation to work ability and musculoskeletal pain in workers aged 55-70 years. The study includes 336 participants and will be conducted in the municipality of Esbjerg, Denmark. The study will assess various physical and physiological parameters, including work ability, height, weight, body mass index, blood pressure, pain threshold, and musculoskeletal pain. The study will also evaluate the participants' ergonomic exposure at work and their physical activity levels. The results of this study will provide valuable insights into the impact of ergonomic exposure on the health and well-being of senior workers and will inform strategies for improving work ability and reducing musculoskeletal pain in this age group.

This is a dose-escalation study of autologous L1CAM-specific CAR+EGFRt+ T cells in treating patients with locally advanced and unresectable or metastatic small cell neuroendocrine prostate cancer. Participants undergo leukapheresis to obtain peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) for T cell product manufacturing and may undergo bridging therapy at the discretion of the treating clinician and/or principal investigator (PI). Participants then undergo lymphodepleting chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide and fludarabine, and receive an autologous L1CAM-specific CAR+EGFRt+ T cell infusion on day 0. Based on disease response and persistence of CAR T cells, participants may receive additional lymphodepletion chemotherapy and an autologous L1CAM-specific CAR+EGFRt+ T cell infusion as soon as 6 weeks and no later than 24 weeks after the first infusion, or at the discretion of the PI. The primary outcome measures are the incidence of adverse events and dose-limiting toxicity rates. Secondary outcome measures include objective response, radiographic progression-free survival, and overall survival.

This study aims to assess the safety and efficacy of a new technique called Whipple over the splenic artery (WOTSA) as a treatment for pancreatic ductal cell adenocarcinoma (PDCA) which traditionally requires total pancreatectomy (TP). The study will compare the clinicopathological characteristics and survival of 40 patients who underwent WOTSA with a historical control group of 30 patients who underwent TP. The primary outcome measures will include the remnant pancreatic volume and physiological parameters, and the secondary outcome measures will include postoperative chemotherapy and follow-up.

The study aims to investigate the effect of breastfeeding education given to fathers via WhatsApp messaging application in the postpartum period on breastfeeding. The study will be conducted as an experimental design with four groups of Solomon. The primary outcome measures will be the Breastfeeding Support Scale and the Partner Breastfeeding Influence Scale, which will be administered to the fathers and mothers on the 3rd and 42nd day postpartum, and at 12 weeks postpartum. The study will be conducted in a hospital setting and will include mothers and fathers who are breastfeeding and have a gestational age of 37 weeks and above, weighing 2500 g and over, and not having any congenital diseases or health problems that may prevent breastfeeding. The study will be randomized, double-masked, and parallel-group design.

This study aims to evaluate the frequency and timing of PIK3CA mutation testing in patients with advanced breast cancer (ABC) and the correlation with clinical outcomes. The study will also assess the treatment patterns and outcomes in patients with PIK3CA-mutated ABC. The study is a non-interventional, retrospective analysis of electronic health records (EHRs) and will include patients who were diagnosed with ABC between 2015 and 2020. The primary outcome measures will include the number of patients with PIK3CA mutations, time from first BC diagnosis to first PIK3CA evaluation, and time from advanced BC diagnosis to first PIK3CA evaluation. Secondary outcome measures will include demographics, clinical and pathological characteristics, and treatment outcomes.

The study aims to investigate the effects of melatonin on sleep spindles in children with autism. The study will be conducted as an open-label, single-group assignment design, with participants receiving 5mg of melatonin per day for two consecutive nights. The primary outcome measure will be the change in sleep spindle density during non-rapid eye movement sleep, measured using a portable EEG device. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in sleep quality. The study will enroll male and female subjects with autism spectrum disorder aged 12-18 years, who will be excluded if they have a history of head injury, seizure disorder, or other neurological disorders.

This study aims to investigate the etiology of persistent velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI) in children with operated velopalatal cleft. The study will use real-time MRI to analyze velopharyngeal motor skills in static and dynamic conditions. The study will enroll 40 children aged 7 to 12 years with isolated cleft lip and/or velopalatal cleft who have undergone cheiloplasty or intravelar veloplasty at the Amiens University Hospital. Participants will be divided into four groups based on the severity of VPI and the anatomy of the velum. The primary outcome measures will include the ratio between the diameter of the pharynx at rest and during phonation, closure distance between the velar knee and the posterior pharyngeal wall, and distance between the velar knee and the posterior pharyngeal wall. The study will be conducted at the Amiens University Hospital and will have a parallel assignment, double-masked design.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of a home-based exercise training program (GEMS program) in improving cognition, walking, and physical activity in older adults with multiple sclerosis (MS). The program will be delivered remotely using telerehabilitation, and will include a 16-week intervention period followed by a 32-week follow-up period. The primary outcome measures will include cognitive function, walking endurance, and physical function. Secondary outcome measures will include physical activity level, exercise behavior, vascular function, and cognitive function. The study will enroll 120 participants and will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in Montreal, Canada.

This is a pilot study to assess the clinical and biological effects of using the oXiris hemofiltration hemofilter with blood purification capability in critically ill patients with vasoplegic shock. The primary outcome measure is a 50% reduction in vasoinotropic score within 24 hours of initiation on oXiris. Secondary outcome measures include the evolution of the vaso-inotropic score within 72 hours of management, quantitative determination of angiotensins and regulatory enzymes, clearance of endothelial permeability markers, markers of sepsis-induced immunosuppression, and mortality at 90 days. The study will be conducted as a non-interventional research study, and patients will be monitored for 3 months.

This study aims to compare the efficacy and safety of two different methods of urinary bladder dissection during total laparoscopic hysterectomy in cases with previous cesarean section. The two methods are central and lateral urinary bladder dissection. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with 50 patients in each arm. The primary outcome measure will be the rate of urinary bladder injury during dissection, and secondary outcome measures will include operative time, amount of blood loss, and late urological complications. The study will be conducted at a single center, and the participants will be women undergoing total laparoscopic hysterectomy for benign conditions with a previous cesarean section scar.

This is a 6-month observational study of patients with asthma. The study will look at the association of the asthma microbiome and disease characteristics, severity, and treatment response. Participants will be divided into two groups: biologic naive and biologic treated. The study will measure the microbiome signature across the spectrum of asthma severity, establish if there is any association between asthma phenotype and microbiome signature, and determine whether microbiome signature can predict treatment response or resistance.

This study will compare the effects of split-body and full-body resistance training on strength and functional performance in amateur cricket players. The study will be a randomized controlled trial with 28 participants divided into two groups: a split-body resistance training group and a full-body resistance training group. The training will last for 6 weeks, and the participants' strength and functional performance will be measured using the bench press test, leg press test, and 30-second sit-to-stand test. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The Effect Of Traınıng On Breastfeedıng Gıven To Fathers On Breastfeedıng, Parent-Baby Bondıng And Breastfeedıng Self-Effıcacy Level is a clinical trial that aims to investigate the effect of training on breastfeeding given to fathers on breastfeeding, parent-baby bonding, and breastfeeding self-efficacy level. The study will be conducted with a randomized controlled design, and the participants will be divided into three groups: experimental group 1 (breastfeeding training given to mothers and fathers), experimental group 2 (breastfeeding training given only to mothers), and control group (no intervention). The primary outcome measures will include breastfeeding self-efficacy scale-short form, mother to infant bonding scale, father breastfeeding self-efficacy scale short form, paternal-infant attachment questionnaire, and baby evaluation form. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study is a randomized, double-blind controlled trial to investigate the effects of Amway Bundle Combination of Products on Osteoarthritis & Sarcopenia. The study will be conducted on Chinese males and females, aged 50-70, with Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) scale 4-9, but walking 400 meters within 15 minutes, and reporting <20 minutes/week in the past month performing regular physical activity and <125 minutes/week of moderate physical activity. The study will be divided into four arms: Bundle Group 1 with Nutrilite Lifestyle, Bundle Group 2 without Nutrilite Lifestyle, Control Group 1, and Control Group 2 with Nutrilite Lifestyle. The primary outcome measures will be the change of Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) score from baseline, and the secondary outcome measures will include change of WOMAC Questionnaire Scores, Visual Analogue Scale/Score (VAS), Chalder Fatigue Scale (CFS), improvement of fat and muscle portions measured by Inbody S10, change of Hand & Grip Strength measured by Jamar Smart Hand Dynamometer, and change of bone density measured by DXA Bone Densitometer. The study will be conducted for 180 days, with assessments at baseline, day 90, and day 180.
