The purpose of this study is to investigate the effect of adding strengthening exercise for hip rotators and ankle muscles to knee exercises on pain, function, strength of muscles, and knee proprioception in patients with knee osteoarthritis.

The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with 2 groups: an experimental group that will receive strengthening exercises for hip rotators and ankle muscles in addition to quadriceps strengthening, and a control group that will receive quadriceps strengthening only. The primary outcome measures will be pain level, functional level, and knee proprioception, assessed using visual analogue scale, Knee injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score, and joint position sense, respectively. Secondary outcome measures will include strength of hip internal and external rotators, ankle dorsi flexors, planter flexors, invertor and evertor muscles, and quadriceps strength, assessed using handheld dynamometer.

The study will enroll 20 patients in each group, and will be conducted over a period of 4 weeks. The results of this study will provide valuable information on the effectiveness of adding strengthening exercises for hip rotators and ankle muscles to knee exercises in the treatment of knee osteoarthritis.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of Novabel bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent for the treatment of chronic sinusitis. The study is a randomized, parallel-assignment, double-masked trial that will enroll 120 participants who are scheduled to undergo primary or revision bilateral endoscopic sinus surgery. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either the Novabel bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent or a marketed bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent. The primary outcome measure will be the non-reintervention rate at 30 days post-procedure. Secondary outcome measures will include Lund-Kennedy and Lund-Mackay scores, VAS score, sinus panty rate, and implantation successful rate. The study will be conducted at one center in China and is expected to be completed within 18 months.

This study aims to assess the effectiveness of providing cancer care closer to home for patients with multiple myeloma. The study will compare the outcomes of patients who transfer their care to a satellite site with those who do not. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of eligible participants who successfully transfer to the provider at a satellite location. Secondary outcome measures include the types of candidacy that providers use for transfer of care, treatment burden, satisfaction with participant-provider interactions, financial toxicity, and participant rationales for opting to transfer or maintain care at their usual site. The study will use a non-randomized, parallel assignment design, with participants either transferring their care to a satellite site or maintaining their care at their usual site. The study will be conducted at the Siteman Cancer Center, with participants recruited from the Division of Oncology.

This study is comparing the use of virtual reality goggles to nitrous oxide for pain management during dental procedures in pediatric patients. The primary outcome measures are the rate of effectiveness of virtual reality distraction to nitrous oxide and the rate of effectiveness virtual reality goggles reduce pain. The study is randomized, open-label, and will enroll 4-12 year old patients who require two restorative procedures that include injection of anesthesia.

This clinical trial aims to identify patients with a high risk of recurrent colorectal lesions and personalize their surveillance based on mutation burden and clinical-pathological phenotype. The study will determine the mutation profile and mutation burden in 200 patients using an established PCR/DCE-based heteroduplex method and evaluate the clinical and histopathological parameters with mutational phenotype of patient. The study will also compare the mutation profile of lesions from the index period with the mutation profile of metachronous lesions and analyze the similarity of the mutation profile of lesions found in the same/close areas of the colorectum.

The SAM Project: Science Against Malnutrition Project is a clinical trial that aims to characterize malnutrition through the identification of specific biomarkers of the condition. The study will analyze the expression of microRNAs in blood and saliva samples, as well as the metagenomic analysis of fecal and salivary samples. The study will also measure the plasmatic extracellular vesicles and the metabolomic analysis of fecal and salivary samples. The study will be conducted on patients affected by malnutrition and sex- and age-matched healthy controls not affected by any pathology and/or malnutrition due to deficiency or excess. The study will be conducted for 36 months.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of different exercise strategies in patients with Parkinson's disease. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months and will involve 3 treatment groups: standard care, written exercise guidance by neurologists, and physical therapy. The primary outcome measures will include minutes per day of moderate to vigorous physical activity and steps per day. The study will be conducted at two clinics in the Chicagoland area: Northwestern Medicine Lake Forest and University of Chicago Medical Center.

This clinical trial aims to assess the effectiveness of multi-channel time-resolved functional near infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) in preventing perioperative brain injury during shoulder surgery in the beach chair position. The study will use a full-head coverage tr-fNIRS device to monitor cerebral oxygenation in multiple brain regions during surgery, and will compare the results to current commercial cerebral oximeters. The primary outcome measure will be the impact of intraoperative hemodynamic parameters on regional differences in cerebral oxygenation between brain regions during surgery. Secondary outcome measures will include regional differences in cerebral autoregulation, covert stroke, and delirium. The study will enroll 30 patients and will be conducted at a single center.

The study is a randomized clinical feasibility trial that aims to assess the safety and efficacy of Mechanical Insufflation-Exsufflation (Cough Assist) in critically ill adults. The study will be conducted in two ICUs in Belgium and will include patients who are invasively ventilated for more than 48 hours. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of complete sessions of MI-E every calendar day for all patients with a maximum of seven days of invasive ventilation. Secondary outcome measures include the incidence of pneumothorax, endotracheal tube obstruction, severe hypoxemia, severe hypotension, and severe hypertension. The study will also assess the acceptability, intervention appropriateness, and feasibility of MI-E. The sample size calculation is based on the incidence of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and the duration of invasive ventilation. The study will be conducted over a period of one year, and the results will be used to determine the efficacy and safety of MI-E in critically ill adults.

The Enavogliflozin Outcome Trial in Functional Tricuspid Regurgitation (EVENT) is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study that aims to assess the effects of enavogliflozin on clinical and echocardiographic outcomes in patients with functional tricuspid regurgitation and heart failure with preserved left ventricular ejection fraction. The study will be conducted over 18 months and will enroll patients who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria. The primary outcome measure will be a composite of cardiovascular death, hospitalization for heart failure, or worsening of tricuspid regurgitation. Secondary outcome measures will include all-cause death, cardiovascular clinical event, renal event, change of tricuspid regurgitation, and change of right ventricular strain. The study will be conducted at multiple sites and will be randomized, double-blind, and placebo-controlled.

The study aims to investigate the relationship between physical activity and FVIII pharmacokinetics in patients with severe hemophilia A under prophylaxis. The study will use the SenseWear armband device to measure the number of daily steps and assess the association between physical activity and FVIII PK parameters. The study will enroll patients aged 12-60 years with severe hemophilia A and will be conducted at the Haemostasis and Thrombosis Center of the Fondazione Policlinico Gemelli IRCCS Rome.

This study aims to determine the effectiveness of early vs late locomotor training in individuals with spinal cord injuries. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four groups: early intervention, sub-acute intervention, chronic intervention, or standard of care. The primary outcome measures will include the 10-meter walk test, 6-minute walk test, and walking index for spinal cord injury. Secondary outcome measures will include daily step counts. The study will be conducted at a single center and will enroll 160 participants.

The study aims to investigate the effect of education given according to the health promotion model on premenstrual symptoms, emotional eating behavior and perceived stress in women experiencing premenstrual syndrome. The study will be conducted as a pretest-posttest randomized controlled study. The participants will be randomly assigned to the experimental and control groups. The experimental group will receive training given according to the health promotion model using the Philips 66 technique, while the control group will not receive any training. The primary outcome measures will include the Premenstrual Syndrome Scale, Eating Habits During the Premenstrual Period Form, Healthy Lifestyle Behaviors Scale, Emotional Eating Scale, Perceived Stress Scale, and Visual Vissual Pain Scale. The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year.

The AMP SCZ Observational Study: PREDICT-DPACC is a non-interventional study that aims to identify and validate biomarkers and predict individual outcome trajectories in clinical high-risk (CHR) individuals for psychosis. The study will capture data from two CHR research networks and will be analyzed using a flexible infrastructure that can accommodate multiple data types. The study will assess clinical trajectories and predictors of outcomes in the CHR population, and will examine measures such as clinical, cognitive, neurophysiology, neuroimaging, genetics, and fluid biomarkers. The study will also use digital assessments such as daily ecological momentary assessment and passive sensing measurements. The study is expected to provide powerful and robust stratification tools to identify and validate biomarkers and predict individual outcome trajectories.

The study aims to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of the Problem Management Plus (PM+) intervention for prisoners in the Netherlands. The PM+ intervention is a brief, scalable, and evidence-based psychological intervention that addresses common mental health problems. The study will be conducted as a single-blind pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) with a qualitative study to evaluate the process following the pilot RCT. The primary outcome measures will assess the feasibility and acceptability of PM+, and the secondary outcome measures will provide preliminary indications of pre to post-effects on symptoms of depression and anxiety, self-identified problems, quality of life, trauma, and suicidal vulnerability. The study will include 60 Dutch-speaking adult prisoners with elevated levels of psychological distress, who will be randomly assigned to either the PM+ intervention group or the care-as-usual control group. The study will be conducted in Dutch prisons, and the intervention will be delivered by trained master students in clinical psychology. The study will assess the feasibility and acceptability of PM+ in the prison setting and provide preliminary indications of its effectiveness in improving mental health outcomes among prisoners.

This study is a Phase I clinical trial that aims to determine the safety and efficacy of xevinapant in combination with radiation and chemotherapy in patients with head and neck cancer. The study will be conducted in two parts: dose escalation and dose expansion. Participants will be assigned to one of five dose levels of xevinapant (50 mg, 100 mg, 150 mg, 200 mg, or a dose found during the escalation phase) and will receive radiation and chemotherapy (carboplatin and paclitaxel) weekly for 7 doses. The primary outcome measure is to determine the best safe dose of xevinapant when given in combination with radiation and chemotherapy. Secondary outcome measures include progression-free survival, overall survival, locoregional failure, distant failure, and response rate.

Please note that this is a summary and not the actual clinical trial document.

This clinical trial is researching the safety and effectiveness of the drug ARV-471 (PF-07850327) in treating estrogen receptor-positive (ER+) and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-advanced breast cancer in Chinese participants. The study is a single-arm, open-label, phase 1 clinical trial. Participants will get a single dose of ARV-471 once daily for 28 days. The study will assess the pharmacokinetics, safety, and tolerability of ARV-471 in Chinese participants with ER+/HER2- advanced breast cancer.

The Paramedical Protocol for Ventilation in Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome is a clinical trial that aims to assess the effectiveness of a paramedical care protocol in reducing mortality and improving outcomes in patients with ARDS. The study is a prospective, multicenter, randomized, controlled, open-label, phase III, stepped wedge cluster randomized design. The primary outcome measure is a combination of mortality and the number of days without mechanical ventilation at D28. Secondary outcome measures include measures of tidal volume ventilation, plateau pressure, PEEP, FiO2, oxygenation, and duration of mechanical ventilation. The study will be conducted at multiple centers and will enroll patients aged 18 years or older who are intubated and mechanically ventilated with ARDS. The study is expected to run for 26 months.

The proposed study aims to improve HIV outcomes among Haitian immigrants living with HIV in the US by adapting and testing the iENGAGE intervention, a culturally tailored engagement and retention intervention. The study will be conducted as a prospective, quasi-experimental single arm with a sample of newly diagnosed or nonvirally suppressed HIWLH adults drawn from two Federally Qualified Health Centers in Miami. The primary outcome measures will include change in engagement in care score and change in HIV load measurement. The study will also use a mixed-methods approach to examine barriers and facilitators to viral suppression among HILWH.

The study is a randomized controlled clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of the Endoclean device in comparison to the Passive Ultrasonic Irrigation (PUI) and Conventional preparation methods for root canal debridement. The study will enroll 109 subjects and will be conducted over a period of 2-3 years. The primary outcome measure will be the successful healing of periapical lesion up to 12 months post-procedure, and the secondary outcome measures will include freedom from postoperative pain up to 7 days of follow-up period and long-term effectiveness up to 24 months post-procedure. The study will be conducted at a single center and will include patients aged between 18-75 years with apical periodontitis and radiographic evidence of apical periodontitis in anterior or posterior teeth larger than 1.5 mm in diameter. Exclusion criteria include patients with pre-existing health or oral conditions that placed them at risk during the trial, patients with generalized untreated periodontal disease, and patients with a history of analgesic intake within the past 3 days or antibiotics in the last 1 month. The study will use a parallel assignment intervention model and will be open-label, meaning that neither the participants nor the investigators will be blinded to the intervention. The results of the Endoclean group will be compared to data gathered from the comparator device groups, and the results will be presented in the clinical investigation report.

The FRACT-AI study aims to evaluate the impact of artificial intelligence-enhanced image analysis on the diagnostic accuracy of frontline clinicians in the detection of fractures on plain X-rays. The study will compare the performance of 18 readers with and without AI assistance in detecting fractures on X-rays. The study will use a randomized controlled design, with each reader reviewing 500 X-rays in two sessions, one with AI assistance and one without. The primary outcome measures will include sensitivity, specificity, and area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AU ROC) for both the AI algorithm and the readers with and without AI assistance. The study will also assess the speed of the readers with and without AI assistance. The study is expected to provide valuable insights into the potential benefits and limitations of using AI in radiology and emergency medicine.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the fine motor skills, hand grip strength, and hand and forearm anthropometric characteristics of children with specific learning disorders (SLD) compared to healthy children. The study will also investigate the relationships between these factors and the impact of fine motor skills on quality of life and participation in activities at home, school, and community settings. The study will use the Bruininks-Oseretsky Test of Motor Proficiency-2 (BOT-2), Purdue Pegboard Test, Hand Dynamometer, and Pinch Gauge to assess fine motor skills, grip strength, and anthropometric measurements. The study will also use the Participation and Environment Measurement Child & Youth (PEM-CY) and the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PEDS-QL) to assess quality of life and participation.

The IM-ZBULLE Study is a multicenter, prospective, randomized, double-blind, controlled, study in 2 parallel groups. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of combining the Z-track and Airlock techniques concerning reducing pain in adult patients treated with Haloperidol decanoate. The primary outcome measure is pain reduction, assessed using a millimeter-scale visual analogic scale (VAS) to measure pain perceived by the patient 5 minutes after the treatment. The study will also measure drug leakage reduction, impact of the injection, overall patient satisfaction, and therapeutic alliance. The study will be conducted over 14 months, with a sample size of 50 patients per group.

This is a feasibility trial of preoperative 5-day hypofractionated radiotherapy for primary soft tissue sarcoma. The study will assess the feasibility of the 5-day HFRT regimen, the rate of favorable pathologic response, the rate of major wound complications, local control, acute toxicity, and 1-year late HFRT toxicity. The study will also explore the potential of SFRP2 as a predictive biomarker for favorable pathologic response.

This is a randomized controlled study to compare the effectiveness of pericapsular nerve group block (PENG block) combined with lateral femoral cutaneous nerve block (LFCN block) and patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) in providing postoperative analgesia after hip replacement surgery. The primary outcome measures are the average VAS score at rest and on movement, and the rate of side effects such as vomiting/nausea, itchy, urinary retention, and respiratory failure postoperative of both groups. The study will be conducted over a period of 72 hours, and the results will be analyzed to determine the effectiveness of PENG block and LFCN block in providing postoperative analgesia after hip replacement surgery.

The study aims to assess the pelvic organ mobility in patients with pelvic endometriosis using dynamic MRI. The study will compare the mobility of the pelvic organs in patients with endometriosis to those without endometriosis. The primary outcome measure will be the mean vertical displacement of the anterior, cervical, and posterior walls of the vagina during maximum pushing force. Secondary outcome measures will include the variation in mean vertical displacement on the walls of each pelvic organ and the association between symptoms and mean vertical displacement. The study will be conducted as a comparative study with patients with and without endometriosis.

This study aims to assess the uptake of the childhood live attenuated influenza vaccine (LAIV) and its impact on healthcare resource use in England during the 2012 to 2022 flu seasons. The study will use data from the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD) and Hospital Episode Statistics (HES) to describe the usage patterns of LAIV and outcomes associated with laboratory-confirmed influenza and/or influenza-like illness (ILI) in children aged 2 to <18 years. The study will estimate a DAG aligned model for LAIV uptake based on demographic and clinical factors for each flu season and across multiple seasons between 2012 and 2020.

This study aims to investigate the feasibility and effectiveness of a fun activity-based intervention to promote happiness and enjoyment in primary school ethnic minority students in Hong Kong. The intervention consists of three weekly sessions of Tang poem recitation and one performance session, led by experienced instructors from Bestreben Drama Association Limited. The primary outcome measures include the number of successfully recited poems, change in happiness, and change in acculturation. The study will be conducted as a pilot pre-post interventional trial with no controls.

This is a randomized controlled trial to assess the effectiveness of a digitally assisted risk reduction platform for youth at high risk for suicide. The platform, called Vira, uses mobile sensing data and HIPAA-compliant client communication tools to provide a unique understanding of risk factors, including psychological distress, anhedonia, and behavioral withdrawal, and sleep disturbance among high-risk individuals. The study will include 200 adolescent patients aged 13-18 years old randomized to either the Vira group or treatment as usual control group. The primary outcome measures will be the Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C-SSRS) and the Scale for Suicidal Ideation (SSI). Secondary outcome measures will include the Screen for Anxiety Related Emotional Disorders (SCARED), Risky Behavior Questionnaire for Adolescents (RBQ-A), Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), Mood and Feelings Questionnaire (MFQ), and Anticipatory & Consummatory Interpersonal Pleasure Scale (ACIPS). The study will assess the effectiveness of the Vira platform in reducing suicidal thoughts and behaviors, anxiety, risky behaviors, sleep disturbances, and improving mood and social engagement among high-risk youth.

This clinical trial aims to study the impact of non-visual light input on sleep and circadian rhythms in individuals of different ages and genders. The study will use pupillometry to measure pupil size in response to different light stimuli and saliva collection to assess melatonin levels. The study will be conducted on individuals aged 18-85 years old and will include both men and women. The primary outcome measures will be pupil size and melatonin levels. The study will be conducted as an open-label, single-group assignment, and will include 8 different order combinations of light stimuli.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a new parent training program for parents with ADHD, called Improving Parenting Skills Adult ADHD (IPSA). The program is designed to improve parental self-efficacy, reduce parental stress, and improve parenting skills. The study is a randomized controlled trial with a parallel group design, where participants are randomly assigned to either the IPSA group or a control group. The primary outcome measures include parental self-efficacy, parental stress, household disorganization, and child behavior problems. The study will also explore the feasibility of IPSA and assess its acceptability and potential harms.

The Substance Use and Health Risk Intervention (SUHRI) for Justice-involved Youth is a single-arm, open-label, technology-based intervention designed to address substance use and risky sex practices among justice-involved youth. The intervention consists of four individualized sessions administered on a tablet as a self-directed approach, with onsite proctor support. The primary outcome measures include problem recognition, decision making, intention to reduce personal risk, service initiation, substance use, and sexual/STI health risk. The study will assess the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy of SUHRI in reducing substance use and risky sex practices among justice-involved youth.

This is a phase II open-label, single-center, single-arm futility trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of daily remote ischemic conditioning (RIC) in patients with primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS). The primary endpoint is the timed 25-foot walk at 12 months follow-up. The study will follow the Simon-2-stage MiniMax design for futility studies.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the clinical trial.

The study aims to assess the correlation between prothrombin time at diagnosis and response to corticosteroid therapy in patients with severe alcoholic hepatitis. The primary outcome measure is the response to steroid treatment assessed with Lille score at day 7. Secondary outcome measures include death, early liver transplantation, and infection occurring during hospitalization. The study is a single-arm, observational study, and all patients with severe alcoholic hepatitis admitted to the hospital will be included.

The study aims to compare the effectiveness of functional task training and functional therapy program on gross motor function, range of motion, and balance in children with cerebral palsy. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with 2 groups receiving either functional task training or functional therapy program for 8 weeks. The primary outcome measures will be goniometer, pediatric balance scale, and gross motor function measure scale. The study will be conducted on children with cerebral palsy aged 6-12 years, with GMFCS score of 1-2, and without deformity, visual disorder, or mental retardation.

This study aimed to investigate the prognostic value of neutrophil-lymphocyte ratio (NLR), absolute lymphocyte count (ALC), and thrombocyte-lymphocyte ratio (TLR) in predicting the outcomes of tetralogy of Fallot (ToF) primary repair. The study was a retrospective observational study conducted at the National Cardiovascular Center Harapan Kita from January 2020 until December 2022. The study included patients with ToF who underwent primary repair and had a complete blood cell count with differential count available preoperatively. The primary outcome measures were the number of patients requiring redo surgery, mortality, and complications. The secondary outcome measures were hospital length of stay and postoperative length of stay. The study found that higher NLR and lower ALC were associated with increased risk of redo surgery, mortality, and complications. Higher TLR was associated with increased risk of complications. These findings suggest that NLR, ALC, and TLR may be useful in predicting the outcomes of ToF primary repair.

This study aims to assess the effectiveness of patient-applied aqueous lidocaine via tampon as a pre-treatment prior to intra-uterine device placement. Subjects will apply the lidocaine or a saline placebo to the end of a standard tampon with a plastic applicator and then place the tampon 1 hour prior to the procedure. The tampon will be removed as the subject prepares for the procedure. The procedure team will measure the procedure time as well as the subject and provider impressions of the procedure. This data will be evaluated to compare the lidocaine to the control group.

The study aims to assess the feasibility and acceptability of a universal capillary screening program for chronic autoimmune, metabolic, and cardiovascular diseases in a general population. The study will enroll participants from Cantalupo, a locality of 3095 inhabitants belonging to the Municipality of Cerro Maggiore (Milan). Participants will undergo capillary blood sampling to test blood glucose levels, glycated hemoglobin, total cholesterol, HDL-c, LDL-c, triglycerides, Glutamic Acid Decarboxylase (GADA), Insulinoma-Associated-2/Tyrosine Phosphatase (IA-2A), Insulin (IAA), Zinc Transporter-8 Autoantibodies (ZnT8A) for type I diabetes and tissue transglutaminase antibodies for celiac disease. The results of autoantibodies research for celiac disease and type 1 diabetes will be available within a few days. In case a participant screens positive for type I diabetes and/or celiac disease, they will be subsequently invited to undergo a new confirmatory blood draw on venous blood. Blood pressure will be also measured for each participant. The study will assess the feasibility and acceptability of the screening program, as well as the prevalence of the identified diseases within the population.

The SMaRT Mom study is an intervention study that aims to help breastfeeding mothers manage and reduce their smartphone use during breastfeeding. The study will be conducted with 30 healthy breastfeeding mothers, aged 20-40 years, who have been diagnosed with smartphone addiction. The study will be randomized, controlled, and parallel-group designed, with both intervention and control groups. The intervention group will receive the SMaRT Mom intervention, which includes a smartphone app that detects and alerts the mother when she is using her smartphone excessively during breastfeeding, and a set of guidelines for reducing smartphone use during breastfeeding. The control group will not receive any intervention. The study will measure the effectiveness of the SMaRT Mom intervention on reducing smartphone use during breastfeeding, and will also assess changes in infant temperament, maternal self-efficacy, and mother-infant interaction. The study will use a variety of methods to measure these outcomes, including surveys, questionnaires, and physiological measures such as heart rate variability and skin conductance.

This is a single-center, open, randomized, single-dose, completely repeated crossover bioequivalence study to evaluate the effects of the test/reference preparation, entacapone, levodopa, and carbidopa tablets (II) in the postprandial state in healthy adult subjects.

The study will be conducted in accordance with the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki and the relevant laws and regulations of the country. The study will be conducted at a single center, and the subjects will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: Group A (Test (T)-Reference (R)) or Group B (Reference (R)-Test (T)). Each subject will receive a single dose of the test or reference preparation, and the plasma concentration of the drug will be measured at multiple time points over a 10-hour period. The primary outcome measures will be the peak plasma concentration (Cmax) and the area under the plasma concentration-time curve (AUC0-t) of the drug.

The study will enroll 36 healthy subjects, and the subjects will be randomly assigned to the two groups using a randomization table. The washout period between doses will be at least 2 days. The subjects will be fasting for at least 10 hours before dosing. The study will be conducted in a single-center, open-label design, and the subjects will be closely monitored for adverse events throughout the study.

The results of this study will provide information on the bioequivalence of the test/reference preparation, entacapone, levodopa, and carbidopa tablets (II) in the postprandial state in healthy adult subjects. The study will also provide information on the safety and tolerability of the drug in this population.

This study aims to investigate the use of combined electroencephalography (EEG) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) at 7 Tesla to map brain anatomy and function in healthy participants and patients with essential tremor, psychosis, and epilepsy. The study will use structural MRI and functional MRI to obtain detailed images of the brain and its activity patterns. The primary outcome measures will include contrast-to-noise ratio between thalamic nuclei in 7T structural MRI and Pearson correlation between thalamocortical brain regions in 7T functional MRI. The study will also measure microstate duration in EEG acquired concurrently with 7T functional MRI. The study will be conducted as a single-center study with healthy participants and patients with essential tremor, psychosis, and epilepsy. The study will be designed as a within-subjects design, with each participant undergoing both EEG and MRI scans. The study will be conducted over one day, and the primary outcome measures will be collected on the same day. The study will publish the neuroimaging datasets in fully anonymized form in suitable public data repositories.

This study aims to assess the impact of weight loss on hepcidin levels and iron status in subjects with obesity and iron deficiency. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a red meat-free diet or a calorie-restricted diet with red meat. The primary outcome measures will include serum hepcidin concentration, serum iron concentration, and serum ferritin concentration. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in blood reticulocytes percentage, serum soluble transferrin receptor concentration, blood haemoglobin concentration, serum C-reactive protein concentration, serum leptin concentration, serum interleukin 6 concentration, serum lipopolysaccharides concentration, plasma malondialdehyde concentration, plasma trolox equivalents concentration, and changes in faecal microbiota composition. The study will also assess the impact of the interventions on body weight, fat mass percentage, waist circumference, lean mass percentage, and skeletal muscle mass percentage.

Please provide a concise summary of the study in 150-200 words.

The NIEM-O study is a clinical trial that aims to assess the effectiveness and safety of non-invasive electrophysiological monitoring in high-risk pregnancies. The study will compare the use of continuous eCTG monitoring with conventional intermittent CTG monitoring in pregnant women at the Obstetric High Care (OHC) of Máxima Medical Centre (MMC). The primary outcome measure is the incidence of perinatal mortality and major neonatal morbidity. Secondary outcome measures include incidence of maternal mortality, neonatal morbidity, patient satisfaction, and caregiver satisfaction. The study will enroll 1911 pregnant women and will be conducted over a period of 6 months.

This study aims to identify genetic susceptibility to severe infections, including but not limited to all types of viral, bacterial, and fungal infections. The study will use a homozygosity mapping approach on multiplex and/or consanguineous families to identify chromosomal regions associated with the disease. Candidate genes will be identified and validated as factors of susceptibility to infectious diseases. The study will include individuals who have previously suffered from severe infectious diseases and their relatives. The study will also include healthy volunteers. The primary outcome measures will be the identification of chromosomal regions associated with the disease and the validation of candidate genes as factors of susceptibility to infectious diseases. The study will use whole genome genotyping and high-throughput sequencing techniques. The study is expected to take approximately 10 years to complete.

This study aims to investigate the prevalence, type, and risk factors of urinary incontinence in married women and its effect on their quality of life. The study will be conducted among married women over the age of 18 in [City or Region]. The study will use a diagnostic test to determine the type and risk factors of UI and the Incontinence Quality of Life questionnaire to assess the effect of UI on the quality of life. The study will be conducted from October 2022 to July 2023.

This is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of two cellular orthobiological products, bone marrow aspirate concentrate (BMAC) and minimally manipulated adipose tissue (MM-AT), in the treatment of knee osteoarthritis (OA). The study will enroll 204 patients with symptomatic unilateral knee OA and randomly assign them to receive either BMAC or MM-AT infiltration into the knee joint. The primary outcome measure will be the Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC) pain subscale, assessed at 6 months follow-up. Secondary outcome measures will include the WOMAC index, Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), EuroQol Visual Analogue Scale (EQ-VAS), Tegner Activity Level Scale, objective parameters such as range of motion and circumferences, Patient Acceptable Symptom State (PASS), Minimally Clinical Important Difference (MCID), expectations about the effectiveness of the treatment, Kellgren-Lawrence score, and 3 Tesla Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Imaging (3T MRI). The study will also analyze circulating microRNAs. The results of this study will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of these two cellular orthobiological products in the treatment of knee OA and may help to establish a new standard of care for this condition.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled Phase III clinical study evaluating the efficacy and safety of CBD TPM capsules in adults for the reduction of insomnia severity. The study will be conducted in three arms: placebo comparator, 75mg CBD, and 150mg CBD. The primary outcome measures will be the mean change from study baseline of insomnia severity index (ISI) score at 8 weeks and mean change from study baseline in subject sleep efficiency (sSE) at 8 weeks. The study will be conducted over a period of 8 weeks.

The study aims to detect the prevalence and pattern of intestinal parasitic infection among cirrhotic patients in Sohag University Hospital. The study will be conducted on one hundred cirrhotic patients and one hundred non-cirrhotic patients with no comorbidity. The study will be randomized, open-label, and parallel-group design. The primary outcome measure will be the detection of prevalence and pattern of intestinal parasitic infection in cirrhotic patients and the difference between cirrhotic patients and non-cirrhotic patients with no comorbidity. The study will be conducted over a period of one year.

The REtinal Detachment Outcomes Study (REDOS) is a clinical trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of two different surgical techniques for treating rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (RRD): pars plana vitrectomy with or without scleral buckle, and with or without sulfur hexafluoride gas tamponade or perfluoropropane gas tamponade. The study will assess the primary outcome measure of single surgery anatomic success, as well as several secondary outcome measures, including pinhole visual acuity, best-corrected visual acuity, time to onset of RD recurrence, severity and number of complications, and quality of life questionnaire. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida and will include adult patients with rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.

This study aims to evaluate the differential effects of 0.25%, 0.5%, and 1% ropivacaine on the onset time and duration of ultrasound-guided ankle blocks in patients having forefoot surgery for anesthesia and postoperative analgesia. The primary outcome is the difference in the duration of the sensory blocks. The secondary outcomes are the difference in onset time of the sensory block, the postoperative pain scores, and the opioid consumption.

The study aims to investigate the effect of compression stockings on the complaints, well-being, and sleep quality of pregnant women with restless legs syndrome. The study will be conducted as a randomized, open-label, parallel-group clinical trial. Pregnant women with restless legs syndrome who are between 18 and 40 years old and are at least 27 weeks pregnant will be included in the study. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the compression stockings group or the placebo sock group. The primary outcome measures will be the RLS severity rating scale and the Pittsburgh sleep quality index. The study will be conducted for 21 days.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of home-based strength and Tai-chi exercise snacking for improving physical function in Taiwanese and British older adults. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 weeks, with participants randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the waitlist control group. The primary outcome measures will include changes in the Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) and secondary outcome measures will include balance function, strength function, agility function, flexibility, quality of life, and wellbeing. The study will also assess attitudes towards exercise and acceptability of the intervention.

This is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) designed to evaluate the effectiveness of pre-emptive caudal epidural analgesia with ropivacaine and dexamethasone in lumbosacral spine surgeries. The study will be conducted as a parallel-group, quadruple-masked, randomized controlled trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either caudal epidural injection with 0.25% ropivacaine 20 ml containing dexamethasone 8 mg (Group RD) or caudal epidural injection with 0.25% ropivacaine 20 ml (Group R). The primary outcome measures will be postoperative Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) scores at immediate, 4, 8, 12, and 24 hours postoperatively. Secondary outcome measures will include time to demand of first dose of supplemental (rescue) analgesic medication, and any complications and adverse drug reactions.

The study aims to determine the effect of nursing care based on Kolcaba's comfort theory on comfort, care satisfaction and sleep quality of intensive care patients. The study is a randomized controlled experimental study with a parallel assignment and double-blind design. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental or control group. The experimental group will receive nursing care based on Kolcaba's comfort theory, while the control group will receive standard care. The primary outcome measures will be evaluated using the General Comfort Scale, Comfort Behaviors Checklist, and Richard-Campbell Sleep Scale. The study will be conducted in the intensive care unit of a hospital.

The P-KIDs CARE Health Systems Intervention in Tanzania is a study that aims to improve the quality of care for injured children in Tanzania. The study will be conducted in two phases. In the first phase, the researchers will conduct formative research to inform the development of the intervention. In the second phase, the researchers will develop and pilot test the intervention in two study facilities. The intervention will include training on patient assessment and stabilization, and a decision support tool to assist with timely referral decisions. The study will measure the effectiveness of the intervention on mortality, time to definitive care, patient disposition, and patient morbidity. The study will be conducted in two study facilities in the Kilimanjaro Region of Tanzania and will enroll approximately 200 pediatric injury patients.

This is a preliminary study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of combining pelvic floor rehabilitation with postural re-education and spinal mobilization in women with stress urinary incontinence and chronic low back pain. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with 30 participants randomly assigned to either the experimental group (pelvic floor rehabilitation and postural re-education) or the control group (pelvic floor rehabilitation and spinal mobilization). The primary outcome measures will be the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Urinary Short Form (ICIQ-UI SF) and the Pain Visual Analogue Scale (VAS). Secondary outcome measures will include the Modified Oxford Scale (MOS). The study will be conducted over a period of 5 weeks, with assessments at baseline, after 5 weeks of treatment, and 1 month after the end of the training.

The study aims to develop a pharmacodynamic model for propofol in older adults, using frontal EEG as a pharmacodynamic parameter. The study will be conducted as an open-label, single-group assignment trial, and will enroll patients aged 65 years or older undergoing non-cardiac elective surgery requiring general anesthesia. The primary outcome measures will be performance error, median absolute performance error, median prediction error, time of loss of response, time of burst-suppression, and time of return of response. The study will compare the performance of the new pharmacodynamic model with the BIS index, and will assess the accuracy and bias of the predictions.

This is a randomized controlled trial to assess the non-inferiority of a very short course of antibiotics (1 day) compared to the standard course of antibiotics (4-7 days) in patients with acute cholangitis after endoscopic biliary drainage. The primary outcome measure is clinical cure rate by day 14 after ERCP without relapse by day 30. Secondary outcome measures include all-cause 90-day mortality, relapse of cholangitis within 90 days, rate of any other subsequent infection requiring antibiotic therapy within 90 days, rate of subsequent infections with MDR bacteria or Clostridioides difficile within 90 days, rate of other adverse drug events within 14 days, length of intensive care and hospital stay for the initial episode of cholangitis, quality of life and health utility at day 7, day 30 and day 90, and societal costs and cost-effectiveness/-utility at 90 days.

This is a randomized controlled trial to compare the effectiveness of conventional lung recruitment maneuver versus ultrasound-guided lung recruitment maneuver in morbidly obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery. The primary outcome measure is the change in lung ultrasound score at 2 hours post-induction. Secondary outcome measures include the incidence of atelectasis and intra-operative desaturation. The study will be conducted at the Anesthesiology Department in Tanta University Hospitals for one year, and will include 30 patients in each group.

This study aims to determine whether one-day irradiation (a single fraction) is non-inferior to fractionated radiotherapy over a three-month period in terms of pain relief for patients with heel spurs (HSS). The study will compare the effectiveness of different single fraction radiotherapy prescriptions and evaluate the need for reirradiation till 1 year after radiotherapy between fractionated vs. single fraction radiotherapy. Additionally, the study will compare the quality of life and VAS score at different time points between fractionated vs. single fraction radiotherapy and between different single fraction radiotherapy prescriptions. The study will also evaluate the individual parts of Calcaneodynia score and individual domains of quality of life.

Please provide a concise and accurate summary of the study in 150 words or less.

This is a randomized controlled trial comparing the clinical outcomes and efficacy of single versus double pyloromyotomy techniques for gastric per-oral endoscopic myotomy (G-POEM) in the treatment of gastroparesis. The study will be conducted as a parallel-group, open-label, randomized controlled trial. Participants with refractory and severe gastroparesis will be randomly assigned to receive either single or double pyloromyotomy G-POEM. The primary outcome measures will be clinical success at 3 months, 6 months, and 12 months follow-up, and gastroparesis cardinal symptom index (GCSI) score before and after GPOEM at 3, 6 months, and 12 months follow-up. Secondary outcome measures will include technical success rate, total procedure time for each method, adverse events, and recurrence of symptoms. The study will be conducted at a single center, and the sample size will be 40 participants per group. The study is expected to be completed within 2 years.

This is a single-arm, open-label study to assess the efficacy of Minayo Iron-rich Yeast Drink with SOD on female nutritional anemia, skin condition, and Qi-blood deficiency syndrome. The study will be conducted on 30 healthy female participants, aged 18-35, with hemoglobin concentration level below 110g/L. Participants will receive Minayo Yeast Drink Product, 385 pieces, 25ml/piece, each piece contains 13mg of iron, for 4 consecutive weeks. The primary outcome measures will be the change of serum ferritin level, hemoglobin concentration level, Superoxide Dismutase (SOD) concentration level, and Glutathione (GSH) concentration level. Secondary outcome measures will include the changes of lines/wrinkles on the face. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The RaDiCo-IDMet study is a national cohort study that aims to investigate the clinical, genetic, biological, and morphometric characteristics of patients with imprinting disorders (IDs) and their metabolic consequences. The study will also search for an association between the metabolic phenotype of IDs patients and their biological profile, determine the prevalence of metabolic abnormalities, estimate the risk for metabolic complications, and describe different therapeutic approaches. The study will enroll patients (adults and children) with a confirmed diagnosis of ID, regardless of the severity of the disease, and will follow them for an average of 10 years. The study will also analyze (epi)genetic mutations transmission in proband and relatives.

This is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effectiveness of unipolar and bipolar interlocking in the treatment of humeral shaft fractures in adults. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients with radiologically assessed bone healing at 12 months. The study will enroll 40 patients in each arm and will be conducted at a single center. The study will use questionnaires and scanner to assess the outcome.

The EPI-MINN study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to improve cognition and motivation in individuals with early psychosis. The study will compare the effectiveness of cognitive training plus personalized real-time intervention for motivational enhancement (PRIME) to treatment as usual in improving cognition, motivation, and quality of life in individuals with early psychosis. The study will also examine the impact of the intervention on functional outcomes and brain activity. The study is expected to provide valuable insights into the most effective treatments for early psychosis and may have important implications for the development of new interventions.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of using wearable fitness trackers in prehabilitation for patients with oesophago-gastric, hepatobiliary, and lung cancers. The primary outcome measures are the total number of minutes of moderate-intensity exercise and the volume of physical activity achieved over an 8-week period. Secondary outcome measures include weekly adherence, duration of exercise, intensity of exercise, and patient feedback on the use of heart rate trackers in a prehabilitation setting. The study will be conducted as a parallel-group randomized controlled trial, with participants randomized to either an exercise to a heart rate zone intervention or a control group exercise to a rating of perceived exertion.

The LA POPA trial is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effectiveness of two minimally invasive treatments for pilonidal disease: pit-picking surgery and pit-picking surgery with laser-assisted closure. The study will assess the success rate of treatment at 1 year and long-term follow-up, as well as other outcomes such as pain, patient-reported outcomes, wound healing, and recurrence rate. The study will be conducted at multiple centers in the Netherlands and will include patients aged 12 and older with primary pilonidal sinus disease.

This study aims to identify the sociodemographic and clinical characteristics of patients with substance use disorder who are admitted to the addiction management unit of Assiut University Hospital. The study will also assess the personality traits and patterns of substance abuse among these patients. The study will use a supportive psychotherapy intervention to help patients detox and rehabilitate. The study will measure the sociodemographic characteristics, personality traits, and patterns of substance abuse of the patients at admission and one week after admission.

This is a phase 2 single-arm study of immune checkpoint inhibitors and radioembolisation for previously untreated metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma. The primary outcome measures are best objective response and rate of abscopal effect. The secondary outcome measures are progression-free survival, overall survival, incidence of treatment-related side effects, local control rate, and distant control rate.

Please provide a concise summary of the study in 100 words or less.

Here is a summary of the study in 100 words or less:

This phase 2 single-arm study investigates the efficacy and safety of immune checkpoint inhibitors and radioembolisation for previously untreated metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma. The primary outcomes are best objective response and abscopal effect, with secondary outcomes including progression-free survival, overall survival, and incidence of treatment-related side effects.

This is a phase II study of neoadjuvant durvalumab and tremelimumab with gemcitabine and cisplatin in patients with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma that is borderline resectable/resectable but with high risk for recurrence. The primary outcome measure is the rate of conversion from unresectable to resectable tumor after 4 or 8 cycles of treatment. Secondary outcome measures include objective response rate, pathological complete response, overall survival, progression-free survival, rate of R0 resection, relapse-free survival, patient-reported outcomes decline, and event-free survival.

The study is an open-label, single-arm, multi-center study. All participants will receive neoadjuvant durvalumab and tremelimumab plus gemcitabine and cisplatin. If the tumor is evaluated to be resectable after cycle 4, the patient may proceed with surgical tumor resection. If the tumor is deemed unresectable after cycle 4, the patient will proceed with cycles 5-8 followed by reevaluation for surgical resection. The study will enroll approximately 24 participants.

The study is designed to assess the feasibility and efficacy of neoadjuvant durvalumab and tremelimumab with gemcitabine and cisplatin in patients with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma that is borderline resectable/resectable but with high risk for recurrence. The study will also evaluate the safety and tolerability of the treatment regimen.

This clinical trial aims to establish normal reference values for the structure and blood flow of the extremities of Chinese Han adults using high-frequency ultrasound. The study will measure the intima thickness and blood flow velocity of the dorsalis pedis artery and proper palmar digital artery. The study will also explore the influencing factors of the measurements. The study is a multi-center study in China and will include healthy volunteers.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of STERIFY GEL in the treatment of periodontitis following scaling and root planing. The study is a randomized, controlled, split-mouth trial, with 30 participants divided into two groups: the experimental group receiving STERIFY GEL and the control group receiving scaling and root planing only. The primary outcome measures include pocket depth, gingival recession, clinical attachment level, plaque index, bleeding index, furcations, and grade of mobility. The study will be conducted over 3 months, with assessments at pre-treatment, 1 month, 2 months, and 3 months. The study is being conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) in enhancing hippocampal neuroplasticity and improving memory recovery in veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and peritraumatic amnesia. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design, with 40 male veterans aged 25-60 years old, who will receive either HBOT alone or HBOT and hippocampal training. The primary outcome measures will be changes in memory gaps and time to inaccessible memory surfacing, while secondary outcome measures will include changes in brain activity, cognitive performance, and memory test results. The study will be conducted over a period of four months, with baseline and follow-up assessments.

The CuDOSIS trial is a clinical trial that aims to assess the diagnostic accuracy of 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT imaging for the diagnosis of cardiac sarcoidosis. The study will include patients with suspected or confirmed cardiac sarcoidosis, as well as patients with acute lymphocytic myocarditis, and a control group of patients with neuroendocrine tumors. The primary outcome measure will be the proportion of patients with tracer uptake in the heart on 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT in patients with verified cardiac sarcoidosis. Secondary outcome measures will include the 24-month rates of adverse outcomes, the proportion of patients with tracer uptake in the heart on 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT in patients with acute lymphocytic myocarditis, and the distribution of tracer uptake in the heart in patients with cardiac sarcoidosis and acute lymphocytic myocarditis, respectively.

This is a randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled, single-center pilot/exploratory trial to assess the effect of probiotics on immunosuppressive-drug-associated diarrhea among renal transplant recipients. Participants will receive either probiotics or placebo for six months, and the primary outcome measures will be reduction in immunosuppressive drugs-associated diarrhea, analysis of inflammatory biomarkers, and association between inflammatory markers and fecal microbiome. The study will enroll 20 participants per group, and data will be analyzed using chi-square test, general linear model analysis of variance (GLM ANOVA), and Pearson correlation analysis.

This is a randomized clinical trial to assess the efficacy of inhaled sedation with sevoflurane compared to current intravenous sedation practice for improving PaO2/FiO2 in ICU patients at high risk for ARDS. The study will be conducted in a single center, and will enroll 120 patients who are at least 18 years old, have a known risk factor for ARDS, and are undergoing invasive mechanical ventilation. Patients will be randomly assigned to receive either inhaled sedation with sevoflurane or intravenous sedation (current practice), and will be followed for 28 days. The primary outcome measure will be the evolution in PaO2/FiO2 ratio within 5 days from randomization. Secondary outcome measures will include progression to ARDS, rate of pneumonia, ventilator-free days to day 28, organ failure to day 5, mortality at day 28, length of ICU-stay up to 28 days, and physiological and hemodynamic measures.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the outcomes of different treatment modalities for massive rotator cuff tears. The study will include patients aged between 50 and 80 years who have a massive rotator cuff tear diagnosed on MRI and have not had previous rotator cuff surgery. The study will have three arms: arthroscopic rotator cuff partial repair with superior capsular augmentation using the long head of the biceps tendon (LHBBT), arthroscopic rotator cuff partial repair, and conservative treatment. The primary outcome measures will include change in shoulder strength, range of motion, and functional outcome according to the American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) score, Constant-Murley score (CMS), and Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) score. Secondary outcome measures will include integrity of surgically repaired rotator cuff tendons on MRI studies using Sugaya classification, change in quality of life, and change in kinesiophobia score. The study will be conducted at Tartu University Hospital Sports Traumatology Centre and will have a follow-up period of 6 months, 12 months, and 24 months.

The IRIS program is a single-arm, open-label clinical trial that aims to provide holistic care to individuals who inject drugs and present with injection-related infections. The program includes diagnosis and treatment of infections, substance use treatment, peer support, and care coordination/systems navigation. The primary outcome measures include the number of emergency department visits and hospital readmissions within 30 days of initial hospital admission or program enrolment. Secondary outcome measures include completion of intended treatment, number of hospital readmissions, number of emergency department visits, number of new initiations or continuation of substance use treatment, and mortality rates. The study will be conducted in Hamilton, Ontario, and will enroll individuals aged 16 or older who present with a confirmed or suspected injection-related infection and have a history of injection drug use within the past 3 months.

The study aims to compare the use of a mobile app for surveillance of adverse events following influenza immunization to a web-based platform. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the mobile app or web-based notification group. The primary outcome measures will include useability and adverse event reporting. The study will be conducted over a period of four months.

The study aims to investigate the effect of virtual reality on pain, anxiety and patient comfort during trigger point injection. The study will be conducted with a randomized controlled parallel design. The experimental group will be shown videos through virtual reality glasses during the procedure, while the control group will not use virtual reality glasses. The study will measure anxiety, comfort and pain levels before and after the procedure using the State Anxiety Scale, General Comfort Scale and Visual Analog Scale.

This study aims to investigate the effect of autonomic dysfunction on hemodynamic instability during per-oral endoscopic myotomy in achalasia patients. The study will be conducted as a prospective observational study, and patients will be divided into two groups based on the results of the heart rate variability test (HRV test) performed preoperatively: patients with autonomic dysfunction and patients with normal autonomic function. The primary outcome measure will be the wobble of systolic arterial pressure (SAP) during surgery, which will be calculated using the formula: performance error (PE) = (measured SAP - reference SAP) x 100/reference SAP. The study will be conducted at Gangnam Severance Hospital, and the inclusion criteria will be patients aged ≥ 19 years who are scheduled to undergo per-oral endoscopic myotomy. The exclusion criteria will be patients who are hemodynamically unstable before surgery, patients in whom preoperative HRV test cannot be conducted, pregnant women, and breastfeeding women.

The study aims to evaluate the use of virtual reality glasses during inhaler treatment in children. The study is a randomized controlled trial, and the participants are children aged 2-5 years who need inhaler treatment. The children are randomly assigned to one of three groups: VR audio-visual users with Roller Coasters, VR audio-visual users with Wild Dolphins, or those who do not use any additional equipment. The primary outcome measure is the change in pain scores, and the study will also evaluate the effectiveness of the treatment and the duration of crying. The study is conducted in the Pediatric Emergency Department of the Health Sciences University Haseki Training and Research Hospital.

The study aims to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and effect of a transdiagnostic psychological treatment for anxiety and depression in youth. The treatment is based on the Unified Protocol (UP-C/A) and is delivered in a group format to children and adolescents, with parent training coupled with the module the children are working on. The study will be conducted in two primary care locations, and the therapists will receive training and regular supervision in the method. The study will measure outcomes such as emotion regulation, anxiety and depression symptoms, quality of life, and treatment satisfaction. The study is a clinical open trial, and the participants will be recruited from routine primary care.

The PALISA study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to assess the effectiveness of skin conductance measurement in reducing pain and stress during less-invasive surfactant administration in preterm infants. The study will enroll 40 infants and will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in Luxembourg. The primary outcome measures will be the median peaks per second at prespecified time-points, adjusted for median peaks per second at baseline, and the median Neonatal Pain, Agitation and Sedation Scale (N-PASS) at prespecified time-points, adjusted for median N-PASS at baseline. Secondary outcome measures will include the absolute number of apneas, desaturations, bradycardia, arterial hypotension, and blunt surfactant reflux, as well as differences in heart-rate, oxygen saturation, and SpO2/FiO2-ratio between baseline and prespecified time-points. The study will also assess the incidence of LISA failure, intubation within 72 hours, air-leaks within 72 hours, and intraventricular hemorrhage at first ultrasound scan after 72 hours.

This is a feasibility cluster randomized controlled trial of a home-based depression care for older people delivered by lay providers in Nigeria. The study aims to assess the feasibility of the intervention and its acceptability to older adults with depression in a low-income setting. The intervention is a behavioral therapy called emhGAP-Age, which is adapted for older adults and delivered by lay providers. The study will enroll 120 participants, aged 60 years and older, who will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the active comparator group. The primary outcome measure will be depression remission, assessed using the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9) at six months post trial entry.

This is a clinical trial studying the effectiveness of using platelet-rich plasma (PRP) enriched collected autologous bone in ACL reconstruction to reduce the widening of the tibial tunnel. The study will be conducted on 107 patients and will assess the primary outcome of tunnel diameter change and secondary outcomes such as femoral tunnel diameter change, graft maturity, and bone healing. The study will be randomized and controlled, with patients receiving either the PRP-enriched bone graft or the standard ACL reconstruction technique. The study will be conducted over a period of 24 months, with follow-up assessments at 10 to 14 months post-surgery.

This is a pilot randomized controlled trial to assess the effectiveness of high flow oxygen in preoxygenation during rapid sequence induction in infants and small children. The study will be conducted on pediatric patients who are indicated for rapid sequence induction and will be randomized into three groups: face-mask preoxygenation, HFNOC preoxygenation, and HFNOC + face-mask preoxygenation. The primary outcome measures will be the incidence of desaturation under 90% and the incidence of manual ventilation during RSI. Secondary outcome measures will include time to desaturation under 90% and 80%, time needed for relaxation, time needed for intubation, time to reach oxygen saturation 100%, first intubation attempt success rate, number of intubation attempts to successful intubation, intubation conditions, and incidence of complications.
