The study aims to evaluate the effects of an acupuncture treatment protocol for nasal congestion in allergic rhinitis (AR) compared to azelastine nasal spray (Carelastin®). The study is a randomized, open-label, controlled, interventional, monocenter trial. The primary outcome measure is the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) to compare the effects of acupuncture and azelastine nasal spray on nasal congestion in AR after 6 weeks of treatments based on VAS score. The study will also assess the effects of acupuncture on other nasal and ocular signs and symptoms in AR, general health, concentration, and energy level in AR, and equalization of middle ear pressure in AR in the case patients fly and/or dive.

The study aims to assess the feasibility of a clinical trial to target the maternal gut microbiome to improve mental health outcomes in pregnant women with a history of anxiety and/or depression. The study will randomize 250 participants to one of four study groups: Gutopia, Gutboost, Gutless, or Gutnone. The primary outcome measures will be the feasibility of participant recruitment and adherence to supplement intake. Secondary outcome measures will include obstacles to study completion, adherence to dietary protocol, and completion of study visits. The study will be conducted virtually, unless participants need in-person follow-ups.

This is a retrospective study of high dose follitropin delta in a mixed protocol with human chorionic gonadotropin. The study is designed to evaluate the effectiveness of follitropin delta in improving the outcomes of in vitro fertilization (IVF) cycles. The study will include women aged 18-42 years undergoing IVF/ICSI cycle IVF antagonist protocol. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either follitropin delta + hCG or follitropin delta + HP-hMG. The primary outcome measure will be the number of good quality blastocysts.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of telemedicine in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The study will be conducted in two stages. In the first stage, 60 patients with IBD will be randomly assigned to either a telemedicine intervention group or an observation group. In the second stage, both groups will be re-hospitalized six months after randomization to evaluate IBD activity. The primary outcome measures will be the change in quality of life in IBD measured by SIBDQ and WHOQOL-26, and the maintenance/achievement of clinical remission of Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis. Secondary outcome measures will include maintaining/achieving endoscopic and histological remission of IBD, change in the number of adverse drug reactions, change in patient satisfaction with treatment, and change in psychological well-being. The study will be conducted over a period of one year, with the first six months dedicated to the intervention and the remaining six months dedicated to follow-up.

The SAUNA trial is a randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment, multi-center study to assess the efficacy and safety of continuing somatostatin analogues (SSAs) upon progression in patients with gastroenteropancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (GEP NETs). Participants will be randomly assigned to either continue or withdraw SSA treatment for 18 months. The primary outcome measures are progression-free survival (PFS) and time to deterioration (TTD), and the secondary outcome measures include overall survival (OS), response rates (RR), quality of life (QoL), and cost-effectiveness. The study will be conducted at multiple sites in France and will enroll approximately 120 participants.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of a peer-mediated intervention for children with language impairment in preschool classrooms. The intervention involves training peers to play with the target child during center time, and the primary outcome measures include language skills, social skills, and behavior. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design, with 12 classrooms assigned to the treatment condition and 13 to the control condition. The study will be conducted over a period of 9 months, with assessments at baseline, 3 months, and 9 months.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the study, highlighting the key aspects of the trial, including the population, intervention, and outcomes.

This study aims to test the effectiveness of combining dalfampridine with physical therapy in improving mobility in people with multiple sclerosis. The study will randomly assign participants to one of three groups: dalfampridine only, physical therapy only, or a combination of both. The primary outcome measure will be the change in timed 25-foot walk from baseline to the end of treatment. The study will also explore secondary and tertiary outcomes, such as functional connectivity, clinical and personal factors associated with treatment responsiveness, and disease progression trajectories.

The study aims to assess the test-retest reliability, responsiveness and interpretability of CLEFT-Q, a questionnaire on health-related quality of life specific to patients with cleft lip and palate. The study will include 50 patients who will answer the questionnaire twice with a 1-2 week interval between the two administrations. Additionally, 50 patients will answer the questionnaire before and after secondary surgery of the nose, lips, jaw or to improve speech. The study will also include 20 healthcare professionals who will be interviewed about their experiences with CLEFT-Q. The primary outcome measures will be the change scores of CLEFT-Q and the secondary outcome measures will include photographs and recordings of speech.

This study aims to compare the effectiveness of core stabilization and dynamic stretching exercises in reducing the intensity, frequency, duration and severity of pain in primary dysmenorrhea. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial and will recruit nulliparous women aged 18-25 years who are experiencing primary dysmenorrhea. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a stretching exercise group or a dynamic core stabilizing exercise group and will receive 8 weeks of exercises, 3 days per week. The primary outcome measures will be the WaLIDD score, side bridge test, McGill quality of life questionnaire and PFSD scale, which will be assessed at baseline and 8 weeks.

This study aims to measure non-invasively, easily, and reliably the variations of cerebral perfusion in patients with or without cardiovascular risk factors during controlled variations performed during routine care to adjust the blood pressure level within the recommended safety standards during general anesthesia. The main objective is to identify a significant linear relationship between the percentage change in mean velocity (Vm) and the percentage change in the 95% spectral frequency front (SEF95) during the MAP change.

The study aims to assess the feasibility and acceptability of the PediQUEST Response to Pain of Children with Severe Neurologic Impairment (PQ-ResPOND) intervention in children with severe neurologic impairment. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention in reducing pain and symptom burden in children with severe neurologic impairment and symptom burden impairment and pain and symptom burden impairment and pain and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impairment and symptom burden impair and symptom burden impair and symptom burden impair and symptom burden impair and symptom burden and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and symptom and sympt the and sympt the and.

This is an observational study that aims to assess the effectiveness and safety of first-line Serplulimab plus chemotherapy in treating extensive small cell lung cancer. The study will enroll 30 participants and will be conducted at one center in China. Participants will receive 6 cycles of first-line Serplulimab plus chemotherapy, and MRD testing will be performed before treatment, after 2 cycles of treatment, after 6 cycles of treatment, 6 months after the end of chemotherapy, and 1 year after the end of chemotherapy. The primary outcome measure will be progression-free survival, and secondary outcome measures will include overall survival, objective response rate, and disease-control rate. The study will be conducted over a period of one year.

The Aktivplan Digital Intervention is a clinical pilot study that aims to assess the effectiveness of a digital intervention for supporting regular heart-healthy levels of physical activity following completion of a phase II rehabilitation program. The study will be conducted with patients who have completed a phase II rehabilitation program and will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, which will receive the Aktivplan digital intervention, or the control group, which will receive usual care. The primary outcome measures will include recruitment rate, drop-out rate, data completeness, adherence to the intervention, usability of the intervention, user experience of the intervention, user acceptance of the intervention, technical stability of the intervention, and use of alternative and additional strategies for supporting physical activity. Secondary outcome measures will include exercise capacity, physical activity behavior, weight, blood pressure, blood cholesterol, HbA1c, smoking, health-related quality of life, exercise self-efficacy, and patient safety. The study will be conducted over a period of 10 weeks, and the results will be analyzed to determine the effectiveness of the Aktivplan Digital Intervention.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, cross-over study to evaluate the effectiveness of intranasal oxytocin in improving social and repetitive behaviors in youth with autism spectrum disorder. Participants will receive either oxytocin or placebo twice daily for four weeks, and will be assessed using a variety of measures, including the Social Responsiveness Scale-Second Edition, the Repetitive Behavior Scale-Revised, the Behavioral inflexibility scale, a computerized Emotional body language task, a computerised probabilistic reversal learning task, and electrocardiogram. The primary outcome measures will be social behavior and repetitive behavior, and the study will also assess behavioral inflexibility, social cognition, and vagally-mediated heart rate variability.

This study aims to create and validate a clinical evaluation scale for the abdominal condition of premature babies. The scale, called ECAP, will be used to assess the abdominal condition of premature babies and to determine the effectiveness of abdominal massage in improving their condition. The study will include premature babies born at least 3 days ago and will be conducted in the neonatal intensive care units of the Clermont-Ferrand hospital center. The babies will be evaluated daily by nurses, physiotherapists, and residents using the ECAP scale. The study will also assess the validity of the ECAP scale and the impact of abdominal massage on the babies' condition.

This randomized controlled trial aims to assess the effectiveness of Empowered Relief (ER) delivered by ASPMN nurses in reducing pain catastrophizing and improving pain intensity in adults with persistent pain. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the ER group or the wait-list control group. The ER group will receive a 2-hour Zoom ER class delivered by an ER-trained ASPMN nurse, while the wait-list control group will continue their usual pain care for 2 months and then receive the ER class. The primary outcome measures will be change in pain catastrophizing and pain intensity, assessed at baseline, 2, 4, and 8 weeks. The study will also collect data on demographics and health variables, as well as participants' experience of the ER class and any barriers encountered.

This study aims to investigate the mental effort and confidence in the accuracy of pain intensity ratings in patients and nurses. The study will compare the mental effort of choosing and understanding different pain intensity rating scales, and the confidence in the accuracy of fictional pain intensity rating patterns. The results will inform future efforts to improve pain communication between patients and nurses.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) for the treatment of poor graft function after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-HSCT). The study is an open-label, single-group assignment design, and will enroll patients who have undergone allo-HSCT and have poor graft function. The primary outcome measure is the hemogram recovery of patients, and secondary outcome measures include infection rate, graft-versus-host disease, and survival rate. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The MOVIN' CARE for PD study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effectiveness of two mind-body interventions, yoga, and arts-based approaches, in improving the psycho-social-spiritual well-being among PD patients. The study will be conducted among adults diagnosed with mild to advanced PD in Hong Kong. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the yoga intervention, the arts-based intervention, or a wait-list control group. The primary outcome measures will include change of perceived stress level, overall quality of life, and PD-related symptoms. Secondary outcome measures will include change of self-compassion, self-efficacy, perceived social support, constipation severity, bowel habits, and gut microbiota composition. The study will be conducted over a period of 9 months, with follow-up assessments at 3, 6, and 9 months.

Please note that this is a summary of the study and not the actual study document.

This is a randomized controlled trial of an integrated digital intervention for adults with alcohol use disorder. The intervention is a mobile health application that provides cognitive-behavioral therapy and pharmacotherapy for alcohol use disorder. The study will compare the effectiveness of the intervention with usual care for adults with alcohol use disorder. The primary outcome measure is change in past 30-day alcohol use from baseline to 6 months post-treatment entry.

This study aims to compare the clinical pregnancy rate of embryo transfer in natural vs substituted cycles. The study will be conducted at Clinique OVO and will include women aged < 40 years old who have undergone either a frozen embryo transfer in natural cycle or substituted cycle IVF and FET cycles. The study will evaluate the clinical pregnancy rate of embryo transfer in natural vs substituted cycles. The primary outcome measure will be the clinical pregnancy rate, which will be measured at 6 to 8 weeks after Frozen Embryo Transfer.

This study aims to compare the effects of inhalational anesthesia (sevoflurane) and intravenous anesthesia (propofol) on the incidence of postoperative delirium, postoperative cognitive dysfunction, and postoperative functional decline in older adults undergoing non-cardiac surgery. The study will also assess the effects of the two anesthesia techniques on levels of blood phosphorylated tau 181 (p-tau181) and patient-reported outcomes (PROs). The study is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either inhalational anesthesia (sevoflurane) or intravenous anesthesia (propofol) during surgery. The primary outcome measures will include the incidence of postoperative delirium and postoperative cognitive dysfunction, as well as changes in levels of p-tau181 and PROs. The study will be conducted at Oregon Health & Science University.

The study aims to assess the nutritional status of children with congenital heart disease and to adopt a protocol to avoid nutritional deficiency and achieve the normal growth in children with congenital heart disease. The study will be conducted on children aged between 5 weeks to 18 years who are diagnosed with cyanotic and acyanotic congenital heart disease. The study will exclude children with comorbidities such as severe sepsis, endocarditis, empyema, autoimmune diseases, liver cirrhosis, and children receiving immunosuppressive therapy. The study will measure the nutritional status of the children using anthropometric measures such as weight, height, length, head circumference, and mid-arm circumference. The primary outcome measure of the study is to assess the nutritional status of the children with congenital heart disease.

This is a randomized controlled trial of surgical resection of glioblastoma with pH sensitive amine CEST-EPI. Patients will be enrolled by the UCLA Ronald Reagan Medical Center. The investigators will recruit patients with imaging consistent with WHO grade IV glioblastoma. The primary endpoint will be progression free survival and secondary endpoints will be overall survival, surgical complication rate, and quality of life differences as measured by pre- and post-operative karnofsky performance scale scores.

This study aims to investigate the patterns of urinary bladder cancer in Darfur, Sudan, with a focus on understanding the clinical outcomes, etiology, histology, and demographic distribution of the disease. The study is a cross-sectional, hospital-based study conducted at Nyala Specialized Hospital in Darfur, from 2020 to 2022. The study includes all Sudanese patients who live in Darfur and presented with urinary bladder mass, aged above 18 years. The exclusion criteria include patients who do not live in Darfur and those who refused to participate in the study. The primary outcome measures include the patterns of urinary bladder cancer in Darfur, Sudan, with a focus on understanding the clinical outcomes, etiology, histology, and demographic distribution of the disease.

This study aims to investigate the relationship between mental stress and bowel preparation quality in patients undergoing colonoscopy. The study will enroll 1000 patients and will use the Boston Bowel Preparation Scale (BPS) to assess the quality of bowel preparation. The study will also collect information on the patients' physical and mental stress levels using a questionnaire. The primary outcome measure will be the quality of bowel preparation, which will be assessed during colonoscopy.
