The proposed project will evaluate the efficacy of the SkillFlix for Parents online video library in improving the sexual health communication skills of parents of teens with autism spectrum disorder. The study will be a randomized controlled trial of dyads with pre- and post-assessment, and a 3-month follow-up assessment. The primary outcome measures will be the demonstrated skill score in communicating with their teens about sexual health and the parent reported frequency of discussions with their teens about sexual health and relationships. Secondary outcome measures will include parent conversation quality score, parent confidence in their ability to use skills in communication with their teen, teen reported frequency of discussions with their teens about sexual health and relationships, teen conversation quality score, teen confidence in their ability to use Making Connections skills, family sex communication quotient score, teen's sexual health knowledge, teen's sexual health attitudes, and teen's sexual health behaviors.

This study aims to investigate the role of DDX17 in regulating vascular endothelial pyroptosis in sepsis patients. The study will enroll 30 patients with sepsis or septic shock and will measure the plasma levels of DDX17 and GSDMD, as well as assess the correlation between these proteins and the severity and prognosis of the disease. The primary outcome measure will be 28-day mortality, and the study will also assess the correlation between the plasma levels of DDX17 and GSDMD and the severity and prognosis of the disease.

This is a single-center prospective study of non-invasive methods for the diagnosis of postoperative complications in liver transplant recipients. The study will assess the effectiveness of early allograft dysfunction (EAD) in predicting postoperative complications in liver transplant recipients. The primary outcome measures will include the Olthoff criteria and the levels of bilirubin, INR, ALT, and AST in the first 7 days after liver transplantation. The study will enroll patients who are eligible for liver transplantation and exclude those who have a history of previous liver transplantation, are unable to give informed consent, or have fulminant hepatitis. The study will be conducted at a single center and will have a duration of 2 weeks from liver transplantation.

This is a multi-center, phase II, randomized, controlled clinical trial to test the safety and efficacy of Elemene plus Stupp Protocol compared with Stupp Protocol alone for newly-diagnosed glioblastoma (ndGBM) patients. The primary outcome measure is the 12-month overall survival (OS) rate. Secondary outcome measures include the OS, progression-free survival (PFS), and adverse events.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the clinical trial.

This study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to assess the effects of prone positioning on lung recruitability in infants and children with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The study will be conducted in a pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) and will include patients who meet the inclusion criteria and have a PaO2/FiO2 ratio ≤ 200 mmHg. The study will be conducted in a 2x2 cross-over design, with each patient undergoing both the supine and prone positioning protocols. The primary outcome measure will be the effect of prone positioning on lung recruitability, as measured by the PaO2/FiO2 ratio. Secondary outcome measures will include differences in gas exchanges, ventilatory ratio, global impedance-derived End-expiratory lung volume, regional impedance-derived End-expiratory lung volume, tidal volume distribution, global impedance-derived lung dynamic strain, regional impedance-derived lung dynamic strain, and safety endpoints such as the number of displacements of the endotracheal tube during prone position and the number of oxygen desaturations during prone position.

The study aims to investigate the effects of progressive relaxation training on pain characteristics, attack frequency, activity self-efficacy perception, and social participation in women with tension-type headache and migraine. The study will be conducted with 22 women in each group, and the intervention will be administered for 6 weeks. The primary outcome measures will include occupational self-assessment, World Health Organization disability assessment schedule 2, pain catastrophizing scale, headache impact test-6, and visual analog scale. The study will be conducted in a well-lit, clean, and comfortable room with a temperature of 22-24 degrees. The women will be instructed to stop eating and wear comfortable clothes at least two hours before the sessions. The sessions will be held twice a week for 30 minutes each over 6 weeks. The study will assess the effects of progressive relaxation training on pain intensity, frequency, and disability in women with tension-type headache and migraine.

The study aims to investigate the use of microRNA biomarkers for the diagnosis and management of neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome (NOWS). The study will enroll infants exposed to in utero opiates and measure the levels of specific microRNAs in their saliva. The primary outcome measures will include neurodevelopmental outcome scores, the maximum concentration of morphine required for withdrawal symptom control, and the levels of specific microRNAs in saliva. The study will also explore the use of exosomes as a potential source of microRNAs for diagnostic purposes.

The study aims to investigate the effect of patient education on pain level and fear of pain in orthopedics and traumatology patients. The study is a randomized controlled experimental research design. The participants were randomly assigned to either the intervention or control group. The intervention group received patient education on pain management, while the control group did not receive any education. The primary outcome measures were pain level and fear of pain, which were assessed using a Visual/Visual Analogue Scale and the Fear of Pain Scale-III, respectively. The study found that the intervention group had lower pain levels and lower fear of pain compared to the control group. The results suggest that patient education on pain management is effective in reducing pain and fear of pain in orthopedics and traumatology patients.

The Patch BRIDGE trial is a randomized controlled trial that aims to assess the efficacy and safety of using a transdermal buprenorphine patch for induction of buprenorphine treatment during pregnancy. The study will enroll pregnant women with opioid use disorder and randomly assign them to receive either the transdermal buprenorphine patch or a sham patch. The primary outcome measure will be the severity of withdrawal symptoms during the induction phase, and secondary outcome measures will include induction success, treatment adherence, and recovery success. The study will be conducted at a single center and will enroll approximately 40 participants.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of transcutaneous oximetry in the diagnosis of vascular compression in patients suspected of having thoracic outlet syndrome. The primary outcome measure is the variation in upper limb ischemia estimated by TcpO2 measurement and calculating of the DROPmin. The study will enroll patients who have undergone additional examinations as part of their diagnostic assessment, including venous and arterial Doppler or dynamic arteriography and venography. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The SmartCP study is a feasibility study to determine if a mobile health app for symptom monitoring in people with chronic pancreatitis is feasible, complementing current specialist clinical care. The app is designed to assist patients in the management of their symptoms, improve their quality of life, and reduce the need for hospitalizations. The study will run for 16 weeks and will include a single-arm, unblinded, feasibility study design with an embedded quantitative and qualitative process evaluation. The primary outcome measures will include feasibility, acceptability, retention, incidents, user statistics, and secondary outcome measures will include the occurrence of crisis events, symptoms, quality of life, hospitalization, and use of communications and educational features.

This is a retrospective cross-sectional study that aims to investigate the incidence of anal fissure among COVID-19 survivors, and to identify the risk factors associated with its development. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months, and will include patients who were discharged home safely after receiving treatment for COVID-19 infection. The primary outcome measure will be the incidence of anal fissure among COVID-19 survivors, and the secondary outcome measures will include the risk factors associated with its development.

This study aims to assess the effects of platelet-rich fibrin (PRF) on wound healing following palatal connective tissue harvesting. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with 20 patients in each arm (test and control). The test group will receive PRF treatment, while the control group will not. The primary outcome measures will be tissue thickness and pulsatility index, which will be evaluated using ultrasonography. The study will be conducted over a period of 90 days, with follow-up evaluations at days 3, 7, 14, 21, and 30.

The ARRC III trial is a pilot registry study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of the Advanced Recovery Room Care (ARRC) model of care at the Royal Adelaide Hospital (RAH). The study will compare the outcomes of patients receiving ARRC care with those receiving usual ward care. The primary outcome measure is the number of days spent at home within 90 days after surgery, and secondary outcome measures include in-hospital complications, mortality, and cost-effectiveness. The study will be conducted at the RAH and will include patients undergoing elective or unplanned surgery who are scheduled to stay in the hospital for at least one night after surgery. The study will exclude patients undergoing cardiac surgery and those scheduled for postoperative Intensive Care Unit management.

This is a Phase 3b, open-label, hybrid type 2 study with co-primary aims of effective use and implementation. The study will evaluate the effectiveness and implementation of CAB-LA as a PrEP option in men who are mobile for work in South Africa and Uganda with a high burden of HIV. The study will be conducted in two countries, South Africa and Uganda. The study will recruit 400 participants who will be randomized into two groups: Group A will receive oral TDF-FTC PrEP (using either event-driven or daily) and Group B will receive CAB-LA over 9-months. After 9-months, participants from both groups will be offered a choice of PrEP for a further 9-months, with the ability to change choice as required. The study will assess the effectiveness and implementation of CAB-LA as a PrEP option in men who are mobile for work in South Africa and Uganda.

The study aims to assess the psycho-emotional state of patients with TMD. The study will be conducted on 130 patients diagnosed with TMD and 130 patients without TMD as a control group. The primary outcome measures will be assessed using a questionnaire survey that will be administered to the participants. The questionnaire will assess the emotional state of the participants over the past 4 weeks, including lowered mood, emotional irritability, sadness, lack of desire for daily activities, lack of concentration, self-isolation, and critical thoughts. The results will be divided into four sections; A, B, C, and D. The study will be conducted from 2021 to 2023.

This study aims to investigate the effects of touch on brain connectivity and metabolic biomarkers in preterm infants. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with participants receiving either therapeutic touch, affective touch, or static touch. The primary outcome measures will be changes in brain activity and metabolic biomarkers, and the study will also assess changes in EEG power and urinary metabolites. The study will be conducted over a period of 40 weeks, with assessments at baseline, 1 hour, 10 days, 4 days, 8 days, 12 days, and 40 weeks.

This is a non-myeloablative conditioning regimen for patients with sickle cell disease, including compromised organ function. The study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of the regimen and will include a total of 20 participants. The primary outcome measure will be the success rate of the regimen, defined as successful engraftment and absence of acute grade 3 or higher GVHD or moderate to severe chronic GVHD evaluated at 1 year post-transplant. Secondary outcome measures will include event-free survival and overall survival, viral reactivation and disease, and autoimmune and hyperinflammatory complications.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of two different sperm preparation methods, microfluidic chip and density gradient centrifugation, on the euploidy rate of pre-implantation genetic testing in women undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF). The study will randomly assign eligible women to one of the two groups and compare the euploidy rate of blastocysts between the two groups. The primary outcome measure is the euploid rate of blastocysts, and secondary outcome measures include live birth rate, positive urine pregnancy test rate, clinical pregnancy rate, ongoing pregnancy rate, miscarriage rate, multiple pregnancy rate, and DNA fragmentation. The study will be conducted over three years, and the results will provide valuable information on the effectiveness of the two sperm preparation methods in improving IVF outcomes.

This study aims to investigate the relationship between BDNF gene single nucleotide polymorphism and nerve growth factor serum level as risk factors for the severity of allergic rhinitis. The study will be conducted on 50 patients with chronic allergic rhinitis who will undergo genotyping and blood sampling for the measurement of BDNF, NGF, IL-1, and C-reactive protein levels. The primary outcome measures will be the levels of these biomarkers in the blood, and the study will have a duration of two months.

This study aims to investigate the effect of mindfulness-based intervention on EEG brain activity, cognitive, and psychological well-being in healthy elderly individuals. The study will be conducted as a single-group, open-label design, with 8 weekly group sessions of mindfulness-based intervention. The primary outcome measures will be change from baseline in dispositional mindfulness, verbal memory, and interoceptive mindfulness, and change in EEG alpha power. The study will enroll 60 community-dwelling older adults, aged 60-75 years, with normal cognition and no history of depression, anxiety, or major neurological or psychiatric disorders.

The study aims to determine the prevalence of Mycoplasma Genitalium (MG) infection and associated antimicrobial resistance among HIV-infected male in Hong Kong. The study will also assess the prevalence of other sexually transmitted infections (STIs) such as Chlamydia trachomatis (CT) and Neisseria Gonorrhoeae (NG) among the participants. The study will use self-sampling kits for STI testing in the laboratory. The primary outcome measures will be the prevalence of MG infection and MG resistance mutations, while the secondary outcome measures will include the prevalence of other STIs and demographic information.

This is an open-label, parallel-assignment, randomized controlled study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the combination of Dalpiciclib with physician-selected endocrine therapy in patients with HR-positive and HER2-negative recurrent/metastatic breast cancer who have failed previous CDK4/6 inhibitor treatment. The primary endpoint is investigator-assessed progression-free survival (PFS). Secondary endpoints include objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), and overall survival (OS).

The study population consists of patients with HR-positive and HER2-negative recurrent/metastatic breast cancer who have failed previous CDK4/6 inhibitor treatment. Patients will be randomly assigned to receive either the combination of Dalpiciclib with physician-selected endocrine therapy or chemotherapy selected by the physician. The study will be conducted at multiple sites in China.

The study will be conducted in two phases. The first phase will involve screening and enrollment of patients, and the second phase will involve treatment and follow-up. The study is expected to be completed within approximately 24 months.

The primary outcome measure is investigator-assessed PFS, which will be measured using RECIST v1.1. Secondary outcome measures include ORR, DCR, and OS. Safety will also be evaluated throughout the study.

The study will be conducted in accordance with the International Conference on Harmonisation (ICH) Good Clinical Practice (GCP) guidelines and the Declaration of Helsinki. The study protocol has been approved by the institutional review board (IRB) at each participating site.

Patients who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria will be randomly assigned to receive either the combination of Dalpiciclib with physician-selected endocrine therapy or chemotherapy selected by the physician. The study will be conducted at multiple sites in China.

The primary outcome measure is investigator-assessed PFS, which will be measured using RECIST v1.1. Secondary outcome measures include ORR, DCR, and OS. Safety will also be evaluated throughout the study.

The study will be conducted in accordance with the International Conference on Harmonisation (ICH)

This is a single-arm, open-label, multicenter study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of XELOX combined with Fruquintinib and Sintilimab regimen conversion therapy in patients with gastric cancer/gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma only with liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis. The primary endpoint is progression-free survival (PFS), and the secondary endpoints include overall survival (OS), objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), duration of response (DOR), translational rate, and adverse events (AEs).

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of alternative incentives to encourage physical activity among older adults. The investigators will randomly assign participants to either receive additional prosocial and personal incentives for their walking behavior or not receive these incentives. The primary outcome measure will be change in step count over an 8-week period, and the study will also collect data on physical and mental health. The study will be conducted among 200 older adults in San Diego, California, and will use Fitbits and Fitabase software to track step count and collect data.

This is a clinical trial conducted at the Moi Teaching and Referral Hospital in Kenya to evaluate the effectiveness of a wireless vital sign monitor (neoGuard) in detecting abnormal physiological signals and providing alerts/alarms to nurses to check on newborn patients' status. The study will be conducted in two arms: an intervention group where the neoGuard device will be used, and a comparison group where standard-of-care vital sign monitoring will be used. The primary outcome measures will include nurse's response time to patients in distress, percentage of actionable alarms, incidence of patient complications, in-hospital mortality, and frequency of key interventions. The study will run for 16 months, and user experience and perceptions on feasibility and sustainability will be captured through user surveys at the end of the intervention period.

This is a Phase II study to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of hypofractionated radiation therapy in aged (≥ 70 years old) or fragile (≥ 65 years) patients with limb or trunk soft tissue sarcoma. The study will be conducted in two cohorts: a neo-adjuvant cohort and an adjuvant cohort. Patients in the neo-adjuvant cohort will receive hypofractionated radiation therapy prior to surgery, while patients in the adjuvant cohort will undergo surgery before receiving the adjuvant hypofractionated radiation therapy. The primary outcome measure is the rate of patients free of major surgical complications within 6 months of surgery. Secondary outcome measures include disease-free survival, surgical complications, wound disorders, healing time, quality of life, patient autonomy, geriatric parameters, and toxicities of the radiation therapy.

This study aims to determine the clinicopathological profile of head and neck cancers in Army Hospital of Nepal. The study is a retrospective analysis of medical records of patients diagnosed with head and neck cancer between May 2022 and April 2023. The study will analyze the age-wise distribution of head and neck cancers, the distribution of cancers according to the subsite, histopathology, TNM staging, and treatment modalities. The study will use SPSS version 22 for data analysis and p-value <0.05 will be considered statistically significant.

This study aims to determine whether a health communication message, designed to educate and activate parents about their child's risk for OSA, can increase the number of children with OSA symptoms who receive a referral for further evaluation and possible treatment. The message is an infographic that helps parents recognize nighttime symptoms of OSA and how these nighttime symptoms may be impacting their child during the day. Parents will be randomized to either view the health communication message or usual care before their child's primary care visit. The primary outcome measure is the rate of completed OSA referral. Secondary outcome measures include the rate of OSA referral, rate of evidence-based evaluation, rate of OSA diagnosis, and rate of OSA treatment. The study will also assess parent activation, which is the rate of parents who report planning to speak with their child's provider about OSA after viewing the health communication message.

The study is a multi-country, prospective, post-marketing study of upadacitinib evaluating the speed of onset and durability of effectiveness for patients with moderate to severe Crohn's disease for 3 years in real-world clinical practice. Participants will receive upadacitinib as prescribed by their physician according to local label. The study will measure the time to achieve first clinical response and the percentage of participants achieving clinical remission at the end of induction therapy.

The study is designed to assess the effectiveness of an online version of the QAPS in measuring prewriting skills in children aged 3-7 years old. The study will be conducted online and will include a demographics survey, emotionality assessment, strengths and difficulties questionnaire, and ego resiliency scale. The primary outcome measures will be the online QAPS, Beery VMI, functional hand tasks, and the demographics survey. The study will be conducted over a period of 5-10 minutes.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of the Critical Time Intervention-Peer Support (CTI-PS) model for individuals with serious mental illness discharged from inpatient psychiatric treatment facilities in Portugal. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention or control group. The intervention group will receive CTI-PS services for 9 months, while the control group will receive usual care. The primary outcome measures will include the WHOQOL-BREF and the Camberwell Assessment of Need (CAN). Secondary outcome measures will include psychopathology, level of disability, orientation toward recovery, self-stigma, and substance use. The study will be conducted in Portugal and will include individuals aged 18-65 years with any psychotic disorder diagnosis.

The Registry for Vascular Trauma and Follow-up Examinations is a clinical trial that aims to assess the long-term outcomes of patients with vascular injuries caused by trauma. The study will include patients aged 18 years and older who have suffered vascular injuries, and will involve regular follow-up examinations to assess the patency of grafts/vessels, reintervention rates, and the development of treatment patterns. The primary outcome measures include the patency of grafts/vessels, assessed through ultrasound, ABI-measurement, and CT/MRI scans, and the reintervention rate. The study will be conducted over an average of one year, with assessments at three time points: 3, 6, and 12 months after trauma.

The study will be a prospective randomized control trial consisting of subjects requiring ORIF of the distal radius. Subjects will be divided into two groups based on age, then subsequently be randomly divided into two groups following their inclusion in the study. Groups will be normalized based on gender. One group will undergo the normal rehabilitation protocol for the hand and wrist as determined by Dr. Liberman. The study group will undergo rehabilitation protocol for distal radius fractures modified by use of a tourniquet for blood flow restriction during selected exercises. The study will measure body composition/bone density, forearm girth, grip strength, pinch grip strength, DASH survey, Michigan Hand Outcomes survey, and Patient Rated Wrist Evaluation.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to assess the effectiveness of the Stand up for your Health® computer app in reducing sitting time, musculoskeletal symptoms, and improving cardiometabolic markers in sedentary office workers. The study will be conducted over a period of six months, with measurements taken at baseline, 3rd month, and 6th month. The intervention group will receive the computer prompt Stand up for your Health®, while the control group will only receive education through an information leaflet. The primary outcome measures will include sedentary behavior, cardiometabolic biomarkers, and musculoskeletal symptoms.

The study aims to investigate the effects of low-load blood flow restriction (BFR) and creatine supplementation on physical performance, body composition, and neuromuscular function in women. The study will be conducted over 9 months and will include 40 women who are recreationally active and not currently taking creatine supplements. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four groups: control, creatine and BFR exercise, creatine and no-BFR exercise, and placebo and no-BFR exercise. The primary outcome measures will include strength, body composition, neuromuscular function, and endothelial function, while secondary outcome measures will include mood states. The study will be double-blinded and randomized to ensure the validity and reliability of the results.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the levels of Growth Differentiation Factor-15 (GDF-15) in the plasma and cerebrospinal fluid of patients with anorexia nervosa (AN) and healthy controls. The study will also assess the correlation of GDF-15 levels with body composition and energy expenditure in AN patients. The study will enroll 8 patients with AN restrictive type, exercising subtype and 8 patients with AN restrictive type, non-exercising subtype, as well as 16 healthy controls. The primary outcome measures will be the levels of GDF-15 in the plasma and cerebrospinal fluid, and the correlation of these levels with body composition and energy expenditure. The study will be conducted over a period of 3 weeks, and will include assessments of body composition via Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DEXA) scans and of energy expenditure via indirect calorimetry.

The study aims to collect data on clinical, radiological and patient reported outcomes after pleural intervention. The study will be conducted in at least 20 centers across the UK and will include patients undergoing pleural procedures such as thoracocentesis, chest drain, indwelling pleural catheter, pleural biopsies, and medical thoracoscopy. The primary outcome measures will include complications such as bleeding, infection, pneumothorax, organ injury, pain, and re-expansion pulmonary oedema within 30 days. Secondary outcome measures will include patient reported outcome measures of dyspnoea and chest pain within 4 weeks. The study will provide a best practice standard for pleural interventions and will help to ensure patient safety.

The Artificial Intelligence for Preventing Heart Disease (AiPHD) study aims to develop a novel clinical-imaging AI-based model to identify and categorize patients at high risk of disease progression and provide a more personalized management approach to improve patient outcomes. The study will be conducted as an observational, single-center, prospective, and retrospective study. The primary outcome measures will be the composite outcome 1, which is death by cardiovascular events or non-fatal myocardial infarction, and composite outcome 2, which includes all-cause mortality, non-fatal myocardial infarction, hospitalization due to angina or angina-like symptoms, and late coronary revascularization. The study will enroll 2500 patients in the retrospective cohort and 500 patients in the prospective cohort. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida. The key terms related to the study include Artificial Intelligence, Proportional Hazards, Coronary Computed Tomography Angiography, and Major adverse cardiovascular events.

This is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled Phase II clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of different doses of Edaravone Dexborneol Concentrated Solution for Injection Combined With Conventional Medical Therapy in the Treatment of Patients With Cerebral Hemorrhage. The study will be conducted in two periods: Period A and Period B. In Period A, the subjects will be randomly assigned to receive either the Synbixin 37.5 mg or Synbixin 62.5 mg dose level, or the placebo group. In Period B, the subjects will be randomly assigned to receive the 62.5 mg dose level or the placebo group. The primary outcome measures will be the incidence of serious adverse events (SAEs) up to 90 days after the first dose of treatment, and the proportion of subjects with AEs, AEs leading to dose interruption or discontinuation, AEs related to study drug, AEs of special interest (AESls), and with abnormal vital signs, abnormal physical examination findings and abnormal laboratory tests results. The secondary outcome measures will include the proportion of subjects with modified Rankin Score (mRS) 0-2, which assesses the degree of disability or dependence in daily activities, with scores ranging from 0 (no symptoms) to 6 (death), at 90 days after the first dose of treatment, and the distribution of subjects with mRS, which assesses the degree of disability or dependence in daily activities, with scores ranging from 0 (no symptoms) to 6 (death), at 14, 30, 90 days after the first dose of treatment. The study will also evaluate the change from baseline in National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS), which quantifies the impairment caused by a stroke, with scores ranging from 0 (no stroke symptoms) to 42 (the most severe stroke), at 14, 30, 90 days after the first dose of treatment, and the proportion of subjects with NIHSS 0-2, which quantifies the impairment caused by a stroke, with

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Manzhi Guben granules in improving exercise tolerance and promoting body rehabilitation in patients with novel coronavirus infection. The study will be conducted as a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical study. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either Manzhi Guben granules or a placebo. The primary outcome measure will be the results of the 6-minute walking test on day 14 after treatment. Secondary outcome measures will include pulmonary ventilation function on days 14 and 28 after treatment. The study will enroll middle-aged and elderly outpatients aged 50-80, who have entered the convalescence phase of COVID-19 and have fatigue, shortness of breath, cough, and other symptoms. Exclusion criteria include severe and critically ill hospitalized patients with novel coronavirus infection, and patients with severe neurological, cardiac, pulmonary, hematopoietic, endocrine, musculoskeletal motor system and other primary diseases and mental disorders. The study will be conducted at multiple sites in China.

This study aims to investigate the neural bases of decision-making and executive functioning in healthy individuals using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). The study will assess the relationship between individual differences in decision-making and executive skills and their possible changes with ageing. The study will involve a behavioral assessment of decision-making and executive skills and a multimodal fMRI session including data concerning brain activity, structure, and connectivity. The results will provide a useful baseline for investigating alterations of decision-making and executive functioning in pathological conditions.

This study aims to investigate the usability of Neutrocheck amongst healthy volunteers and healthcare professionals. The study will be conducted in two phases. In the first phase, participants will be given paper instructions or app instructions to use Neutrocheck and their performance will be observed and recorded. In the second phase, participants will be asked to complete a questionnaire to assess the effectiveness of key information for safety and user satisfaction. The study will measure the identification of use errors, close calls and use difficulties associated with selected hazard-related use scenarios and participant's perceived root causes of these. Additionally, the study will compare descriptive statistics for task completion rates, user satisfaction and compare the results between the two study groups.

This study aims to improve the gait and walking abilities of individuals with Parkinson's disease using a new wearable device called Heel2Toe. The device provides real-time auditory feedback to help participants take better steps. The study will be conducted in two arms: an experimental arm where participants will receive the device immediately, and an active comparator arm where participants will receive the device after a delay of 3-4 weeks. The study will measure the effectiveness of the device in improving gait and walking abilities, as well as its impact on motivation, apathy, and quality of life. The study will also assess the device's usability and acceptability.

The study aims to investigate the effects of a laughter yoga program on the mood, anxiety, and loneliness among adolescents with intellectual and physical disabilities in a special school. The study is a randomized controlled trial with 40 adolescents randomly allocated to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group will receive a 4-week laughter yoga program, while the control group will receive routine care provided by the special school as usual. The primary outcome measures include mood, anxiety, and loneliness, which will be measured before and immediately after the intervention. The study will assess the feasibility and acceptability of the laughter yoga program among adolescents with intellectual and physical disabilities in a special school.

This randomized controlled trial aims to assess the effectiveness of decision aids in improving cervical cancer screening uptake among South Asian women. The study will recruit 300 participants and will be conducted in the Greater Manchester area. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three arms: a control group receiving a leaflet containing information about healthy lifestyles, an experimental group receiving a printed decision aid, or an experimental group receiving a mobile decision aid. The primary outcome measure will be decisional conflict, and secondary outcome measures will include cervical cancer screening uptake, risk perception, and screening decision. The study will be conducted over a period of three months, with follow-up assessments at baseline and two weeks after the intervention.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the additional effect of forward head posture correction on temporomandibular dysfunction. The study will be conducted on patients with mild to moderate myogenic TMD who have been diagnosed with forward head posture. The participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: conservative treatment only, conservative treatment with Denneroll cervical traction orthodontic, or placebo traction. The primary outcome measures will include anamnestic questionnaire, craniocervical angle, and mouth opening. The study will be conducted at the dental clinic of the University of Sharjah, and the participants will be recruited through advertisements and referrals. The study is expected to last for 7 weeks, with follow-up assessments at baseline, 3rd week, and 7th week.

The study is a parallel-group, open-label, randomized controlled trial to compare the efficacy of Clindamycin Phosphate 1% Gel versus Once-daily Dapsone 5% Gel in the treatment of Moderate Acne Vulgaris. The study will be conducted for 03 months. The primary outcome measure will be assessed using Global Acne Grading Score (GAGS).

This study aims to investigate the relationship between rotator cuff tear severity and scapular and rotator cuff muscle activation patterns. The study will use surface electromyography (sEMG) to assess muscle activation during functional tasks in participants with rotator cuff tears of different sizes. The primary outcome measure will be muscle activation amplitude, and secondary outcome measures will include differences in muscle activation patterns by tear size.

The SENIOR RCT is a multicenter study conducted in two North Italian Scientific Hospitalization and Treatment Institution in Pavia on older malnourished adults (≥ 65 years old). The estimated duration is 24 months, which include 6 months of nutritional intervention and a follow-up after 6 months, with an preferred starting date on January 2024. The primary objective of the SENIOR RCT is the evaluation of the efficacy of a 6 months sustainable nutrition protocol on malnourished older adults participants (diagnosed with the most recent GLIM criteria) in comparison to the hospital standard of care. Therefore, the primary endpoint is the improvement of the nutritional status between pre- and post-intervention between experimental and control group measuring the change of body weight and strength (handgrip). Secondary objectives are the change pre- and post-intervention between experimental and control group for blood biomarkers, dietary habits, quality of life and evaluation of sarcopenia.

The study aims to investigate the dynamic changes of Torque Teno Virus (TTV) load in Chinese renal transplant recipients during immunosuppressive therapy. The study is a double-blind, multicenter, prospective, observational cohort study. The primary outcome measures are any biopsy-proven acute rejection and clinical diagnosed acute rejection. The secondary outcome measures include infection events, donor-specific antibodies (DSA), and donor-derived cell-free DNA. The study will enroll 100 participants and will be conducted at two sites in China. The study is expected to be completed by December 31, 2023.

This study aims to compare the effectiveness of vitamin B3 and vitamin B12 in promoting nerve regeneration and functional recovery in children with severe traumatic brain injury (TBI). The study will enroll 300 participants, aged 6 to 15 years old, and will be conducted as an open-label, parallel-group trial. Participants will receive either vitamin B3 (up to 16 mg/day) or vitamin B12 (up to 250 mcg/day) for 18 months. The primary outcome measure will be the change in stair climb test (SCT) score, which evaluates functional strength, balance, and agility. The study will assess the effectiveness of both vitamins in promoting nerve regeneration and functional recovery in children with severe TBI.

This study is evaluating the efficacy and safety of pyrotinib in women with high-risk early-stage breast cancer. The study is an open-label, single-arm trial, and all participants will receive pyrotinib for one year after completing adjuvant anti-HER2 therapy. The primary outcome measure is invasive disease-free survival at year 2, and secondary outcome measures include disease-free survival at year 2, overall survival, and adverse events. The study is designed to assess the safety and efficacy of pyrotinib in this patient population and to provide information on the long-term outcomes of patients with high-risk early-stage breast cancer.

The study aims to assess the impact of consuming pasta at lunch or dinner on multiple health outcomes in normal-weight subjects. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with participants divided into two groups: one consuming pasta at lunch and the other at dinner. The primary outcome measures will include sleep quality, anthropometric parameters, cardiovascular risk factors, and gut microbiota composition and functionality. The study will run for 7 months, with assessments at the beginning and end of each of the two intervention phases.

This is an open-label, single-center, phase 2 study evaluating 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT imaging in up to 55 participants with multiple myeloma. Participants will be enrolled into one of two cohorts based on disease status; newly diagnosed multiple myeloma (NDMM) participants will be enrolled into Cohort 1 and relapsed refractory multiple myeloma (RRMM) participants will be enrolled into Cohort 2. All subjects will undergo an 18F-fluciclovine injection followed by a static whole-body PET/CT at three time points: Timepoint #1, Timepoint #2 (after induction for NDMM or at 6 months for RRMM), and Timepoint #3 (at progression or at 5 years). Results will be compared to 18F-FDG PET/CT imaging at those same timepoints. The primary purpose of this study is to determine the concordance between 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT and 18F-FDG PET/CT in participants with multiple myeloma.

This clinical trial is studying the arm swing during walking in early multiple sclerosis. The study is being conducted to evaluate the arm swing amplitude during walking in patients with early multiple sclerosis and healthy controls. The primary outcome measures include arm swing amplitude, step-speed, two-minute walk test, timed up and go, and timed 25-foot walk test. The study is designed to understand the changes in functional mobility in patients with early multiple sclerosis.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment, phase III clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of adjuvant Pyrotinib and Capecitabine for HER2 positive micro invasive breast cancer. The primary endpoint is invasive disease-free survival (iDFS) at 5 years. The secondary endpoints include distant disease-free survival (DDFS) and overall survival (OS) at 5 years. The study will enroll 200 patients and will be conducted at 10 centers in China.

Please provide a clear and concise summary of the clinical trial.

This is a pilot randomized controlled trial comparing the effectiveness of video biofeedback and laryngeal control therapy in the treatment of paradoxical vocal fold motion (PVFM). The primary outcome measure is the change in Dyspnea Index score before treatment and one month after treatment. Secondary outcome measures include responder rates, the Clinical Global Impressions - Improvement (CGI-I) score, and a qualitative survey. The study will enroll 20 participants per group and will be conducted at the Washington University School of Medicine Voice and Airway Center.

This study aims to evaluate the implementation of a multifaceted and multidisciplinary protocol to promote an improvement in sleep quality in critically ill patients. The study will be conducted in a quasi-experimental design, with a pre-sleep protocol group and a post-sleep protocol group. The primary outcome measure will be the change in the Richards-Campbell Sleep Quality Score, and secondary outcome measures will include changes in the Sleep in the ICU Questionnaire, Confusion Assessment Method for the ICU, Questionnaire on the patient's perception of sleep from the family member's point of view, Questionnaire for the evaluation of the multidisciplinary team regarding prior knowledge of sleep protocol, and changes in the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index and Epworth Sleepiness Scale. The study will be conducted in adult patients (18 years or older) who have spent at least two nights in the ICU and have neuropsychiatric conditions to respond to the sleep questionnaire. Exclusion criteria include neuropsychiatric conditions that prevent responding to the questionnaire, active alcoholism, active illicit drug use, severe withdrawal symptoms, and moribund patients. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This is a pilot study of a community pharmacy-based program to enhance adherence to adjuvant endocrine therapy among breast cancer survivors. The program consists of a web-based training for pharmacists, standardized consultation guides, and evidence-based web sheets. The study will be carried out in approximately 66 pharmacies in Quebec, Canada, and will include approximately 132 women. The primary outcome measures will be the intention to adhere to adjuvant endocrine therapy, adjuvant endocrine therapy knowledge, attitude towards adjuvant endocrine therapy, perceived social support, perceived behavioral control, anticipated regret, coping planning, fear of recurrence, and side effects. The study will also assess the acceptability and feasibility of the program and its implementation.

The study aims to investigate the effects of Melissa officinalis extract in phytosome form on sleep quality and duration in subjects with mild to moderate anxiety and sleep disorders. The study will be conducted as a randomized, double-blind, crossover design, with 2 arms: Melissa phytosome and placebo. The primary outcome measures will be sleep duration, perceived sleep quality, perceived anxiety, and quality of life. The study will be conducted over 6 weeks, with 5 weeks of study and 1 week of training. The devices will be configured to create a remote-accessible account for each participant, allowing researchers to record sleep-related data. The study will assess the effectiveness of Melissa phytosome in improving sleep quality and duration, as well as its impact on anxiety and quality of life.

The study is a randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment, multi-center Phase II clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of lenvatinib and tislelizumab plus CapeOX chemotherapy as first-line treatment for advanced gastric cancer or gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma with positive PD-L1 and low TMEscore. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival, and the secondary outcome measures include overall survival, objective response rate, disease control rate, and duration of response. The study will enroll approximately 120 patients and will be conducted at multiple centers in China.

This study aims to assess the effectiveness of Social Engage Coaching (S-ENG) in reducing loneliness and improving satisfaction with social activities in older adults living in senior living communities. The study will use a single-arm, open-label design, with 30 participants receiving S-ENG over a 4-month period. Participants will complete ecological momentary assessments (EMA) on smartphones to measure loneliness, satisfaction with social activities, and time in conversations and outside the home. The primary outcome measures will be loneliness and satisfaction with social activities, assessed at 16-week follow-up.

This study aims to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of higher doses of estrogen therapy in women with premature ovarian insufficiency (POI). The study will be conducted as a non-randomized, open-label, single-arm trial. Participants will receive transdermal estradiol gel 0.1% 1.5mg/day and 2.0mg/day, respectively, in addition to micronized progesterone 200mg vaginally for 14 days per cycle. The primary outcome measures will be the evaluation of the severity of estrogen deficiency symptoms, changing the assessment of quality of life, and changes in the level of sex hormones. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in bone mineral density and the level of follicle-stimulating hormone. The study will be conducted over 12 months, with assessments at baseline, 3 months, and 12 months.

The study aims to investigate the effects of a Limosilactobacillus reuteri probiotic and a prebiotic blend on the gut microbiome, immune system, and metabolome in obese individuals. The study will be conducted as a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial with four arms: probiotic, prebiotic, synbiotic, and placebo. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the four arms and will receive either the probiotic or prebiotic supplements or a combination of both, or a placebo, for eight weeks. The primary outcome measures will include changes in immune profile, faecal microbiome composition and diversity, and metabolic profile at eight weeks. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in satiety rating, gastrointestinal tolerance, and adverse events. The study will provide valuable insights into the potential benefits of the probiotic and prebiotic supplements in modulating the gut microbiome and improving immune function in obese individuals.

This study aims to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of AD16 tablets in healthy adults after a single oral administration. The study will be conducted as a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-escalating study. Seven dosing cohorts will receive a single oral dose of AD16 or placebo, and the primary outcome measures will include adverse events, serious adverse events, laboratory test results, vital signs, and electrocardiogram readings. The study will also measure the pharmacokinetics of AD16, including Tmax, Cmax, t1/2z, AUC 0-∞, AUC 0-t, CL/F, Vd/F, λz, and MRT. Secondary outcome measures will include the amount of drug excreted in urine and feces, renal clearance, and fecal excretion rate.

This study aims to measure the effect of urolithin A supplementation on endothelial function, cerebral blood flow regulation, and serum biomarkers of NO bioavailability and mitochondrial function in middle-aged adults with obesity. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either urolithin A supplementation or a placebo for 4 weeks. The primary outcome measures will include changes in arterial function and local stiffness, blood flow on the surface of the hand, homeostatic cerebral blood flow, plasma biomarkers of NO homeostasis, and plasma biomarkers of mitochondrial function.

This study aims to examine the effects of vibration applied at different frequencies with a percussion massage gun on joint range of motion, pain, functionality and kinesiophobia in individuals with cervical disc herniation. All individuals participating in the study will receive a conventional treatment program 4 days a week. In the conventional treatment program, heat will be applied to the neck area for 20 minutes and TENS (100 Hz) will be applied to the painful area. Additionally, patients will be given joint range of motion (ROM) exercises under the supervision of a physiotherapist. Patients will be asked to perform ROM exercises in 2 sets of 10 repetitions, holding for 2 seconds at the end point in all directions. As a strengthening exercise, isometric exercises will be given in the flexion extension, right and left lateral flexion directions by waiting for 6 seconds at the end point. Isometric exercises will be performed in 2 sets of 10 repetitions with 1 minute rest between sets. Vibration Group Vibration application will be applied to the individuals in this group in addition to conventional methods. Vibration application will be applied to the trapezius, levator scapula and cervical paravertebral muscles with a percussion massage gun (Compex Fix 2.0) along the origo-insersio line for 3 minutes for each muscle group. Vibration application will be made with the soft head of the percussion massage gun. Vibration therapy will be applied 3 days a week for 3 weeks.

The study aims to create a register of patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) for a comprehensive assessment of the influence of gender characteristics, clinical and anamnestic factors, body composition, topical characteristics of congestion, instrumental data, and markers of cellular inflammation and stress on immediate and long-term outcomes in patients with acute decompensated heart failure with preserved ejection fraction.

=========
The study aims to adapt and pilot the Brothers Building Brothers by Breaking Barriers (B6) intervention for telehealth delivery (Tele-B6) among young Black gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men (YB-GBMSM) living with HIV. The study will evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy of Tele-B6 compared to a waitlist control group. The primary outcome measures will include acceptability, change in perception of structural racism and discrimination, change in perception of HIV stigma, and change in perception of internalized homonegativity. The study will also assess the impact of Tele-B6 on retention, intervention fidelity, safety, and minority stress. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial with a waitlist control design. Participants will be recruited from an established community-based organization (CBO) in Atlanta, Georgia.

DTTC is a motor-based intervention where the client watches, listens to and imitates the clinician. Treatment follows a temporal hierarchy where children receive multisensory cueing to establish accurate movements. The study aims to investigate the impact of parent/caregiver involvement on DTTC treatment outcomes in children with CAS. Participants will be randomized to either the Direct Training Group (DTTC + Home Practice + Direct Caregiver Training) or the Indirect Training Group (DTTC + Home Practice + Indirect Caregiver Training). The study will assess changes in whole word accuracy, phoneme accuracy, speech intelligibility, and functional communication.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of workshops and exchange groups for laryngectomized patients. The study will include 40 patients who will participate in a cycle of four sessions over four months. The primary outcome measures will be differences in quality of life scores before and after the program, between the program and non-program control groups. The secondary outcome measures will be the average patient scores for overall quality of life and ENT-specific quality of life before and after the program. The study will also evaluate the participation rate during each session.

MS-DETECT is a clinical trial that aims to assess the effectiveness and safety of the MSCopilot® Detect mobile application in detecting disability worsening in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS). The study will evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of the MSCopilot® Detect application in detecting clinically meaningful worsening (disability worsening) based on the revised-MSFC, and its ability to detect disease progression in the absence of a relapsing activity (PIRA). Additionally, the study will assess the reproducibility and reliability of MSCopilot® Detect individual scores and/or composite scores at-home over time, and the association between MSCopilot® Detect individual scores and/or composite scores and clinical scores. The study will also evaluate the patient quality of life (QoL) and their association with MSCopilot® Detect individual and composite scores. The study will be conducted as a single-arm, open-label, multi-center study, and will include 180 patients with RRMS or SPMS.

The PCOS Challenge Study is a registry study that aims to collect information to advance research and improve care for PCOS patients. The study is open to individuals diagnosed with PCOS or exhibiting symptoms, and will collect information through surveys over a one-year period. The study will compare the outcomes of individuals with PCOS to those without the condition, and will use keywords provided by the Centre Hospitalier Valida to track the study's progress.

This is a cluster-randomized trial of low molecular weight heparins. The study will evaluate whether treatment with any of the low molecular weight heparins will increase the risk of bleeding requiring blood transfusion during admission or death within 30 days in patients with indication for low molecular weight heparins. The study will also evaluate the risk of all-cause mortality within 30 and 365 days, blood transfusion during admission, pulmonary embolism, deep venous thrombosis, heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, liver failure, and length of hospital admission. The study will be conducted in patients with indication for low molecular weight heparins.

The study aims to compare the effects of two respiratory muscle training protocols, inspiratory muscle training (IMT) and expiratory muscle training (EMT), on inspiratory and expiratory muscle strength in adults with acquired brain injury. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial, with 8 weeks of training, and will assess the primary outcome measures of inspiratory and expiratory muscle strength, as well as secondary outcome measures of pulmonary volume and flow. The study will be conducted in a rehabilitation center, and participants will be randomly assigned to either the IMT or EMT group.

The ASARD-TMA study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of an automated surveillance, alert, and rapid diagnosis system for the diagnosis of thrombotic microangiopathies (TMAs) in patients admitted to the emergency department or inpatients of involved hospitals. The study will assess the time taken for diagnosis and treatment of TMAs using the automated algorithm and compare it with the current clinical practice. The study will be conducted in two phases, with the first phase focusing on the development and validation of the automated algorithm, and the second phase focusing on the implementation and evaluation of the system in clinical settings.

The study is designed to assess the feasibility of the Access-H2O faucet for individuals with spinal cord injuries. The study will determine if subjects can activate the faucet to control water outputs via the motion sensor, eye gaze, and speech speaker. The primary outcome measures will assess the subjects' ability to access water for activities of daily living.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of an activity wristband-based intermittent teaching unit in promoting physical activity and its psychological mediators among secondary education students. The study will be conducted as a cluster-randomized controlled trial, with two arms: an intervention group that will receive the intermittent teaching unit, and a control group that will not receive the intervention. The primary outcome measures will include changes in perceived autonomy support, basic psychological needs, motivation toward physical education, self-determined motivation towards physical activity, intention to be physically active, and habitual physical activity. The study will be conducted over eight weeks, with assessments at pre-intervention, immediately post-intervention, and after a six-week follow-up.

The study is designed to assess the agreement of Task Force® CORE/CARDIO with a reference device in measuring blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output during autonomic function testing (AFT) in patients with orthostatic intolerance. The study will be conducted in a single-center, randomized, controlled, and crossover design. Participants will be randomly assigned to undergo AFT with either the Task Force® CORE/CARDIO or the reference device, and the order will be reversed for the second test. The primary outcome measures will include the agreement of blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output between the two devices. The study will enroll 20 participants with orthostatic intolerance.

The proposed research project aims to develop and implement a successful and effective digital care plan for post-secondary students in Ontario, Canada, using AI-assisted online interventions. The study will assess the effectiveness of online psychoeducation and diagnosis-specific e-CBT programs in improving mental health outcomes, such as anxiety, depression, stress, quality of life, resilience, social anxiety, and ADHD symptoms. The study will use a stepped-care approach, starting with online psychoeducation and progressing to diagnosis-specific e-CBT programs based on the AI algorithm's recommendations. The study will also monitor the success and fidelity of the programs using surveys and focus groups.

This study aims to assess the efficacy of Omnivirol-Salicylic Acid (AV2-SA) combination therapy for cutaneous warts, with a focus on persistent warts. The study will be conducted as a randomized, parallel-group, quadruple-masked, controlled clinical trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either AV2-SA or standard Salicylic Acid (SA) treatment. The primary outcome measures will be the cure rate and recurrence rate of the index warts at 12 weeks and 6 months after enrollment, respectively. Secondary outcome measures will include the number of participants with treatment-related adverse events, time to clearance of index wart, change in size of index wart, and number of verrucae remaining. The study will also investigate the prevalence of mucosal HPV types in cutaneous warts.

This study aims to assess the efficacy of letrozole in the treatment of ectopic pregnancy. The study will be conducted on 75 pregnant women who have been diagnosed with ectopic pregnancy. The patients will be randomly assigned to three groups: the first group will receive a single dose of methotrexate, the second group will receive letrozole twice a day for 10 days, and the third group will receive letrozole three times a day for 5 days. The primary outcome measures will be the level of βhCG and anti-müllerian hormone. The study will be conducted over a period of 14 days.

This cross-sectional study aims to evaluate the effect of fenestrated closure compared to non-fenestrated closure to the left ventricular size at systole and diastole in patients with atrial septal defect and pulmonary hypertension. The study will be conducted on patients who underwent surgical closure of ASD with fenestrated or non-fenestrated patch. The primary outcome measure will be the change in left ventricular diameter during both systole and diastole, measured preoperatively and postoperatively. The study will be conducted from January 2017 to October 2021.

This study aims to investigate the role of oxidative stress and mitochondrial TERT in the progression and therapeutic resistance of papillary thyroid cancer. The study will measure the levels of H202 generation, TERT mitochondrial localization, and the effects of exogenous oxidative stress and therapeutic agents on TERT nuclear to mitochondrial translocation in thyroid cancer cell lines. Additionally, the study will investigate the mitochondrial oxidative stress generation, proliferation, apoptosis, and migration in cells lines treated with Src kinase inhibitors. The study will also perform genetic and expression profile characterization of tumor tissues.

The COMET trial is a randomized controlled trial that aims to assess the effectiveness of whole-body hypothermia versus targeted normothermia in infants with mild hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy. The study will be conducted at 20 neonatal units in the UK and will include 400 infants. The primary outcome measure will be the mean cognitive composite score from the Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development IV at 22 to 26 months of age. Secondary outcome measures will include neonatal seizures, duration of intensive care, duration of hospital stay, duration of mechanical ventilation, duration of inotropic support, number of babies with bloodstream or cerebrospinal fluid positive infection, number of babies with thrombocytopenia or coagulopathy requiring transfusion of blood products, opioid use, number of babies exclusively breastfeeding at hospital discharge, brain injury scores on conventional magnetic resonance imaging, survival without any neurological impairment, and preschool child behaviour checklist (CBCL 1½-5) at 22 to 26 months of age.

The study aims to investigate the diagnostic and prognostic role of serum amyloid A (SAA) in intrathoracic sarcoidosis. The study will compare the serum concentrations of SAA in patients newly diagnosed with intrathoracic sarcoidosis to healthy controls and assess the correlation of SAA with other biomarkers of granulomatous inflammation and pulmonary interstitial disease, lung function test results, radiologic extent of disease, and changes in lung function tests and HRCT disease extent after 3 years of follow-up.

Please provide a concise summary of the study.

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to assess the benefit of early intrauterine transfer of blank culture medium prior to transfer of a thawed embryo from the first in vitro fertilization. The study will be conducted on women who have had a previous failure of embryo transfer and have at least two embryos eligible for transfer or freezing during a first IVF attempt. The study will be conducted in a parallel group design, with a sham comparator group, and will be single-blinded. The primary outcome measures will be the clinically progressive pregnancy rate, occurrence of pregnancy, occurrence of a biochemical pregnancy, occurrence of a clinical pregnancy, and occurrence of an early miscarriage. The study will be conducted over a period of three years.

This study aims to construct a database of prognostic risk factors and quality of life of patients with primary solid malignant cancers receiving immunotherapy for the first time based on questionnaire surveys. The study will collect baseline and follow-up information on patients' demographic characteristics, tumor and anti-tumor history, quality of life scores, and outcome measures such as progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS). The study will provide high-level evidence-based medical evidence for the selection of immunotherapy schemes, the precise prevention and health management of adverse reactions after immunotherapy, and the further improvement of survival prognosis of patients.

This study aims to investigate the effect of acupressure on back pain in the late postpartum period after cesarean section. The study will be conducted with a randomized controlled design, and the participants will be divided into two groups: the acupressure group and the control group. The participants in the acupressure group will receive acupressure applications, while the participants in the control group will not receive any application. The study will be conducted with 70 participants, and the data will be collected using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) to assess back pain. The study will be conducted over a period of 4 weeks, and the participants will be evaluated at the end of the first week and the fourth week after birth. The primary outcome measures will be the VAS scores for back pain before and after the application, and the secondary outcome measures will be the VAS scores for back pain at the end of the first month after birth.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of confidential social network referrals for HIV testing in Tanzania. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either CONSORT referrals (behavioral intervention) or card referrals (active comparator). The primary outcome measure will be the uptake of HIV testing among referred clients. The study will be conducted in Moshi, Tanzania, and will include individuals aged 18 years or older who are literate and live, work, or regularly receive care in the area.

This is a randomized, placebo-controlled trial to assess the effects of paroxetine on cardiovascular function in patients with septic shock. The study will be conducted in adult patients diagnosed with septic shock for less than 48 hours and using a minimum dose of noradrenaline. The primary outcome measure will be time to vasopressor discontinuation, and secondary outcome measures will include cumulative vasopressor dose, variation in cardiovascular sequential organ failure assessment score, and length of stay in the ICU. The study will be conducted in a parallel-assignment, quadruple-masked manner, and the sample size will be calculated based on the decision of the study management committee.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of a tele-education program in patients with moderate depressive episodes in primary care. The program consists of 5 individual remote sessions over 5 weeks, with a focus on educational diagnosis, personalized hygienic and dietary measures, identifying symptoms of depression, and providing clear information on antidepressants. The control group will receive standard care as usual. The primary outcome measure is the rate of maintenance on continuous antidepressant medication at 6 months after inclusion. Secondary outcome measures include changes in feelings of self-efficacy and barriers to treatment.

This is a pilot observational study to assess the ability of continuous 'home' EEG to accurately diagnose narcolepsy and demonstrate response to treatment. The study will recruit participants already under investigation within GSTT children and adult sleep service for hypersomnolence. The primary outcome measures will be the sensitivity, specificity, and positive and negative predictive values of the Dreem headband derived EEG in predicting a final diagnosis of narcolepsy derived from gold standard in-patient clinical testing with polysomnography and multiple sleep latency test ICSD-3 protocol.

This is a Phase 1/Phase 2, open-label, dose-escalation, and dose expansion study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of SAR444836, an adeno-associated viral vector-mediated gene transfer of human phenylalanine hydroxylase, in adult participants with phenylketonuria. The study will be conducted in two phases: Phase 1 will be a dose-escalation phase, and Phase 2 will be a dose expansion phase. Participants will receive a single dose of SAR444836 on Day 1. The primary outcome measures will be the incidence of treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs) and the proportion of participants with sustained plasma level of Phe <360 μmol/L for ≥4 weeks without dietary Phe restriction at Week 24 and Week 96 or End of Study following SAR444836 administration.

This clinical trial aims to assess the clinical applicability of pseudo-continuous arterial spin labeling (pCASL) as a substitute for fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (FDG-PET) in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and subjective cognitive decline (SCD). The study will evaluate the correlation between brain hypoperfusion and brain hypometabolism at baseline and the predictive properties of brain hypoperfusion and brain hypometabolism for conversion to dementia. Additionally, the study will analyze differences in brain perfusion patterns according to amyloid and tau status and correlations between brain hypoperfusion and neuropsychological tests, CSF, and blood biomarkers.

This is a single-arm, multicenter, observational safety surveillance study of VyndaMx® (Tafamidis Capsule 61 mg) in patients with transthyretin amyloid cardiomyopathy (ATTR-CM) in India. The study will assess the safety of VyndaMx® Capsules and will be conducted at multiple sites in India. The primary outcome measure will be the number of adverse events with Tafamidis within 6 months of first dosing.

The study is a randomized controlled clinical trial to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of the STERN FIX device as a sternal stabilization system in patients after sternotomy. The study will be conducted in patients undergoing surgery that requires median sternotomy, and will compare the STERN FIX device with standard of care wires. The primary outcome measure will be sternal stability, evaluated through clinical assessment using the sternal instability scale. Secondary outcome measures will include safety, device deficiencies, reinterventions, sternal wound infections, dehiscence, sternal closure time, ease of use, surgeon satisfaction, chest pain, blood loss, upper limb functional index, quality of life, sternal halves union/malunion, sternal halves alignment, sternum integrity, and closure system integrity. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida, and will include patients aged 18 years or older with a body mass index (BMI) of 30 or less, and no serious osteoporosis or degenerative bone disease affecting the sternum. Exclusion criteria include suspected or known allergies or intolerance to the device material, serious osteoporosis or degenerative bone disease affecting the sternum, and certain medical conditions or medication use that may interfere with the device's function or study participation. The study will be double-masked, and will randomize patients to receive either the STERN FIX device or standard of care wires. The study is expected to enroll 120 patients and will be completed within 6 months.

This is a randomized controlled study to evaluate the effect of an active break on reduce LBP and perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting in young people with LBP. Participants will be randomly assigned to the intervention group (active break with postural change from sitting to standing) or the control group (self-care recommendations). The primary outcome measures will be average pain intensity, disability, and perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting, and The Global Perceived Effect. The study will be conducted among students, aged 18-25 years, with non-specific low back pain, pain of at least 3 months' duration, without radiation to legs, and without surgical history due to spinal problems.

The study aims to assess the safety and efficacy of tocopherol acetate administered vaginally in pre-peri and postmenopausal women. The primary outcome measures include acidity measure of vaginal secretions, rate of vaginal mucosa dryness, rate of vaginal mucosal integrity, rate of mucosa pallor, quantity of vaginal discharge assessment, whiff test, and rate of Lactobacillus grade according to Ison Hay's classification by bacterioscopic smear. The study will be conducted as a single-arm, open-label study, and all participants will receive the tocopherol acetate vaginal ovules for 14 days. The study will assess the effectiveness of tocopherol acetate in maintaining the vaginal eubiosis and the balance of the microbiota in pre-peri and postmenopausal women.

The study aims to assess the Hematocrit to Hemoglobin Ratio and Red Blood Cell Distribution Width in Polycythemia Vera and Secondary Erythrocytosis. The study will collect data about clinical manifestations, history of thrombosis, and investigations such as complete blood picture, including Hematocrit and haemoglobin level, serum uric acid, JAK2V617F mutation status, bone marrow aspiration, and biopsy with reticulin stain. The study will be conducted at Sohag University Hospital, specifically in the internal medicine department and chest department. The study will recruit newly diagnosed patients with polycythemia vera and secondary erythrocytosis from December 2022 to September 2023. The primary outcome measures will be Hematocrit to Hemoglobin Ratio and Red Blood Cell Distribution Width in both groups.

The study aims to determine the effect of PI measurement on the emergency triage classification in patients with dyspnea. The study will be conducted on adult patients who present with dyspnea and whose perfusion index values are measured with Masimo Radical-7 device at the time of admission, at the first hour and the second hour of admission. The primary outcome measures will be the use of perfusion index for triage status determination. The study will be conducted as an open-label, single-group assignment, and the participants will be assigned to the experimental group.

This is a randomized, double-blind, active-placebo controlled phase II study to assess the efficacy and safety of Lysergic Acid Diethylamide (LSD) in patients with palliative care needs. The primary outcome measures are changes in state anxiety, pain levels, quality of life, demoralization, and spiritual well-being. Secondary outcome measures include changes in depression, isolation, anxiety, fear, and denial of imminence of death, and pre-occupation with pain, as well as changes in patient behavior and attitudes, caregiver burden, and adverse events. The study will enroll 120 participants and will be conducted at a single center in Germany.

The SmartMom study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a text messaging intervention in promoting healthy behaviors during pregnancy. The study will enroll 1,200 pregnant women in Canada and will be conducted over a period of 42 weeks, from enrollment to birth. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, which will receive three text messages per week with evidence-based information on healthy behaviors during pregnancy, or the control group, which will receive one text message per week with general information about pregnancy. The primary outcome measures will include changes in weight during pregnancy, attendance at prenatal care visits, and health literacy at the end of pregnancy. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in fear of childbirth, depression, anxiety, and use of tobacco, vaping, alcohol, or cannabis during pregnancy. The study will also assess the incremental costs per incidence of suboptimal weight gain and inadequate prenatal care avoided.
